content.name: SoapDog (SPX/win32)
content.description:
This almost works...

This identity might break soon. Running SSB as Win32 app on ARM64 hardware.

content.text: Just to confirm that Patchfox runs under Firefox for Windows 10 on ARM. Getting `ssb-server` to run is the tricky part. Damn native modules.

[【﻿Ｎｅｔｓｃａｐｅ Navigator™】](@z2M8msI2EUubNHnrEJncglDIy2/SUd+36jCyJnfeiHk=.ed25519),

Right now it kinda sucks because it is running under emulation.

I'm running patchwork as the server because I couldn't really get any other app working, not even plain simple `ssb-server` from the command line. I've rebuilt patchwork to use win32-ia32 arch, so it launches and runs but it is slow and sometimes it fails to respond (as in the server part fails to respond, which makes patchfox wait wait wait forever).

This all could soon be in the past because the machine is really fast when running proper arm64/aarch64 apps. I do have a prebuilt version of nodejs 12 for ARM here but it fails when I do node-gyp stuff. Building native stuff on windows is really hard and the way the NodeJS ecosystem is basically an infinite game of jenga using `node_modules` as the tiles, it becomes quite fragile. Lots of fourth and fifth party dependencies end up trying to compile something.

So far I've managed to compile stuff to x86 but I haven't managed to compile things for ARM64...
Started following a bunch of hermies, just enough to get FOAF data into this machine... :-)

[kira](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519),

Happy Birthday!!! Feliz Aniversário!!! All the best to you and yours! May your day be filled with joy, love, and all the stuff you like! :heart: :smiley_cat: :sparkle:

I'm trying to switch to a Surface Pro X as my main machine. Many here know about my love for the Surface form-factor and this looked like a great machine with perfect specs for my very mobile use cases. Still, the ARM64 processor in irs heart poses a lot of challenges to the SSB stack, not because we can't do ARM but because the tools are not ready for doing ARM on Windows.

So, to make this work, I have a gutted version of `scuttle-shell` running under WSL (no systray). From the nodejs point of view, it is just running under Ubuntu under ARM, so, not unlike a Raspberry Pi. Everything works great.

I then connect to it at the moment using Patchfox which is compiled using _NodeJS for x86-32 Win32_ because compiling native modules under _ARM64 Win32_ is basically impossible (getting Visual Studio 2019 to run its x86 win32 cross-compiler to ARM64 upon node-gyp invocation is a mess). After Patchfox is compiled through clever x86 win32 emulation (which works better than we deserve), it is run under Firefox which has a native ARM64 edition for windows (THANK YOU MOZ) and flies on this machine.

Which means I am almost ready to completely switch to this machine. The good news is that there is already both Electron 6.x and 7.x for Windows on ARM and NodeJS. The only missing bit is the node-gyp stuff.

I still need to switch to my Surface Go or my mac to do real work with Electron at the moment but the future is quite bright for ARM64 IMHO.

  ![photo_2019-11-27_22-08-27.jpg](&Jez7JX9il/8MH6N23DchD41/HH/AGfl5e1wgbqlhyLI=.sha256)
_Some memory consumption data_

 ![photo_2019-11-27_22-08-36.jpg](&5DNiXZmh07Pd2Rsz031Gi1++Xljr765ZFFqYvIh1f+g=.sha256)
_WSL under ARM64 under Windows 10_

One tricky thing I've noticed is that `ssb-ws` is not listening on localhost or 127.0.0.1 and instead it is listening on the public IP which makes it quite hard to set the remote for Patchfox. I think something changed in how the server part of SSB deals with listening and connections and I am a bit lost. I don't understand why `ssb-ws` wouldn't bind to localhost, it makes sense to do it.

cc #ssb-learning

[andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519),

Move gifted us professional-looking photos during the last [Mozilla Tech Speakers](https://events.mozilla.org/techspeakers) meetup in Amsterdam.

Oh, and [the program is open for application for the 2020 cohort](https://discourse.mozilla.org/t/application-now-open-for-mozilla-tech-speakers-2020-cohort/48782).

Trying to install patchfoo here but I am lost in a bootstrapping problem.

I managed to get the `ssb-npm-registry` running but trying to install `ssb-npm` with either:

```
$ npm install --registry=http://localhost:8043/ -g ssb-npm
```

or

```
$ mkdir -p /tmp/ssb-npm-registry-1.10.2 && cd /tmp/ssb-npm-registry-1.10.2 &&
curl -s 'http://localhost:8989/blobs/get/&U7z22fE8SpMiwZMQtUdDvbRUQ9NHTAXdosjzcJD3j/I=.sha256' | tar xz &&
./package/bootstrap/bin.js --ws-url http://localhost:8989 \
  --branch %1WiEpn3ymmfO4n7k5Q7V3mIQUO4+v2nlFomxYZhPYyY=.sha256 \
  -- install -g ssb-npm@1.7.1
```

Hang at some module. On the first case it is hanging at `pull-handshake`.

I'm following Cel so I guess I can ask for blobs.. don't know what is wrong.

This affects patchfox as well, a lot.

I'm now deriving the address from whatever you specified in the `remote` configuration but this is not fail-proof and requires you to change your `remote` manually to point at the correct IP.

I don't understand why this change was made. I wrecks a ton of code that assumed localhost, why not bind to it by default as well as binding to whatever changes are currently in place?

[cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519),

content.text:
Patchfox can edit profile metadata now.

 ![profile editing.gif](&692uDn+Gr9GxH34SbEtk2VJ5WqIrNqCBDc/mnQTbI4o=.sha256)

[RangerMauve](@tdeT1cU3xUQaD2Ne5Ox0Dndly50qS+c5+//Fl7tyPqg=.ed25519),

It is good to do research before acting. My suggestion is to:

### Step 1: create research working group.

Find who of your friends is keen to help with research. You need these three roles filled:

* _Stringer:_ This person will research NGOs/Charities/Projects/etc that your team admires or recognize as doing something well in the space you want to act. The main take-aways from this person works are contacts in the projects you admire, a blurb why said project was select as inspiration. This can all be done with just the internet and a phone.
* _Notetaker:_ This person will keep a journal once you visit and interview people/projects selected by the _stringer_.
* _Photographer:_ This person (which should not be the notetaker) will keep a photo journal of the research. Photos of course need to be done only with consent of all involved.
* _Interviewer:_ This person will guide the interview process.

### Step 2: research.

The _stringer_ after talking with all the team to identify your shared values and dreams will research which ngos/projects/charities/etc that are a match. The results will be presented and discussed. You'll then try to arrange an opportunity to visit and interview people in each of the selected projects. As a team, you'll decide on questions, hypothesis and things to observe and identify in those visits you've arranged.

The _interviewer_, _notetaker_ and _photographer_  go into the projects. What you're trying to gauge is more about the real life of such projects, their challenges, theory of change and impact on the group you want to affect. It is good to talk to the homeless and ask them about the project/ngo you're in outside of the range of the personel from said project/ngo. Ask everything. Keep asking. Take notes. 

### Step 3: Dive into your data.

Spend a long time with your team over your data.

* What chanllenges you've spotted that no one is able to solve?
* What good opportunities are there to either join forces with other projects or empower/multiply other people working on the same area?
* After seeing the real world, what caused most empathy in your team? What made you want to act?

### Step 4: Your planning matrix

Decide what is your dream. What do you want to act upon? Then, build a [planning matrix](https://andregarzia.com/2015/12/tools-for-causing-impact.html) for it. Sorry for the broken markdown tables in that post, I'll fix it as soon as I can. The important thing about planning matrices is that they are S.M.A.R.T. (specific, measurable, ambitious, responsible and time bound).

If you use the described 6-column version, you'll have a kick-ass tool to plan your actions and measure if they are actually working.

I've used this approach to manage a social project for Mozilla in vulnerable areas of Rio in the past, [this is our report from our 1-month of research](https://webmaker-dist.s3.amazonaws.com/reports/rio.pdf) which we executed before actually starting our social program. We used this to inform and plan what we were actually doing. We used personas to frame our knowledge in this report and it worked great.

Time spent researching leads to more positive outcomes later when you're acting.
[emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) I like it! :D :D :D

[kira](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519),

content.title: A Week With The Surface Pro X
content.summary: I've spent a bit more than a week with my new [Surface Pro X](https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/p/surface-pro-x/). What follows is review of my experiences with it as a try to set it all up for it to become my main machine. Be aware dear reader that this is not a review with benchmarks, graphs, and comparisons with alternative machines. This is a personal account and ecosystem commentary of how it has been working for a single person and what this person (me!) is feeling about it. That being said, read on for the nitty and gritty details.

content.text: Sorry folks, somehow I borked the blog post. It has duplicate content in it. Part of it is Racket Scribble language and then it has the correct markdown. My bad. Wish I could delete it, but hey, it is still readable.

[flaki](@71u5seNcvqBKbpVboQ3bpdpG0X8Dci/nXibw7V9vCRM=.ed25519),

Yaaayyy!!! I'm working on it right now :-)

Did you used the git version or the AMO version?

[flaki](@71u5seNcvqBKbpVboQ3bpdpG0X8Dci/nXibw7V9vCRM=.ed25519),

I'm working on it. I need to fix that but it is soooo hard rsrsrs. The best experience is Patchwork and Patchbay IMHO, they are much more mature than my own patchfox but I am constantly working on it and on my new machine it is the only client I have so either I get it to work well or I'm screwed.

# Hiding channels on Patchfox

So there has been a lot of recent talk here about development noise and I am sorry to add to it but I want to show you all that it is very easy to filter out content in Patchfox. If you're running the AMO version, you can go to settings and fill the data for the filter, but what I'm showing here is a new quicker way that I've just implemented.

In the little GIF below, I'm going to a channel that I want to filter out and adding a filter to it. After that, messages from that channel will no longer appear in any of my views. When I'm done with it and want to see that channel again, I can simply go to the filters page on settings and delete it.

 ![filtering_channel.gif](&hO34qmuUauTmLjjPB0RBP6hRaRHdeRe9iGTvwxp2c04=.sha256)

Now, if developers could always post to some appropriate channel, that would be great :smiley_cat:

content.text:
# Zine App

So the next major revolution for Patchfox is the inclusion of little mini apps inside it. These apps a small self-contained web apps that work _outside_ of the UX provided by the client. This avoid cluttering the main client UI with features while still being able to provide cool stuff to the users.

> **Attention:** This stuff is not ready. I plan to ship the initial mini apps in December but since I don't have many backers, the time I can devote to this project is a bit limitted.

## The launcher

Pressing `CTRL+M` or selecting _Launcher_ from the Patchfox menu will display the new launcher, which is a kind of modal menu that It looks like this:

![Patchfox: launcher](&lrOOLN9bL8I6/si2DcG32PBaWODA1fmrVyRtceIOb7Q=.sha256)

There are two tabs in the launcher, one for the apps and another for all the packages. Patchfox is nothing but a collection of little packages that depend on each other. This is how the other tab looks:

![Patchfox - Public - Firefox Developer Edition 2019-12-04 17.20.18.png](&wRJBj6gQpEHtbwYjyvzTM3SLW1Jos5uSh6Rz0N0pvBg=.sha256)

Lets launch the _Zine_ app.

## The Zine app

The Zine app is a new way to consume ssb content.

 ![Patchfox - Public - Firefox Developer Edition 2019-12-04 17.23.57.png](&nRQBRazgMF6NQ/Vm833Vwegazz0vCt2/V++DGXjRuHk=.sha256)

It provides a tile interface that displays the last 20 root posts and blogs for a given channel. On the topleft corner there is a dropdown menu for you to select what channel you want to see from your list of subscribed channels.

For each card being displayed, you can can click on the arrow on the bottom right corner to go to that thread. The idea is that this view is like a little zine or newspaper that allows you to quickly browser content you like using a neat interface.

I might need help with sorting messages because I see a mix of old and new stuff in there. Maybe is is actually working and the last 20 posts on a given channel do go back to 2 years ago or something. Anyway, I hope this kind of thing excites you all.

Notice how the app takes over the whole screen. This is another difference between launching a little app and just using the normal client UI.

There are other little apps coming...

[KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519), ❤😻💕 I was hoping you'd like it! 

(it is on git right now but it is kinda wonky)
[fireglow](@MAPpha5bEXSpHNlxNTdb/4UiEVafibOuJIr/GSrCDFE=.ed25519) but thats a feature. 😊
rsrsrs I love zines but maybe I named this wrong as it is just another way to consume normal content... it is not like the amazing zine stuff that has been floating here.

[Rabble](@THUzexG1y6kWofwiN8Lix/jNH/P6roYdlCDgpAn2HSc=.ed25519) I really want to go towards that route of little apps. To make it work today, we need something like scuttle shell running. An unobstrusive little daemon providing SSB serving/gossiping/db, so that other apps can connect to it. At Scuttle Camp One we had lots of talk about different approaches to handle this (lessbot, fatbot, nobot, etc) but I haven't kept following all the discussions after the event but I have the feeling that we still don't have a solution.

If we had a local daemon that provided clients with both muxrpc kind of API and PatchQL or whatever then we could even go as far as shipping PWAs. We're soooo close to being able to birth a thousand clients. I have high hopes for a self contained go-based or rust-based daemon. NodeJS is too hard to packages as a deployable binary if you're not using electron.

[wu-lee](@TYYml9T3ap+S5EIN5FV99YDfLOsl7Qb8kdiFNAFRp9s=.ed25519) Welcome to SSB! I work for a company based in Edinburgh but I'm in London. I'm there quite often though.

:D :D :D

friends,

quick question, is there a way to launch patchwork and have it connect to a running sbot instead of it starting its own?
[sean](@N/vWpVVdD1e8IbACUQE4EVGL6+aodQfbQZ8ByC+k79s=.ed25519) omg, this is sooo beautiful. It looks like a movie set.

[moid](@Sur8RwcDh6kBjub8pLZpHNWDfuuRpYVyCHrVo+TdA/4=.ed25519),

I love that they work well for this case. They were created to allow self-moderation in terms of abuse prevention and personal healthcare online, but will also work for lightweight filtering like this.

Have you seen the little zine mini app I showed in [my last message on patchfox channel](%SKbm/cyZI2tU6gJAP2/4C4hIkfcS8ZhYVJXNSbQS8WE=.sha256)? It is yet another way to prioritize content you like.

Installing #patchfoo using `npm install --registry=http://localhost:8043` worked and finally I can see private msgs on this machine rsrsrs. Thanks @cel

I'm using `npm 6.13.2` and that was after the bootstrap completed. I didn't saw any error there it appeared to run fine. I'm still able to use `ssb-npm` if I just use normal _npm_ and point the registry back to the `ssb-npm-registry`.
oh my dear butt! This is awesome!
Awesome people!

LoRaWAN is awesome. There is a lot of cool stuff to play with. Adafruit is your friend.

PS: My router just received an update to support LoRaWAN.

# Patchfox invoice

I just submit an [invoice](https://opencollective.com/patchfox/expenses/12259) for Patchfox development expenses. I've of course worked more than _half a day_ in Patchfox but this is the amount of work that matches the amount of budget I have on Open Collective rsrsrs.

[Ace](@rUntanbH1/pIEpkuTGVokZIl+8u7jBuroTVraNpu1cE=.ed25519),

I suspect you'll enjoy [starlight brigade](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J9Q3i5w6-Ug).

### Update

Sorry I couldn't work on this project last week. I was too busy at my other jobs, sorry. This week I am planning to do a new release with a premiliminary support for restoring accounts. I will need help to verify this code, so if people could spare some time during this week to help me check it out once I release it it will be awesome.

#### How I am planning to do it?

I'm going to lift code from Ticktack to do it. Ticktack used _muxrpc_ to connect to some peers and ask for the _latest sequence_ for the given account to come up with some shared assumptions of how much it should wait until it declared the account restored. I might need help making sure this works as I've never touched muxrpc without an abstraction on top of it before.

Besides that, on the backup I have the _latest sequence_ at the time of the backup and both the content from `conn.json` and `gossip.json`. This means that I know I need to wait until that number arrives and I know which peers I could connect to to ask for more information.
Are you folks planning on repurposing vote changing the _verb_ to an emoji? Is this how it will work? Because I 😻 that.
I'm patchfooing here... 💚💙💓💗

[romuloalves](@xr/Q/zqaEwmmd4wg8xRU1TrMLQhc9qBqNCioCqmv1vQ=.ed25519) those were good years but unfortunately it is all gone now. Mozilla decided to implement the APIs directly into Gecko which makes it impossible to update the browser engine in those devices to recent ones since Mozilla has since removed the needed APIs from Gecko... I don't believe anything exciting in terms of mobile operating system will happen anytime soon. The only things I still keep an eye for but never used are [Sailfish](https://jolla.com/#SailfishOS) and [postmarketOS // real Linux distribution for phones](https://postmarketos.org/).

@patrick, I thought about doing that but the problem is that there are too many ways for that to fail. You'd need to use the [Alarm API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/API/alarms/create), the problem is that if the browser is not open at the time you set it to trigger, the alarm will fail silently. You could program to detect that but it would be an after the failure detection once the user opens the browser again which might be too late for whatever you needed. The other way to solve this would be with a _push notification_ at the correct time but that would require me to maintain a server backend to send those notifications which I'd rather not do. Thats why I opted for the simplest solution, a calendar file, which works regardless if the browser is open or not and will notify you in all devices that are subscribed to your calendar.

A way to solve cluttering is to having more than one calendar. If you're using the common apps such as Google Calendar, or Apple Calendar, or Microsoft Calendar, then you can easily add new "calendars" to your account. You can have the default one be your serious one and have the others for things like this add-on. For example, I have additional calendar for "Mozilla Tech Speakers" which tracks me and my friends public speaking activities, another for my own personal time allocation... Then when you're adding the event, you use the options presented by your calendaring app to add it to the less serious calendar. You'll still receive all the notifications and stuff but it becomes easier to filter out

![photo_2019-12-17_15-31-49.jpg](&RXo/1Z6wlMAjmHfSsJSIh+7lEvMEa5iD53fnvjvjRQ8=.sha256)

A quite beautiful flat white from Redemption Roasters in Coal Drops Yard. I really like it here and this is where I come when I want to work on stuff that is personal because I don't want to associate this place with boring jobs.

It was raining outside when I left home. It made me think twice before commiting to the idea of actually walking to a coffee shop, but in the end I decided to do it. I get bored at home.

This :coffee: saved me by providing me with warmth and caffeine while I was noticing that my work required me to deal with image metadata from JPEG files. Do you know how many ways there are to write metadata inside a JPEG file? Let me paste a list of different specs, all of which can be found inside a JPEG at the same time:

* EXIF 2.2 - including makernotes
* XMP / RDF, including multiple language support
* Dublin Core
* IPTC-NAA IIM 4.1
* Photoshop IRB
* Picture Info
* JFIF
* DCF 2.0
* TIFF/EP
* JFIF Extension
* Embedded s
* Intrinsic JPEG Values

And thats why I come to a lovelly coffee shop, to avoid thinking too much about how developers tend to shoot themselves on the foot with technical debt of acrueing multiple specs over time...

# SSB on Windows 10 on ARM64

Today I managed to compile leveldown. So at the moment the following things are working nativelly on Win32 ARM64:

* NodeJS
* Electron
* Leveldown

I still need to make `sodium-native` compile, at the moment it fails and crashes `npm install`. Once that is done, it will be possible to have native SSB on the Surface Pro X and other ARM based windows machines.

_PS: Don't we all love new ISAs with poor support for dev tools?_
Been refactoring code here, I'll post a lenghtier update in couple hours.
I suspect that `ssb-identities` can do that already and that maybe Patchbay has it in place right now but I am not sure.

I'm a huge fan of analog tools for brainstorming and organising ones own time. Our lives are already suffering from too much disruption from digital apps. People tend to look at planners, diaries and similar paper tools and ask: _"but how will you see it on your phone or laptop?"_ and after a while I've begun to realize that the answer to that question is that _I don't want to see that information on my devices at all._ The more I disconnect, the better my work becomes. I'm too easily distracted by notifications and alt-tabbing into news agreggation sites like HN, Lobsters, etc. I need to go back to what works for me and that is a combination of pen + paper and pomodoros.

At the moment, I have two jobs and a couple freelance gigs going on and I'm burning out but not due to the amount of work but due to acruing stress from thinking that I am failing people because I've been disorganized and am not delivering things in the timeframe that I want to. My plan for 2020 is to ditch one of the jobs (not sure which one) so that I have more time for my own personal projects and gigs.

So, in an attempt to work better, I've spent some time thinking about when it was the last time that I felt happy and productive and reflect on which of the associated features of those days I could replicate here in London. I could reduce it down to:

* Work from coffee shop.
* Use pomodoro technique.
* Plan for weekly deliveries.
* Use pen + paper to organize.

In this post here, I'm going to focus on the third item of this list: _Pen + Paper_. Some people have [GAS](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/gear_acquisition_syndrome) in regards to musical equipment. I have GAS related to stationary tools. Recently, I've forbidden myself from acquiring more notebooks and pens. I already have enough for a lifetime and to be honest, I haven't been using them as much as I'd like (mostly due to being disorganised). So, today, I decided to stop by [my favorite coffee shop](https://www.coaldropsyard.com/redemption-roasters/) and organise my week using pen and paper. 

I'm very fond of [Hobonichi Techo 2020](https://www.1101.com/store/techo/en/) planners but my current one is an 2019 one and it is ending. Even though I love those planners, I don't think they are the best ones for me because they are setup as a daily agenda and I don't think in terms of days. I ended up using my planner more like a diary and it is probably 70% or 80% blank which is a shame since it was an expensive planner. I'm going to use it for scrap paper.

After noticing that Hobonichi Techos were not a match for me, I decided to go flexible and got myself the Travelers Notebook, which is more of a system than a planner. You can buy multiple different refills for it to suit your needs and assemble your own. Here is a handy guide for those that are not aware how it works: [TRAVELER'S COMPANY TRAVELER'S notebook: A Comprehensive Guide | JetPens](https://www.jetpens.com/blog/travelers-notebook-a-comprehensive-guide/pt/726). The problem for me is that I use my current travelers notebook as a brainstorm book. I write there not for remembering it later but for thinking about it right now. So it is a very noisy notebook for me and I guess using it for weekly planning would cause some friction. I could have one notebook inside it for planning and another for brainstorming, which is actually how many people set it up. There are no refills available with weekly planners for it unfortunately.

I believe the best solution for me would actualle be the [Kokuyo Jibun Techo 3-in-1 planner](https://www.jetpens.com/blog/kokuyo-jibun-techo-a-3-in-1-planner/pt/949) which unifies all that I love from the Hobonichi Techo with the flexibility of the Travelers Notebook. You might have noticed that my problem with GAS is real 😺 so I thought against my own desires and decided not to purchase a new planner. Still, I wanted a little booklet to use as daily scratch / weekly planner for my work.

Well, now we're back to the coffe shop, not at the shop itself but on the way to it. A little popup shop was open next to the shop and it had _Winsor & Newton_ written in it. I'm a sucker for their watercolours so I went inside and lo and behold, they had a little, tiny, compact, dotted, landscape notebook there. Perfect for my current use case. What really attracted me to it was that it is a local product made here in London using my favorite type of printing technique, [risographs](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1rfwKuXIhcE). So it is a little notebook made from recycled materials and printed in a risograph which uses soy based inks. Fuck GAS, I got the little booklet and it is gorgeous.

![photo_2019-12-20_15-30-09.jpg](&1eTsh/BU4RYpUGL2cc3U0qtrMNnIXJJMz8Ue6DhZFBY=.sha256)
_The closed notebook._

![photo_2019-12-20_15-30-15.jpg](&Y02EQQ4S2GzWJYCmxb7HJ2J+eO8Mnqjimqsu04wlRo4=.sha256)
_Don't we all love dotted books._

I'm already planning all the week on it and am feeling more productive. Fighting with your own procrastination, chaotic habits, is an ongoing struggle. I hope this week becomes a week I am proud of.

Oh, the notebook is made by [Hato Press | Risograph Printing & Workshops‎](https://hatopress.net/)

# New interface

![backup.gif](&TzwrCJEco49RBjKdTujH9RCZvPAum2o1yrqfUz1Yk1Q=.sha256)

## Why?

Well, I've rewritten it. I've done that because it was hard to work on the depject based code I extracted from ticktack. Depject is very flexible and that flexibility causes some challenges for maintenance. It is very hard to figure out the dependency graph of a depject based project since the use of `needs: [...]` will retrieve all sorts of dependencies from the project own source, patchcore and whatever other depject based dependency you loaded without a clear correspondence between what you're depending and where in disk it is stored. With time and experience, these become a lot more familiar and finding stuff becomes easier but it still adds friction to maintenance and for contribution.

This is even worse for a project such as this one that is cherry picking source code from a larger project. If you check the most current work tree on git, you'll see that there are a gazillion folders and files being used by the program simply because I don't know if I can remove them without breaking some depject need by another component. So, the project had a huge subset of ticktack inside it for no reason and none of the backup code actually really needed any patchcore stuff.

So, I've rewritten it using mithril, without patchcore, depject, no dependency injection besides what is being provided by _package.json_. By using mithril, we can work directly in the JS files without a build system. What we write is what Electron loads, if you change something, you just need to hit refresh. So development was quite fast and it quickly reached parity level with the ticktack based source code.

## But, budget!

This was a decision to refactor made by me without consulting anyone. I wrote all of it today, in about 5 hours. My objective was to reach parity with the code I already had on git. **I'm did this refactor pro-bono. The hours used for this refactor will not be included in the budget.** I did this so that I can complete this software in the next couple weeks. Now the source code is in a state I am much more confortable with and that I fell more confident working on. It is also much much smaller. I'm doing some tweaks to make it pretty to push.

## Where do we go from here?

Now, we add the restore view...

Let me just paste some numbers here.

The old ticktack based source code had 1035 lines spread in 27 files. Which doesn't reflect all the source imported from patchcore which is no longer used. So in the old version, besides those 1035 lines of code and those 27 files, you usually also needed to dive deep into patchcore to check stuff.

The new code has 401 lines in 4 files.

This doesn't include all the electron boilerplate which is the same between versions.

# Svelte Problems I've been building #patchfox in [Svelte](https://svelte.dev) for a while now and it has served me well up until today. The problems I've encountered today are, when grouped together, a blocker for the continuation of the vision I have for the project. In this brief (oh God, I hope it is brief) post, I'm going to explain the problems and why they are a blocker for Patchfox. This is not a criticism of Svelte, it is a declaration of unfitness for what I want to do. All the problems sprout from the same feature: [named slots](https://svelte.dev/docs#slot_name). ## What are named slots? Basically a component can have multiple slots for children inside it. For example, a `Card.svelte` component can be defined like this with two named slots and one default slot: ~~~~
~~~~ and can be used like: ~~~~

Title

this content will end up in the default slot

this is the footer ~~~~ Looks neat right? And it is and it can serve you well, provided you don't stumble into the following problems. ## Named slots add extra divs The HTML generated the snippet above **is not**: ~~~~

Title

this content will end up in the default slot

this is the footer
~~~~ It actually is: ~~~~

Title

this content will end up in the default slot

this is the footer
~~~~ So each of your named slots will add an extra div to your markup. This affects your CSS, specially if you're using a third-party UI kit like bootstrap/foundation/etc which makes assumption about the div hierarchy. ## You can't add a component as a named slot One good thing about having components is that as you develop your app you can build a collection of reusable components. This is specially useful for generic UI controls like `Card`, `Menu`, `MenuItem`, etc. The problem is that you can't pass a component directly into a named slot. Lets pick the example above, suppose you have another component called `CardTitle`, **you can't do**: ~~~~
Title

this content will end up in the default slot

this is the footer
~~~~ You can't add a `slot` property to a component. If you want to add a `CardTitle` component into the `title` slot, then you need to wrap it into some DOM element such as for example a `div` like this: ~~~~
Title

this content will end up in the default slot

this is the footer
~~~~ You know where this is going, now your HTML has three nested divs between `div.title` and `CardTitle`, it goes like: ~~~~
... ... ~~~~ ## No way for a component to test if the slot is empty If your component declares a slot, then it is always generated even if it is empty. There is no way for the component to check if its children contain the content for the named slot before rendering (or after), which means _you can't do conditional slots_ which are present if filled or removed if not. For example, if you declared a `footer` slot for that `Card` component, all cards will have `
` in them regardless if they have content or not. Depending on your CSS, this will add padding, margin, spacing, and other wrong oddities on your layout and you can't check it at runtime. The solution is pairing props and slots, so that you pass a prop that tells if a slot should be rendered, like: ~~~~ ... ... ~~~~ Which sucks because then you need a bunch of `{#if}` inside your templates and you're duplicating work between telling the component you have a slot and also giving it the slot. ## Components can't have a class You **can't do:** ``, the `Card` component needs to declare its styling inside it, its parent can't style their children components. So if you have a `Card` component and you want to add a border to it on some special view, you can't you need to rework `Card` to support this, basically you need to rework `Card` to support every single potential class and style you need it to have and then pass stuff via props such as `` and then inside it check if `kind` is `primary` and then add whatever class is needed. ## No component inheritance Svelte focus on component composition. There is no way to create a component and tell it, hey you are the same as `Card` plus with these extra features. You can't have `RoundCard` deriving from `Card`, you need to have `` and then inside `Card` check for `round`, yada yada yada. ## How this affects Patchfox? Patchfox is meant to be an easy to understand system where pieces are little packages that work together. I want to move Patchfox packages into even higher level, so that we can build them without diving into HTML too much. One of the dreams is to be able to have a collection of UI components that are very high level such as a `QueryRepeater` that receives a query and builds the necessary UI to view the resulting messages. At the moment, there is no way to create generic UI components in Svelte and then create specialized UI components on top of them. This leads to a soup of `
` that breaks CSS and makes inner compoents such as `Card` very very fat as they need to account for all possible styling and slot needs. I spent the day today refactoring Patchfox to have reusable components and thats why I discovered all this. Up to know there was a magical component `MessageRenderer` that did lots of clever stuff without any slots, which means that the avatar, channel, dropdown menu, for all kinds of messages were the same since I couldn't have slots. `MessageRenderer` contains literally half of the `
`, only the top part, each message contains the bottom part. Thats how Patchfox rendered feeds. This makes for a very tight coupled system. For example, if you want a card to have a different top, you needed to change `MessageRenderer` to account for it. Which is what I did today when I made tall and short cards. It is too much friction, too rigid. I can't build the flexible system I want without inheritance, encapsulation, and being able to style (or at least declare a class) for the children.

I'll keep adding some feedback notes to this thread, just for the sake of documentation and organizing my own thoughts.

# Batteries included

Fossil has everything built-in and part of the repo. It has wiki, forum, web pages and a ticketing system. Both the fossil website and the SQLite website are actually just fossil repos you're accessing. There is a lot of power in this. This being said, I won't use most of these features for my dotfiles repo as I don't expect contributions. I might use the wiki as a personal wiki though, or maybe I'll create a private repo and use the wiki there so that I can go crazy with secret stuff.

# Hosting fossil is dead easy.

Fossil is a self contained binary. I just copied the version appropriate to my linux on my VPS to its cgi-bin directory. Then I placed the repository file in _a folder outside the web root_. Each Fossil repository is just a SQLite file. Then it was just a matter of creating a script file, which I named `repo`:

~~~~
#!./fossil
directory: /path/to/my/repofiles
~~~~

Thats it, when you access https://andregarzia.com/cgi-bin/repo/dotfiles, you're actually running the `repo` file. It looks for `dotfiles.fossil` in the directory specified in the script. All the access control, security stuff, it is all part of the repo itself.

# Unversioned files in the repo

One cool stuff that Fossil has that I haven't seen in other SCMs is the ability to add unversioned files to the repo. These files are added and their latest version is tracked but without history. This is good to add binary files or little stuff that you want present but you don't care about the history.

This version is a milestone for SSB Backup Tool because it is the first version that is able to start an SSB server on demand. This means that I can now start working on the restore account part of the app. Be aware that I am intentionally waiting for a long time between attempting to launch SSB server and actually connecting to it. There is a bit of race condition where the background process report that the server has started but it is not yet accepting connections. I add a 20 seconds wait after we receive the server started message to make sure it is actually listening.

---

This is also the first version that is being built for _ia32_ and _arm64_ as well as the other more common platforms. The _arm64_ is not launching at the moment even though it is being built. I suspect it is a problem with the binary node modules used (leveldown and sodium-native). I need to find a way to tell package.json or electron-builder or travis or whichever cloud god is in charge of building stuff to use sodium non-native. Also, anyone here know a drop-in replacement for leveldown that doesn't rely on a native module?

I'd love to be able to force some resolution in `package-lock.json` and have this project build without any binary modules.

---

Anyway, release is here: https://github.com/ssbc/ssb-backup-tool/releases/tag/v0.0.5

Feedback appreciated.

PRs and Issues being open forever does lead to forking and importing from branches or vendoring patched versions into the app. All of this leads to fragmentation and harder interoperability for the ecosystem.

I do see the PRs and issues flying by but I was never confident enough in my own knowledge to review them. I guess others feel the same and those who are confident are probably swamped with other work already. I like [@VictorBjelkholm](@FlzOOyrhTG+Cl6YND5tReJtd2ufUj3++F0ZsfcPalRc=.ed25519) suggestion of having phases for the issues and PRs. I also reeeeaaallly like the idea that funds could be used towards changing this because lets be honest, in the end of the day most of us have bills to pay and can't afford to devote as much time here as we'd like (or this is just me projecting).

From working with mozilla people in the past (circa 2014?! can't remember), we used a system we called RACI for each task to be done. Each letter in this acronym is a person or a collection of people, it goes like this:

* **R**esponsible for the action.
* **A**ccountable for the action.
* **C**onsulted for the action (multiple people).
* **I**nformed on the action (basically stakeholders).

This was more useful when we had a plan of what we'd like to do and mapped it out as a series of actions. For coding, Mozilla usually has module owners which have a final say on their modules. So, there is one person who decides and that has worked well for them (mostly).

In our more lax garden, I think that we should at least map for each repo who:

* Can be consulted about it, as in, these people know what this is for.
* Who should be informed in case of changes.
* Who is responsible for merging stuff (group of people).

If we distribute this in a sensible way, no one will be left with too much on their plate. We can all avoid burn out and _undead issues & PR_ if we work together. 

A group of volunteers triaging issues is also a good idea, at least if only to flag duplicates and non-issues (as in filled to the wrong repo).

Starting a conversation about packaging SSB clients for the popular package managers out there. I'm starting this after casually chatting about it here with [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) who suggested the idea.

Ideally to avoid burn out and it would be great if we had volunteers to package SSB clients for the platforms they actually use instead of someone trying to package things for platforms they can't test.

My suggestion is to initially package Patchwork and Patchbay.

I'm going forward and package those apps for Windows. I'm going to focus on offering the following packages for the following package managers:

* [Chocolatey](https://chocolatey.org/)
  * Binary package which uses the installers on gh.
  * Source package which builds from source.
* [Scoop](https://scoop.sh) (which is my prefered package manager)
  * Binary package using the installers from gh (I don't know if we can do build from source on scoop, need to check).

One cool thing about scoop is that we can host our own [bucket](https://github.com/lukesampson/scoop/wiki/Buckets) which are basically repositories containing the manifests for each app. We can have a scoop bucket under the SSBC github org. I think I'll do that first.

![image.png](&rzgF7Aa/lTtbEkOY3CwaTpl+/0Qsn8aHVkUnoKGR4v4=.sha256)

Okay, I got [chocolatey](https://chocolatey.org) working as well. It is a much more involved process than scoop. I've set a [Github repo for our Chocolatey packages](https://github.com/ssbc/chocolatey-packages). I'm not yet submitting any packages to the Chocolatey community org because I'd like more feedback/eyes on them.

At the moment I've done only Patchwork but it should be almost the same for Patchbay.
So now we have tentative Chocolatey packages and ready to go Scoop packages. Not bad for a day of procrastination, cold and fever :D

Was checking the sbotc source code today. It is amazing, it is so tiny while also being very dense (as in full of content).

I wanted to throw a bit of crazyness into it and bind it to Lua 5.3, I think I'm able to do it on POSIX systems but I won't be able to do it on Windows because `sbotc.c` uses some POSIX stuff which is not available on Windows: `err.h`, `ifaddrs.h`, `netdb.h`, `neinet/in.h`, `sys/select.h`, `sys/socket.h`, `sys/un.h`, `termios.h`, `unistd.h`. 

Even though I'm confident that I can create an `err()` macro on windows to substitute `err.h`, the others are more involved and would require a huge refactor of `sbotc.c` to make it cross-platform which I can't do at the moment. Well, I guess I'll try this some months from now when hopefully I'll be done with my current projects.

# Restore process

I've started working on the _restore identity process_. These are the first screens I've built which are used to double-check what is the current state of the machine before attempting to restore anything. I'd welcome feedback on them.

## First restore screen

![image.png](&FRdWnF/4NEr/MJt3ZvyPWQMwgQ2yvne1CM7rgYAuK7c=.sha256)

## Installation present screen

After that first screen, the tool check to see if there is a secret file on disk. If there is one, it presents the user with the following screen:

![image.png](&RZsuKZe8MdfXQ2QLX6O/xF/oontmCCFo5Ijk/z1Owsk=.sha256)

## SSB server running

After the user confirms that they want to overwrite the identity, we double check to see if there is a running server. This check only makes sense if there is an installation on disk.

# A rant about NodeJS 😤😤😤

Using NodeJS on Windows is good but it is not as straight forward as using it on other systems. The official installer will install nodejs to a standard location and ask you if you want to install the native building tools. Without setting up such tools either from their installers or by hand later, you can't build native modules on your own.

I was unable to build stuff here so I let the official installer install the build tools. What this secondary installer does is:

* Install chocolatey package manager.
* Install VS2017 command line build tools using chocolatey.
* Install Python 2.7 using chocolatey.
* A lot of plumbing between those parts.

Now, the **fucking script doesn't do any checking!** I already had Chocolatey installed and already had Python 2.7 installed and on path (but not from chocolatey). So the installer script failed in a cascading colorful mayhem of messages that had I had set my terminal to some color theme with sparkles, would be worth recording and airing it during New Years Eve as a beautiful demonstration of fireworks. 

In the end I had a broken VS2017, broken Python, broken Chocolatey. And NodeJS still didn't work to build native modules.

I just spent the last hour unsintalling and unbreaking all the shit.

Now, I've just installed NodeJS LTS from Scoop, which in my opinion is much better than chocolatey and am trying to wire it up to use VS2019.

I can't wait for us to have some alternative.

You can kinda bring anything into SSB if you craft scripts well enough. There are people hosting GIT repos here, NPM modules, playing chess games, posting blog entries. It is a very flexible system.

> The available apps. Ugh! –I know it’s a quick way to make cross-platform apps available, but my heart sinks when I download an app and find out it’s made with Electron. Effectively downloading a huge bloated memory-hogging headless browser, just to run some fairly lightweight code. Just make a web app, already!

Electron gets a lot of hate some of which is undeserved. It is very hard to ship cross-platform software in binary form, that's one of the reasons that for a large part of Linux history we had to build from source. If you add Windows and Macs it becomes even harder to support native cross-platform clients, believe me I've been trying to do exactly that and failing miserably for more than a year now.

I'm running Patchwork as my main client on many different machines. On the one I am currently using, which is a Windows 10 on ARM64 machine (not a target people usually ship native apps to), Patchwork is using about 400mb of RAM.  If you compare that with a texteditor written with GTK of course it will look bloated, but if you compare it with the amount of RAM you usually have these days, you'll see that it is usually OK. This machine has 16GB of RAM, it is doing fine.

If that still sounds bad for you, you might be better served by running either #patchfoo or #oasis both of which consume next to nothing and are closer to the web app you want. There is also #patchfox but that requires Firefox and is in the middle of a gigantic rewrite because I don't learn from my mistakes.

> The way I have to set up a separate identity on each device I want to use SSB on. Who thought this was a good idea? It makes no sense at all. I spent most of yesterday evening trying to get the Manyverse Android app and Patchwork to ‘share’ the same identity, by syncing contents of the .ssb folder, so I could use SSB from mobile and laptop with the same identity.

STOP THAT RIGHT NOW! YOU'LL BREAK YOUR FEED!

SSB is not meant to run the same identity on more than one machine. That is not how it works. If you do that and somehow posts from one machine before it finishes synchronizing with all that the other machine posted, you'll end up with messages with the same sequence number but different content causing your feed to be rejected by clients as corrupted. If you do that you'll need to create whole new identities, there is no way to safely salvage a forked feed.

Your feed is a sequence of messages tied together by a signature chain. Each message contains the signature of the previous message in the chain and a sequence number that increases for each message. You can't have two machines contributing to the same chain, it is too risky. The tech was not designed for that.

Developers here are actively working on tech to group identities together so that your multiple identities appear as one. It is not ready but that is where we're going at the moment.

Just to show people that a ton of software we use daily here in SSB land is made by groups who made a different license choice than (A)GPL:

* Firefox is released as MPL
* Rust is released MIT/Apache 2.0.
* NodeJS is MIT.
* XOrg is MIT.
* Go is BSD style with patent grants.
* sodium-native is MIT.
* leveldown is MIT.

Be aware that I like both the GPLv2 and AGPL. I think they are great licenses and make a ton of sense for some projects. It is one of the greatest tools in the Linux community. But there are other tools and sometimes people have their reasons to use them. There is a great chance that in SSB land we might use more MIT software than AGPL software. This doesn't mean that MIT is better than AGPL, it means that the authors made a different choice. Respecting choices is important, or if someone feels a different choice should be made, they should engage without resorting to accusations of disrespecting users, unethical behavior, or claiming people are evil.

[@Léo](@zxMwkWz/dk1wu1Sd7hOCDuFjCbsZ8Y0C7XLFHr/BJpw=.ed25519),

You and I started on the wrong foot. Let me begin by saying that I admire your enthusiasm and passion towards free software and the ideals championed by the Free Software Foundation. I think this organization and ideals are important too.

I do not share many of your views. My view on proprietary software is not the same as you. I don't regard proprietary software as evil. I think people and companies act evil and software is just a tool. A hammer can be used to build a shelf or to kill someone, hammers are not evil, people using them to kill other people are. This is as usual a small and fragmented analogy that doesn't encompass the multitude of different scenarios present in the real world.

Due to this fundamental disagreement between us, which causes you to perceive any approach different than the FSF and its licenses as either evil or enablers of evil, I don't think that there is any argument that I can say here that will cause you to turn to me and say: "yeah, that makes sense."

People are the ultimate source of evil. I've met some pretty evil people associated with the FSF, heck, one of the evil situations (which I will not get into details because it is not worth it) caused them to walk away with 30k USD from us and then scam us. I've also seen FOSS advocates, very famous ones, doing fake accusations towards friends to the Brazilian Federal Police just to cause them harm as they saw those other people as dangerous to their position of power and influence. Does this mean that FOSS and FSF people are evil? No, of course not! Some people I've met there are the most caring and passionate humans I've ever seen. Still, any group that has influence and power attracts those who loves both things, and this is dangerous. There is a lot of evil happening right now in the world regardless of the GPL and in compliance with the GPL.

Saying that that free software is always superior than proprietary software is not true. There are free software which are much better than proprietary and choosing free software and empowering free software people is wise. There are other cases where FOSS is not up to the same quality or standards, specially when we talk about software that takes decades and lots of PhDs to develop. As you mentioned this is mostly a funding problem, companies get the funds and perpetuate this. I agree with you there, but, I also understand that in the pragmatic world I live that the way towards a better future is by negotiation and politics, which means compromise. 

If you want to know why I personally choose MIT? Well, because I want people to be able to run away with the source if they want to. If my software can be used by you and your friends to launch your new startup and provide for you and yours, more power to you. I don't ask for anything back, contribute back as you see fit. If you want to build proprietary software with my source, that is OK. If some software I'm about to release is different and for that specific software, I'd rather no proprietary softeare is ever launch, then, for that one I'd go GPL. It depends on what I want for that software, all things being normal, I'd go with MIT and just give it away.

Be aware that regardless of GPL, MIT, BSD, Apache, that the FOSS world has a funding and sustainability problem. Most of us live inside capitalism and have bills to pay. Very few of us are able to make a living from FOSS. This is even harder for those of us shipping end user applications. Donations and crowdfundings are not sustainable. There are very few specific cases where a major desktop app or library gets enough funding to pay for the maintainers but that is not the norm. In the world of SaaS, the GPL doesn't guarantee much. Companies can comply with it and dump the source across a wall and you still won't be able to replicate what they have due to the sheer lack of money and resources to put the infrastructure up.

I enjoy giving my source away. Sometimes people come back and tell me some stories about how it was used in their companies and we have a laugh. Most of the time they don't. I just want to ship my stuff in the most permissive license I get and what you do with it says more about you than me. (_PS: this is an hypothetical you, not you you._)

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519),

> All patches are owned by their authors. There SHALL NOT be any copyright assignment process.

Be aware that this is extremely tricky once an author becomes fed up with the project for whatever reason and decides to pull their patches from the project. Depending on how fundamental the changes are, it is impossible to remove the patches without rendering the project unusable. That's one of the reasons that many projects started requesting copyright assignments. Remember `leftpad`, NPM went against the authors wish to place the module up again to prevent the meltdown of half of the ecosystem. This is a cautionary tale where all the errs are on the NPM ecosystem, its community but not the author of `leftpad` who is in their right to remove stuff.

I'm not a lawyer but I believe that If they still have the copyright they might be able to issue a DMCA takedown. Copyright law is tricky and trumps licenses. If they send the takedown notice to Github, Gitlab, or whoever is hosting the repo that is pulled, that organization is required take the thing down first and then the parts can start trying to argue over it while it is down.

I don't mean it will be down forever, [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519), but the nature of DMCA takedowns on GH and similar sites is usually to comply with the takedown first then argue over it. So while arguing is happening things become unbuildable. At least for a while as the repos might be down.

Hey Friends, I love the topic of mobile OSs, it is one of my favorite fandoms.

I was heavily invested into BeOS and a member of my local BUG (BeOS User Group, we had bug-br). During the Zeta years, I met and drove the CEO of YellowTAB around during a conference, and was friends with one of their engineers and almost got a position there as well. I contributed to Haiku many years ago as well and wish I could me more active there. I had high hopes when Palm bought it and the BeIA stuff. I could see how BeOS should be the future of mobile computing and appliances. That has never happened.

As for android and compiling android, Firefox OS was basically:

🤖 - ☕ + 🦎 = 🦊

Or in English: pick Android, remove Java, add Gecko. Compiling it was not fun. We relied on Google `repo.sh` tools and a gazilion patches. It could be done but it was definitely not fun. I have no idea how it is to compile Android now. I remember it being quite painful to compile for different devices from the same source tree having to reinitialize the whole working tree and change a million files that were specific to each device. It sucked.

I like the potential of PostmarketOS not as a phone operating system but as a way to give new life to old devices and upcycle them into something useful for DIY projects. We have many devices lying around, they should be put into good use. Still, it requires some high level commitment to install it on most devices and that might be beyond what people who are not invested into that ecosystem want to do.

Fire OS, Harmony OS, those are nothing but Android forks to try to reassert control over the user base of those companies. I understand why they do it, specially Chinese based companies. They can't have their devices going dead because someone in the U.S. add their name to a list.

I agree with [@hoodownr](@YND2Cb9uk3ZdFyzXpaXDH5HZ9udu+qjg4MhNcynK2RE=.ed25519)
that fucshia is the most exciting new thing happening in the OS space at the moment but I don't see its objective being to get rid of GPL and FOSS. That might be a side-effect of it but in my opinion the objective is something else, I can summarize them into two reasons, one is technical, another emotional.

The technical reason for Fuchsia is that Android is a matrioshka of bloat. It is the Linux kernel, which is in essence made to be multitennant timesharing server/terminal OS and has been adapted and molded into everything, but it was never designed to be like this. Then you add the JVM (not the SUN/Oracle one but doesn't matter) which might be a marvel of technology but it is an added layer of something that originally was not designed for this. And then you have your userland and stuff. Now, lets break down a typical mobile device: it is a single-user hand terminal that doesn't receive hardware upgrades or changes. Is UNIX and JVM what you really need here? Can we have a system that is more flexible, has less baggage and made from the start to be flexible for different mobile scenarios.

The emotional one is that Google has lots of smart people inside it. Some of them are quite fucking genius level smart. Google doesn't want those people leaving. If they leave they might end up somewhere else and revolutionizing something away from Google. Google need to keep these smart people a puzzle, an entertaining task that keeps them engaged and while potentially making Google a ton of money.  Fuchsia is a lure to keep PhDs from leaving, give them time to work on a very hard and tempting problem, let them create their dream system from scratch. Let them do it inside Google so that Google owns it instead of out there.
oh yeah!

![photo_2020-01-29_13-34-32.jpg](&7SKkoErx5qMD/+MNLc2c0IFo1G/28JvQLDXs/IE3VJ4=.sha256)
_A cute flat white._

Was walking from home towards Notes Coffee Roasters in Pancras Square, in front of Google HQ, but it was too cold so I detoured towards Redemption Coffee roasters that is a bit closer to home in Coal Drop Yards. Redemption is a really nice coffee place but it is a tad on the small side so depending on the hour it is quite hard to find a table there. I was lucky today and got myself a nice table.

This is my second coffee of the day and probably the last. I started with a black filter and then asked for a flat white later. Also had a ham & cheese croissant but it was not in the pictures.

Today's morning I'm working on a gallery project for [the monastery](https://www.himalayanacademy.com) I work for. I made a design mistake with our GraphQL based workflow. Not really in the GraphQL part but it appeared once we start using it. 

Basically with have thousands of images in our gallery. We decided that the images themselves are the source of truth and everything about the image is saved as exif/xmp/iptc data. Wherever the images end up we're sure to be able to get all the data about them. A harvester process finds all the images and populates a Postgres database with their data. This is done to speed up queries. Everything was working fine. 

The problem that since we use hundreds of volunteers to produce, catalog and curate these images, we were proactive in our system design. We know that in the next years folder structures and file names will probably change, thats why we decided to keep the data inside the images. Each image is identified by its checksum. When an user decides to see an image, a GraphQL query is sent with the checksum. So far, so good. Well, then requirements changed and they asked for a online image editor. I worked on the mutations for it and was now working on the web interface. Each mutation actually writes exif/xmp/iptc data to the desired image file and call the harvester process again.

And there lies the challenge. When we alter the metadata, we alter the content of the image, which alters its checksum and records in the database. The checksum the web interface is holding on memory all of  a sudden points nowhere. All the mutations were returning booleans because it was easier to do for an internal tool.

Now, I'm patching all mutations to return an image, just like the get image query. That's how GraphQL is supposed to be used but remember we started this many years ago when GraphQL was young and we were not quite sure how it worked. I think this project is three years old now.

Now, as I refactor every single mutation, I'm wondering if Redemption Coffee Roasters sells something stronger than coffee...

I'm very good at having ideas and planning them. I'm not as prolific or competent in getting them done though. Over the years, I thought  about many many possible things for SSB which I think I actually know how to implement but never did nor have I ever shared these ideas. This post is a brain dump of former ideas, some of which are still very good, if you're inspired by any of them, please code away. I want to get them out of my head because they occupy space and I'm afraid I'll eventually forget.

## SSB Web API Endpoint

A Web API Endpoint can be constructed as a ssb-server plugin. This could offer its features over GraphQL, RESTful, JSON-RPC or any other fancy method we invent. Messages on SSB are very flexible and I doubt the ability of anything that requires a precise definition of schemas and types to be kept up to date and to be able to accomodate broken or snowflake messages[1].

The idea here is not to create an API server so that you can build new clients. That is something that is needed and is already being done by multiple different approaches. The idea is to create an endpoint that listen on `localhost` to offer a subset of well defined and safe features to Web Pages running on the users browsers. 

### Login With Scuttlebutt

The server above could offer a login with SSB feature with the following workflow: the page does an XHR request to localhost at a known URI to check it the feature is available. If it is, it sends a request asking for login. The local server issues an `open` request to the operating system to open a new web page coming from itself. The web page that the user is viewing has no control or can even see this happening. From the user point of view, they click a link and a new window open with the dialog to login with SSB. The dialog allows the user to share their name, avatar image, and public key with the page. It allows the user to decide to deny access to any of these stuff as well. The original web page can keep pooling to see if the "login job is done". Once it is done the page will either be able to access what the user decided to share or see empty info.

### Web Intent to Share on SSB

The same server and a similar workflow can provide a _Share on Scuttlebutt_ feature similar to the dialogs of Facebook and Twitter. Upon pressing the share link on a web page, a localhost XHR request is sent that causes a new window to open with the dialog. The original web page sees nothing.

[1]: Snowflake message, a one of kind message with a shape slightly different than what the common messages of that type actually have such as some added fields.

## Group For Display

This is a variation of `SameAs` that I always planned to implement on Patchfox. It has well defined and easy (if expensive) mechanics to implement. What it does is group identities together for display purposes in the client side. Once two or more identities are linked with a "Group for Display" message, the client will count those additional identities when computing _mentions_ and _participating_ views while also always adding them to _private messages RECPS_. Just that, it is nothing but a convenience to help those juggling multiple identities. It is a long way from true `SameAs` message but it makes life easier.

## More Info Message
 
This is coming to Patchfox anyway but I've spoken about it I think only to [@KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519)
in the past. This is a private message from you to yourself (and maybe your grouped with identities). **This must be private.**  This message attaches _more information_ to a given profile. This message is not something to be reduced like tangles. You just need to check the last message of this kind for a given profile. When you post a message like this, the computed state of all the info you added is added to a single message. This trades space for an easier way to query. The objective of _more info_ is to add more fields and data to profiles and effectivelly use SSB as an address book without leaking data about people. Code can then be used to generate vCards file from it to be used on phones and stuff.

## Project Moon Hermit

This one has even a name but don't be fooled, it is nothing but an idea. This is to pick Lua and create a new Lua interpreter that has SSB features in it. Initially just a client. This could be done by adding Lua API calls to `sbotc` which would enable a whole new set of small CLI tools.

## Blog Conduit

A ssb-server plugin that exposes MetaWeblog API endpoint. This widely supported by most blogging clients and would allow the user to use tools like MarsEdit or Open Live Writer to write blog posts for SSB.

This same plugin could expose blog posts from your friends and people you're following as RSS so that you could read them with your favorite blogging tool.

I really want to build this one, but you know, time...

## dex-deploy

There is [ipfs-deploy](https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/ipfs-deploy) that makes it easier to deploy a static web site to IPFS. I'm sure that there is something similar for DAT as well. I think it would be cool to have a single CLI tool that would publish a static website into IPFS, DAT and SSB.

[@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519),

I cheated. I go from my own language called [nanodeck](https://github.com/soapdog/nanodeck) to [slideshow](https://docs.racket-lang.org/slideshow/index.html) language which is one of the bundled languages that comes with Racket. Slideshow is a language for building slideshows. Once I've reached that form, I run the slideshow in memory generating bitmaps of each slide. Then I pick the pixel data for each bitmap and emit [source code in WebAssembly Text Format](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/WebAssembly/Understanding_the_text_format) which is _S-expression_ based and felt natural. The source that is emitted is just a shared memory with the pixel data. There is HTML5 source code that is copied over and uses JS to poke on the WASM exported memory to pick the pixel data and display on a canvas.

So the objective was to create a language that could be used to describe slideshows and go from there to something displayable on a browser using webassembly. That was accomplished but the way I've done it is not how it should be done, it is just a toy for the talk.

# Resumed work on Patchfox

> As mentioned in [this thread](%Fn9/eZEAp6TbsrgOjtbI+IOsAJT6zNswaFKzUq+G4lA=.sha256), I was sad with Mozilla for a while (I'm still sad) but I think I'm good enough to resume working on what is really a personal project and not a Mozilla project.

I was reworking Patchfox to replace Svelte with Mithril. This allowed me to keep most of the code intact and work only on the views themselves. While this could lead to a speedy rewrite, I came to realize that this was against what I want. I tend to work my personal projects by doing crazy dumps of idea. I get quite excited with something and want to see results fast. This causes me to work both bottom up and top down at the same time. I usually implement something from the raw routines all the way up to the UI layer, then move to another feature. **The side effect of working this way is that you're always working all over the place and the features you add later tend to sport better patterns than the features you added earlier.** I think I'm gonna call this mode of programming: _technical-debt oriented programming_. That's how Patchfox was originally built, by accruing new features and better patterns over time without reworking the earlier hacks.

In summary my pet peeves with the current version are:

* non-cohesive usage of SSB API. Patchfox offers its own idea of an SSB Library in the form of the global `SSB` class. Not only this shouldn't be a class (since you instantiate it only once and make it a global), many views go into raw `sbot` and `pull-stream` calls completely bypassing `SSB`. **Solution: There should be only one SSB API in Patchfox and I should use it**.
* lots of code duplication. The amount of code duplication in the `SSB` class is through the roof. Every time that a pull-stream is needed, there is a boilerplate that is copied over. If I wanted to add a new `through` to these pipelines, I needed to go all over the class adding it whenever it was needed. It was very easy to miss a function and then some feature would work everywhere but some edge case. This happened because those routines in that class were implemented _as they were needed_, they were not planned. This API grew organically and not by design. **Solution: Design a SSB API library from the start covering all the planned features before building the rest of the client.**.
* hard to debug and iterate. Due to the technical debt and the fact that the whole client passed through browserify before being ready for the browser it became quite costly to iterate on the code in terms of time spent transpiling and the ability to use the browser development tools. **Solution: transpile just what is needed as a preparation step, all the rest of the code is honest JS that the browser knows how to execute.** One side-effect of this was that Patchfox reached the size limits of AMO and new versions wouldn't be accepted until I split those bundles in files ~4mb. 

So, I'm solving all of this in the new version. It is already taking shape but I'll need some more days before it can reach a point where I'm working on the GUI part. For this new version I decided to work on stages and not move to the next stage before I'm happy with it. The planned stages are:

* 💚 Building infrastructure. Come up with a working scaffold and build system that allows me to work on the browser with minimal transpiling. I'll talk more about this in the next post.
* 🛠️ SSB Library. The new SSB library should be designed from the start to provide the features needed for a minimal client. It should avoid code duplication and provide an async sane API. I'm working on this now.
* 💭 Components. GUI components based on Mithril will be constructed so that a client can be built by combining components instead of assembling HTML. This should make Patchfox source-code look more like a GUI app than an HTML app.
* 💭 Packages. Patchfox is a distro of packages, this worked well in the current version and will be maintained in the next version. Anyone can pick the source and customize which packages are loaded and create new ones. The packages will be built using the components.

When the last stage is build, a distro o Patchfox is ready.

# New build system and scaffold

As mentioned in [a previous thread](%wq4Wxx8fbhCiStU9WQ1Wzf3s9qLAs5Xc0hNZW4ioezk=.sha256), I've just finished working on a new file organization and build system for Patchfox. The old system transpiled everything from `src/` into multiple bundles on `dist/` and copied over other files from elsewhere. There were also files from `src/` that were not transpiled and just copied over. It was a bit messy.

The new system uses [Jake](https://jakejs.com/) to build the add-on by doing the following actions:

## Browserify
At the moment `ssb-client` is the only browserified dependency. There is a shim for it in `browserify/ssb-client` that re-exports `ssb-client` as a global `ssbClient`. I can't make it into an ESM because somewhere in the client or its dependencies there are literal octal values which are no longer acceptable when running in _strict mode_. The global is inserted into the HTML with its own `<script src="globals/ssb-client.js>`. The client is only used once in `ssb.connect()`.

Unless `ssb-client` is upgraded, there is no need to run this again to iterate on development of the add-on.

## Snowpack
I'm using [Snowpack](https://snowpack.dev) to transform NodeJS dependencies into ESM that I can import directly on the browser. Snowpack will pick modules declared in `package.json` as `webDependencies` and transpile them into a single file ESM in `web_modules/`, so for example `pull-stream` becomes `web_modules/pull-stream.js` and I can import it in the browser with:

~~~~
import pullStream from "../web_modules/pull-stream.js"
~~~~

Unless I add more NodeJS dependencies, there is no need to run snowpack again while developing the add-on.

## Add-on code

The root folder for the add-on repo is the working tree for the add-on. It contains the `manifest.json` needed by Firefox to sideload the add-on for development and all the source code is ready to go. You can simply clone the repo, sideload the add-on. Changing any code that is not a NodeJS dependency or `ssb-client` doesn't require any step besides reloading your browser window to take effect. The JS you write is what ends in the browser.

## Packaging and distributing

There is code in that working tree that is not needed for the add-on to run such as `node_modules` and the original shim in `browserify/`. The jake task `dist` will create a `dist/` folder containing only the needed files for the add-on to run. You don't need to sideload the add-on from the `dist/` folder but it is good to try it once before release to check it out. It also gives you an idea on the side of the uncompressed add-on.

The `package` task zips the `dist/` folder using [web-ext](https://www.npmjs.com/package/web-ext) and moves the resulting file to `releases/`. As time goes by, that folder will contain zipfiles of all the released versions. This is for convenience if someone wants to rollback the add-on they are running or if we want to checkout something in a past version without going through git history management. I think it is worth to keep these files. If this gets too big I'll find another solution. I'm thinking about adding them as blobs to SSB. Don't know, I'm not yet sure if I will track `releases/` in git. I do need to generate it though as it is that zipfile that is uploaded to AMO.

On my Surface Pro X, running a full rebuild looks like this:

![image.png](&jqQijYQblE5Yi38mCG+nIxusgSlYOu1r0ZDRNgDoyyQ=.sha256)

Of course the timing is useless as the add-on is missing basically all its code rsrs.
[@af](@UYyBSgcbRAlNxWZkuU0oCYLo2s2cV3yh4FDUv/OxVwQ=.ed25519) get well soon <3

Got it working!

I had to change how `ssb.pipelines.thread.use()` worked and change the call to ` pull()` to be:

~~~
pull(
    ssb.sbot.createFeedStream(opts),
    pull.filter(msg => msg && msg.value && msg.value.content),
    pull.apply(pull, pipeline),
    pull.collect((err, msgs) => {
        if (err) {
            reject(err)
        }

        resolve(msgs)
    })
)
~~~~

The key change is ` pull.apply(pull,pipeline)` which allows me to insert _throughs_ to all my collection returning _pull-streams_ without changing the SSB API Library I'm building. It is like adding _middleware_ into ExpressJS. If you've never seen it, checkout the MDN entry for [`Function.prototype.apply()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Function/apply). 

This is that code running:

# On Patchfox & Oasis 💭

Just had a thought here...

#Oasis is _what if the JS was all in the backend._

#Patchfox is _what if the JS was all in the frontend._

Two different approaches targeting roughly the same runtime — the browser — I'm loving to see how both evolve.

With `ssb.pipelines.*` it will be trivial to implement the old Patchfox filtering and abuse prevention routines. In the old source code, any new abuse prevention feature had to touch every single `pull()` call in the source code, now, I'll just be able to do `ssb.pipelines.thread.use()` (for collection of msgs)  or `ssb.pipelines.message.use()`  (for single message) once to add those features everywhere in the add-on.

[@micro](@wsoeSOhEE3yAIEF1gTVMeStUWnoejIz1P6a3lnvjaOM=.ed25519) I don't want to rain on your dream, friend, but the SSB JS stack relies on lots of NodeJS-isms that making it work on deno might be tricky. Unless you're going like Patchwork which is ES as understood by the browser but then you need a locally running _sbot_. I don't think the full stack can be ported to deno easily.
Be aware that AFAIK Mozilla is not onboard with WARC and has serious security concerns. (Or that was the case last time I checked.)

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519),

I see deno as a second-try at NodeJS revisiting what some consider mistakes in it. There is some nice info [on this page](https://deno.land/std/manual.md#introduction). Some random highlights are:

* **Compatibility with the browser.** This alone precludes a ton of NodeJS Standard Library stuff from being present in deno.
* Use ESM instead of CommonJS.
* Capabilities based. Deno requires explicit permissions for file, network, and environment access. Which is not possible with NodeJS code which assumes it is running with the same perms as the user.
* Deno does not use npm
  *  It uses modules referenced as URLs or file paths
* Deno does not use _package.json_ in its module resolution algorithm. 

There is a strong criticism of how NPM became the official package system for NodeJS. Deno avoids that and I think that is good.
