# On laptop batteries

So the 9-cell battery that came with my x230 is busted. It works at 12% efficiency and I've timed it to last about 40 minutes. I've purchased that machine at the [Straford Computer Fair](http://www.stratfordcomputerfair.net/) which happens every Sunday near Stratford station. It is basically a bunch of vendors using foldable tables to sell their used and new products. It has a bazaar vibe, I like it as it reminds me of Rio's Uruguaiana fair but with less opportunities for being robbed or buying back your stolen goods (I once purchased my car radio back there). So, back on topic, today I went back there to see if I could replace the battery or something. The vendor was very welcoming and polite, he only had one other battery like mine there and he offer to exchange them. I tried the battery out and it was operating at 21% efficiency, which means roughly that I'll get 80 minutes out of it, which still sucks but it is better than what I had previously. He asked me how much is a new battery, I answered that I saw on eBay for about GBP 50, so he changed my battery for the 21% one and also gave me GBP 20 back. I liked that.

Today I was researching Reddit and eBay looking for a battery to buy. I'm very wary of buying second-hand battery or unbranded knock-offs. They usually don't age well and are sometime hazardous. That was when I discovered the most amazing thing (or at least I considered it amazing): **Duracell makes Laptop batteries!!!!** 

![image.png](&1lILuYyw08W/1PMn3GDX3bgVR2C7ZAcz05XJEAFjHeg=.sha256)

Yes, you've read it right, you can go to a Duracell shop, put your laptop model in and they will probably have a brand new duracell-cell based battery for you. For the X230 here in the UK they only sell the 6-cell batteries but I suspect that their brand new 6-cell battery will behave better than an unbranded 9-cell knock-off. So I'm purchasing one for myself right now. Will let you know how it goes once I received it.

For those with X230, this is the [UK link](https://www.duracelldirect.co.uk/laptop-notebook/lenovo/thinkpad-x230-battery--kvme6f.html).

I packaged it as a webextension for firefox that places the timers in your sidebar, this way you can browse the web and reveal or close your timers with a simple keyboard keystroke. It looks like this:

 **I haven't released this and will not release this myself on AMO. [@wakest!](@VUXqH/zofAP4WYNnUFjfc8gBU6kJ6jlBe2I9VC6NVTk=.ed25519),

Even though I like it on Twitter as well, I don't think this is a good case for SSB, let me delve into why (and be aware that I too wished that up to some days ago when I really started thinking about it.)

In SSB, apps are not silos, you can use multiple apps with the same feed. You can use Oasis as your daily driver and then switch to Patchbay for gatherings, dark crystal, books and chess, and then switch to Patchfox to be able to post _blog entries_ while browsing or researching. In all these cases, the data is saved to the same location and it is not clear which app is running the `ssb-server`. 

Because of that scenario above, the only way would be to attach metadata to every single message to say where it originated from. Since we don't provide a registry in which apps could register for an ID and thus allow us to use a small compact representation (such as an numeric enum), we'd end up with stuff that is like user-agent strings as can be seen on this mock up:

`SSB/js-stack ssb-server@15.3 patchbay@32 (forked by SoapDog, not up to date because he is lazy), <list of plugins> Win10 ARM64`

And it doesn't matter how compact you make this, if you attach it to every message, we're collectively bloating feed size a lot. It is like padding each record with some extra bytes, this hard a price in disk space, and what does it gets us? A cute experience that even though cute and nice, is not worth the bloat.

I wanted that too for a long time but when I stopped to think of the ramifications, I thought that it doesn't really matter what app I use. If the objective is just discovery of new clients, then, we can simply craft a new message which is a `client announcement` much like a `pub announcement` and client developers could use that to announce new versions. This has many many many many advantages, the main ones being:

* If this message carry download links, your current client can offer you the ability to download the new client or update.
* This being kept in the feed provides statistics on client development over time.
* Depending on which information is added to this message type, it unlocks more actions than just downloading, for example if it links to source code it can allow downloading the source.
* It makes us eat our own vegan food and craft nifty little updates and client switching gizmos that rely on our own technology.

I'm thinking something along the lines of:

~~~
{
  "app": "patchfox",
  "version":"2020.2.2",
  "description: "bla bla bla",
  "icon": "<blob id>",
  "source": "https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/patchfox",
  "releaseNotes":"<post msg id or blog msg id>",
  "downloadLinks": [
    {
      "os": "<all>",
       "url": "https://addons.mozilla.org/yada/yada/"
    }]
}
~~~

This way we embrace the decentralized nature of SSB with everyone able to release clients on the feed. You can even bind forked clients together with tangles, or about messages, or root/branch, not sure what is the best way to mark that one msg is related to another these days. It also do not bloat the feed because it is not attached to all messages, it only happens when there is a new version of a client.

[@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) there are many things that Fate does differently than others RPGs and even though some of these have been present in other earlier system, I have never seen them fully realized together in a single cohesive package. I'll outline some of my favorite stuff:

### Aspects

As [@Fábio Emilio Costa 🇧🇷🐇🕐🎩☕✅ (Patchwork-Requeriment Room)](@UaDd69LROKdpgNokDjdyxgxmXH0J/HD1eK7KEb98/+g=.ed25519) mentioned, aspects are the keystone of Fate and the whole metagame is an economic game around aspects and [_Fate points_](https://fate-srd.com/fate-core/fate-points). Each player has a couple points per session, these points can be spent to:

* **Get dice bonus (or reroll):** If the player can explain how such and such aspect can be used in that action, they can spent a Fate point to either get a bonus or reroll their dice. Example: Hardboiled Detective Harry Hermie has an aspect _Former olympic team swimmer_, when gangsters throw him out of a boat in the bay, his player invokes this aspect to get a bonus on his roll to swim to the shore. The GM accepts the _Fate point_ and the player adds +2 to the roll. 
* **DECLARE A STORY DETAIL:** With the GM agreement, the player can declare a story detail that changes the narrative. Example: Hardboiled Detective Harry Hermie has an aspect _first on the scene_, his player is trying to get to a crime scene ahead of the police and this aspect makes sense, the GM accepts the _Fate point_ and lets the player arrive first on the scene.

The thing is that players start with very few _Fate points_ about two or three, and so there is a mechanism for them getting fate points back, which is _compelling an aspect_. A good aspect needs to work both ways, as in it should be a blessing and a curse. For example, our Hardboiled Detective Harry Hermie has the _first on the scene_ aspect which even though it enables him to arrive quick where he needs to be, it also makes him arrive without any backup. So in a dangerous scene, where Harry is actually being wise and waiting for backup, the GM might compel this aspect and offer a _Fate point_ to the player to agree to arrive first without backup. If the player accepts the compel, Harry is put in a dangerous situation but that player got an extra _Fate point_ to use in the future.

I is not uncommon for players to have matching aspects, such as one character is a mechanic and work with another hero which is a rocketeer flyboy, her name is Sally and the rocketeer is John. John has an aspect _Sally, Save Me!_ which characterize their dynamic where he is always getting into trouble and being saved by the trusted mechanic. Sally on the other hand has an aspect _John is in trouble!_, which puts even more strength to these types of scenarios. These has the metagame property of making both players working the narrative so that the male hero rocketeer is always in trouble and being saved by the female mechanic as they get much more bonuses by acting these ways than against their aspects. The GM is constantly tempted to give them fate points as those aspects are very easy to compel and yet provide the necessary bonus or narrative interference potential. By the way, his example is actually from the book, not my creation, I think this example is a stroke of genius.

## No hit points / health points

In _Spirit of the Century_ and many other Fate games, characters simply don't have hit points as it is a narrative game and not a spreadsheet. The character dies if it makes sense for the narrative for the character to die but not because they've reach some arbitrary threshold on a metric on paper. Characters have _stress tracks_ which basically mark how much _stress marks_ they can get before they have to suffer _a consequence_. There are minor, normal, major consequences. So depending on how much stress (either physical or mental, depending on the action and game) received, the player might opt to get a consequence instead of filling more boxes on the stress track. In a combat, a player might opt to _break an arm_ as a consequence. In a mental combat such as an exchange of insults during a ball, a player might opt to be _humiliated with childhood story in front of their peers_ as a consequence. Instead of numeric damage, you usually have _in narrative consequences_ for combat failure.

## Whole chapters about pacing and crafting stories

The books usually goes beyond what is normal for the GM sections and include a lot of information about crafting compelling stories and maintaining pace. One of my favorite subsections of _Spirit of the Century_ is actually about pacing, remember is a pulp adventure, in that chapter they are outlining what to do if the players are blocked or the adventure stalled and is no longer running at pulp speed. They advise is simply: **send in the ninjas!**, it requires no explanation of why, you just get ninjas (or their equivalent in your setting) to break the windows and start a combat, one of the ninjas might have the info to move the story forward, the pace picked up again. It is pulp.

Something that also stuck with me is when they describe one of the main antagonists in that universe, which is a crazy scientist called _Doctor Methuselah_ (may contain typos). In most D&D games, the villains and monsters are there to be beaten and killed. In _Spirit of the Century_ the GM is told to treat _Doctor Methuselah_ not like that, he is not something for the players to beat and kill. He should be treated as a force of nature, you don't beat and kill a storm, you survive it. Players should survive Doctor Methuselah, thats the correct mindset. That kind of advise and worldbuilding changed GMing forever for me and thats why even _Spirit of the Century_ is my favorite game. It is Fate 2.0 and has problems, the new Fate 3.0 is much better and I can play _SotC_ in it without problem. 

The one Fate game I want and don't have yet is [Atomic Robo](https://www.evilhat.com/home/atomic-robo/) which is based on [the comics of the same name](https://www.atomic-robo.com/). Atomic Robo is one of my favorite comics. It is fucking great and very fun to read. It is as pulp as Spirit of the Century but it provides even more material to work with.

> Are you ready for some two-fisted science adventure? Then it’s time for the Atomic Robo RPG! Have you ever wanted to face down global conspiracy as an immortal atomic robot or Carl Sagan? The Atomic Robo RPG makes it possible.
— _Source: [Atomic Robo Roleplaying Game](https://www.evilhat.com/home/atomic-robo/)_

Be aware that since Fate has an SRD there are many other companies pushing Fate based games out there and not all of them think in the same terms as Evil Hat. A very good example of a good game developed by another company is [Starblazers Adventures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starblazer_Adventures) (I just learned as I was writing this post that it is out of print).

Well thats is it! Fate points, aspects, consequences! Players with narrative power beyond what they usually have in other systems! Pick up and play in ten minutes! Doctor Methuselah is plotting something, it is up to you to stop it!
omg, the [Fate SRD page lists a ton of other games](https://fate-srd.com/) some of which I never heard about...

I've been a bit too anxious about all the panic regarding that virus. All my timelines are flooded with some strange combination of actual facts and good advise and crazy shit. I don't think it is healthy for me but I can't do anything about other places, but I can do something here. SSB is my calm place, where I come to have fun, enjoy life and discover new stuff. 

I understand why people are talking about it and why it is important, it is just that it passed the threshold for me and it is no longer comfortable. That doesn't mean I want people here to change topics or focus. I think it is healthy that people here are talking about it. Thankfully for me, Patchfox contains filters, so I've added two filters:

![Annotation 2020-03-01 143507.png](&0b23OK/47ePJG7xJR5lYgh+YeJLgqnEVJT6YEsCP96k=.sha256)

As you can see from the shot, I'm filtering both a whole channel and messages containing a keyword. That's why I can't type that virus name here or I'll filter my own message. This way SSB stays the same but my subjective view of it changes. I'm no longer exposed to content I don't want without crippling or altering conversations for other people. I can see in the debug logs that content is being filtered:

![Annotation 2020-03-01 143734.png](&qvHwoJmqELumqzZdxCC+uApGiiV5fTcyUq6mDmyUhlE=.sha256)

Which means this stuff is working. Filters are powerful and I wish more clients would adopt something similar. They live only on the client-side, so you don't risk your filters being exposed. One day I might do an export filters to the feed as a private msg feature.

Anyway, I'm happy to solve my own problems and this is why SSB is beautiful. It is a toolkit, we can mold our subjective experience.

it is not foolproof of course as it looks only into the content of a single message, so it doesn't have special treatment of replies, forks, or threads. If the message is not in that channel, and does not contain the keyword but it is a reply for a message that does, it will still appear in my timeline. Making it exhaustive is too exhausting and costly, I'm ok with some cases slipping through.

Welcome to the new release of Patchfox called **The Great Oasis Heist** in which the greatest and most visible addition is the popular view that was first popularized by the [Oasis client](http://github.com/fraction/oasis) (you really should check them out, amazing project and people).

Or from the browser action menu:

 ![Annotation 2020-03-01 230553.png](&EWqyomRXDVVCvF+AZT6QI34Qdlo253ajEqTUbkuEr5k=.sha256)

Another visible change is the inclusion of the message you're replying to in the compose window for a new post:

![Annotation 2020-03-01 231259.png](&40P4J1KhSAOPNVsZWPqXB+T4eq8+7fYWxLN7A/r7KCk=.sha256)

All the other changes were to the internal plumbing in the quantum spaghetti I call source code. 

You can find more information about patchfox on its on web site at [Patchfox.org](https://patchfox.org). The source code is available both in [Github](https://github.com/soapdog/patchfox/) and [Sourcehut](https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/patchfox). You can install it on Firefox via the [Firefox Add-ons Portal](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/patchfox/). This release has been made from the _master_ branch and is being collected at the _v2020.3.1_ tag.

The release notes are:

* **SSB:**
  * Fixed bug with `pull.take(limit)` being fed a string from prefs.
  * Fixed channel and keywords filters.
  * Adding support for pipelines.
  * Reworking everything to use pipelines instead of code duplication.
  * Stolen popular view from Oasis. 
  * There is dead code inside `ssb.js`, It is still WIP.
* **Core:** SSB Client instantiation no longer depends on hardcoded manifest.
* **Hub:** Added popular view (from Oasis).
* **Browser Action:**
  * Added Sourcehut item so that people who don't want to use Github have another option.
  * Added version number to header.
  * Added popular view.
  * Fixes to shortcuts including `c` for _compose new post_ and `f` for going to own profile.
* **Calendar:** limited the _Future Events_ view so that it shows events only up to two years ahead.

### Yesterday, I made Knuth feel a shiver thousands of KM away....

#patchfox 2020.3.1 has a _popular view_ that was taken from #oasis. In Oasis, that view fetches the a number of records that is dictated by:

~~~~
 pull.take(Math.min(length, maxMessages)),
~~~~
_From [Oasis](https://github.com/fraction/oasis/blob/master/src/models.js#L998)_

And it shows those records and thats it. Thats a good behavior. Still, in most Patchfox views that displays a collection of threads (aka anything from the `hub` package and some more) has pagination built-in. There is always both _go previous_ and _go next_ buttons at the end, so I decided I needed that for the popular view as well. Let me be quite clear, Patchfox has that view now but I have no illusion that I understand how [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) computed it, I just patched it enough so it would run. Because of the way it works, there is no easy way to ask for the next page. So, I did what any MacGyver/Jerryrigger/Brazilian would do which is _the worst possible solution that works._

Patchfox has a preference that containst the number of records per page. I changed Oasis popular function signature from `popular({period})` to `popular({period, page})` which means you can ask for a specific page. The way it works is that it multiplies the page number by the limit and fetches that number of records then it slices the result with `collectedMessages.slice(limit * -1)` to fetch only the last page. This means that as you move to the next pages in the popular view, you're fetching more and more records. I can't imagine how many pages you needs to pull until the performance degrades so much that it is unusable. 

This was my quick and dirty solution to pick a query I don't understand and add pagination to it. I'm sure Professor Knuth is shivering somewhere in the U.S.  much like Leia when Alderan exploded, and wondering who in the world is butchering Computer Science. I expect a full squad of Action Computer Science Seals to descend here on me at any time (they are known as the *Garbage Collectors™*) and make me pay for my performance sins.

I'm still working on this. I hope to have a working version by the end of the week. I'll need help with code review for the final part of the restore process. It is too important to let my eyes be the only pair of eyes on it.

# Release 2020.3.2

I've just submit a new release to fix a lingering error on the settings screen that would prevent new users from configuring their secret. The new version is live and your Patchfoxes should be auto-updating right now.

Oh, bonus: Patchfox works quite well on Cliqz.

Patchfox also works on the new Microsoft Edge (which is based on Chromium). The sidebar stuff doesn't work but most of the other features do. The contextual menus also appear not to be working, but the main UI and browser action are fine.

![Annotation 2020-03-02 145155.png](&8JRSN+Jyx/xztSjKe1QgWmAV5KLqoXmUug+MgiHYRjQ=.sha256)

This means that it should work like this on Google Chrome, Opera (which has sidebars) and Vivaldi. I'm not going to release on those browsers at the moment. I'm focusing only on Firefox but it runs on the other browsers too. I thought that many people here didn't realized that.

## PLEASE HALP!

I want to return to this discussion as we need custom url schemes to work. The current scheme used by Patchfox which is:

`ssb:%LcpqzC9+YeQT5fIN79WhcJzfMZPZ9jjGWcXy3fUO5xg=.sha256`

doesn't work anymore as it is not a valid url. The scheme proposed by [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) in #ssb-uri npm module which is similar to:

`ssb:message:sha256:g3hPVPDEO1Aj_uPl0-J2NlhFB2bbFLIHlty-YuqFZ3w=`

Also doesn't work. The browser doesn't recognize this as a valid URL and redirect to search instead of the custom protocol handler.

We need to tweak this until the browsers are happy, or it will never work and we'll not be able to interoperate with the larger web. This could for example be used to generate QR Codes for peer invites, to view messages on the web, and much more.

Relevant patchfox code:

All the filtering stuff is in [`abusePrevention.js`](https://github.com/soapdog/patchfox/blob/master/src/core/platforms/ssb/abusePrevention.js). This code is used from the my SSB platform support file which is [`ssb.js`](https://github.com/soapdog/patchfox/blob/master/src/core/platforms/ssb/ssb.js).

The new codebase is using pipelines, which are basically pull-stream's throughs which are pluggable at runtime. The one that does filtering is called [`filterWithUserFilters`](https://github.com/soapdog/patchfox/blob/master/src/core/platforms/ssb/ssb.js#L142-L150). It is plugged into the pipeline with: `pipelines.thread.use(this.filterWithUserFilters)` which causes all SSB routines that fetches a collection of threads — such as public, mentions, etc — to pass through those filters.

Today I learned it is quite easy to break `ssb-server` by triggering a bunch of `ssb-ws` calls.

Patchfox load timelines like your public feed, popular msgs, and mentions using a single query. That collected set of messages is then passed to Svelte. I've added a `<VoteCounter>` to the `<PostCard>` to be able to show how many people liked a message. This counter does a ssb query to count votes. So for each message in the public feed, it spawns the name number of queries. So, if you never changed the default limit, it means that it would fetch 10 messages and then each message would query for votes. This is crashing `ssb-server`. Be aware that those same 10 messages already query for avatars as well. It appears that the mux in muxrpc is not that mux.

Oh, before that I added Oasis's `transform()` to my pipeline but it slowed fetching messages so much that it became unusable. I'm running with 15 messages limit here and still, it took minutes for a view to load.

Starting on a tentative quick library at https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/ssb-custom-uri to explore this idea.

## Requisites:

* Library should be compatible with the browser without transpiling.

I made an initial version at https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/ssb-custom-uri

Below is the readme. The API signatures are compatible with [ssb-uri](https://github.com/fraction/ssb-uri) by [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) but it is made in vanilla js that should work on the browser and on nodejs without transpiling.

I made a new library because I didn't want to send a PR changing too much of what [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) built on the other library.

# API

### Usage

~~~~
import ssbUri from "./ssb-custom-uri.js"
~~~~

### fromSigilLink
Converts a sigil link from SSB into a custom `ssb:` URL.

~~~~
ssbUri.fromSigilLink("%EOgRe5ppgaugsqGyoWxJQ3QCFaGV7akjFUQ+9RR1jfk=.sha256")

// => ssb:message/sha256/EOgRe5ppgaugsqGyoWxJQ3QCFaGV7akjFUQ+9RR1jfk=
~~~~

### toSigilLink
Converts a `ssb:` url back into a ssb sigil link:

~~~~
ssbUri.toSigilLink("ssb:message/sha256/EOgRe5ppgaugsqGyoWxJQ3QCFaGV7akjFUQ+9RR1jfk=")

// => %EOgRe5ppgaugsqGyoWxJQ3QCFaGV7akjFUQ+9RR1jfk=.sha256
~~~~

# License

MIT

## Added: Pub invites to/from URL

### pubInviteToLink
Converts a pub invite to a shareable link

~~~~
ssbUri.pubInviteToLink("foo.bar.co.nz:8009:@6lOh+rLq4MQubPQoKenbB827dh5NVc2FAjy30MTc08o=.ed25519~93RP4aT6YNm+7++Ab3VQd+w/CL2w6p8QuX7fRaUs9cY=")

// => ssb:invite/pub/foo.bar.co.nz/8009/93RP4aT6YNm%2B7%2B%2BAb3VQd%2Bw%2FCL2w6p8QuX7fRaUs9cY%3D/feed/ed25519/6lOh%2BrLq4MQubPQoKenbB827dh5NVc2FAjy30MTc08o%3D
~~~~

### pubInviteFromLink
Converts a link back into a pub invite

~~~~
ssbUri.pubInviteToLink("ssb:invite/pub/foo.bar.co.nz/8009/93RP4aT6YNm%2B7%2B%2BAb3VQd%2Bw%2FCL2w6p8QuX7fRaUs9cY%3D/feed/ed25519/6lOh%2BrLq4MQubPQoKenbB827dh5NVc2FAjy30MTc08o%3D")

// => foo.bar.co.nz:8009:@6lOh+rLq4MQubPQoKenbB827dh5NVc2FAjy30MTc08o=.ed25519~93RP4aT6YNm+7++Ab3VQd+w/CL2w6p8QuX7fRaUs9cY=
~~~~

With this pubs can add `<a href="ssb:...">` clickable links to their pages and the clients that support custom URLs can intercept those navigation actions and join the pub.

cc [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) [@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519)

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519),

This library is completely self contained and build in old school vanilla JS. I think it is best if it is not incorporated in any of our current NodeJS modules as those can't be used inside the browser without transpiling. It is a single ES6 file.

If this is placed into SSB-Ref or SSB-URI, then I can't use it easily from Patchfox. SSB-URI has `fs.*` access in it and is not browserifiable. SSB-Ref needs transpiling before I can use it and since it uses the standard nodejs library, it needs to be browserified, which makes it a bit larger than needed.

We could simply start using this library as it is now. It doesn't contain the checks and tests that ssb-ref and ssb-uri have. If you pass a malformed URL, you'll get a malformed sigil link or invite back. I can add more tests if we feel we really need it.

I'm still working on this. From my own imprecise calculations, a page consisting of 15 messages would call about 45 queries. Basically three queries per message as the different components in a _message card_ are self-contained and spawn their own queries to fetch the data they need. That is kinda too much to do at the same time. I don't really need this to be fast, I just need it not to crash.

I'm now fiddling with caching responses and creating some work pool/queue.

An important side-effect of the URL scheme being used is that it plays well with routers. The library generates URLs that look like:

* `ssb:message/...`
* `ssb:feed/...`
* `ssb:blob/....`
* `ssb:invite/dht/...`
* `ssb:invite/pub/...`

So regardless of which kind of router you're using, it is easy to strip out the `ssb:` from the URL and do some switch case, or pattern matching if you're lucky to be using a language that supports it, to find out what kind of URL it is. That is also why I haven't implemented a catch-all parser in the library as this is probably better handled by whatever router you're more comfortable with. You can even do silly RegExes to find out which type of URL it is...

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519), 

> 1. I think the “format” part perhaps should be just a number

I think that using numbers make sense only when we're dealing with binary data as it is more compact. For URLs, I think that strings are better and more descriptive. I don't need to keep a hashtable matching the numbers with formats and then somehow having to add more numbers later or retconning stuff as we figure out we did some stuff wrong.

People don't read and memorize URLs like they used to. Many browsers are actively hiding the URLs from the user these days. What we need is for the user to be able to click them. 

> 2. What do we do to support “tangle” locations.

The way I see it, this is up to the client developer. If the user navigates to a URL `ssb:message/...` then the client will pick it up, convert it back to a _message id_ and then decide if it should fetch the whole tangle, reduce the gathering, whatever it needs to do. This goes beyond tangles as new forms of entanglement can be discovered in the future. A client might fetch the whole tangle, another client might just want to fetch that single message. I don't think the URLs should carry information about what it should do with the message as different messages require different types of resolution.

Thats the same reason why I didn't make a `ssb:gathering/...` because that is just a message and the client will identify it is a gathering and do whatever it needs to do. We have hundreds of message types already and as the network grows, there will be even more (I have about 20 more in my mind at least). I don't think the URLs should contain specific parts for each message like that or it will be soon very hard to maintain. Specially once clients start diverting regarding competing message specs (we already have a bunch of those going on with branches and forks).

The main objective for this library is (at the moment) to be able to provide the following features:

* an easy way to convert ids for messages, feeds, and blobs into URLs that can be shared through browsers, im and email.
* an easy way to convert pub and peer invites into and from links.

This alone is already much more than we have now and will allow much easier onboarding into pubs/rooms and linking on the normal web.

[@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519),

I'm doing both ephemeral and long-term caching. Avatars are cached in localstorage and placed in a quick access object when the app launches for example. 

I couldn't simply use `pull-paramap` in the `publi()` call to fetch things because the components are self-contained and some cards and apps may use different sets of components. I'm trying to build a little working queue here, so that all components may still call what they want but those calls are placed in a queue and worked out five by five or some other sensible amount.

[@Johan](@4XHLGF4UDOGiS5oqiDUjN97cKVBExloikIIGMiNjHq0=.ed25519),

Thats part of the story. The thing is that Microsoft can't be expected to port every single language and runtime under the sun by themselves. They need buy in from developers and those developers will only join the platform if there is enough appeal/incentive. Microsoft needs to do a better job of making this new ISA attractive to developers. I've [written about it](https://andregarzia.com/2020/01/windows-on-arm-needs-more-support-from-developers.html).

Windows with an x86 based CPU works pretty well as a developer platform. The problem is when you're doing it on ARM64...

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519),

> * save some length

I don't think this is worth it as it adds more code running as you'll need to keep and maintain a table of correspondences between the numbers and whatever the format is. Also, remember that you have a full url encoded hash after that, so you're not really saving much. It is not worth to add complexity to save ~14 bytes.

> * reduce the amount of junk most people might try and parse (with their eyes)

There is a whole hash in the URL, changing the first segment from something that is actually human identifiable to a magic number doesn't help. The hash is already junk-looking enough. URLs are either wrapped in an `<a>` hyperlink with a nice description in a web page, or sent through im, email, etc to be clicked. If you check any of the dweb URLs, they don't usually are human friendly URLs. All of them contain hashes already. 

Whoever is eye parsing the URL won't be fussed by a human readable string when being presented with the rest of the url which is base64 uri encoded hash.

> * keeping the URIs a consistent length:
>   * the proposed gabby-grove format suffix is currently .ggmsg-v1

The URLs are already not consistent length. They start with prefixes which might be `message`, `blob`, `invite/dht`, `invite/pub`. Depending if it is an _invite code_ or a _hash_ they also have a different number of segments.

Seeing `message/ggmsg-v1/<hash>` is better than `message/1/<hash>` as that one means nothing unless you know the magical number correspondence. Also, if you use numbers and suddenly you need different hash encoding types besides _base64 uri encoded_ then you either need to add more numbers which are not really different formats but encoding for the hash itself, then you have stuff such as

number | meaning
---------|------------
0           | uriEncoded(base64(sha256 hash))
1           | uriEncoded(base64(gabbygrove hash))
2           | lowercase hex encoding of (sha256 hash)
3           | lowercase hex encoding of (gabbygrove hash)

when with strings you could in theory do something like `message/sha256~hex/abc1234fffff...`. Strings are more flexible, easier to debug, more future proof. For example, check IPFS multishash, multiformat, multicodec, and friends, they are all like this with numbers in tables pointing to different formats and codecs. This leads to complexity that we don't need.

> * reduce coder errors:
>   * making it non-human readable is a feature in my mind. I don’t expect people memorise numbers, I would like us all to build off a common spec like https://github.com/ssbc/envelope-spec/blob/master/encoding/tfk.json
>   * this is a pattern e.g. graphql uses for pagination - don’t make things human readable otherwise humans will mess it up.

I'm sorry but I need to strongly disagree with that. Making something intentionally not human readable is not a feature. It is _safety by obscurity_. It adds nothing tangible. I have my own strong opinions regarding GraphQL, the one thing that is important here is that GraphQL queries and mutations are often written by hand by the developers. The URLs generated by this library are not to be written by humans. You have a function that picks either a hash or an invite code and turns into a URL you can share, and a couple other functions that reverse that process. That's the only objective of this library. It is not comparable to GraphQL at all as the needs, constraints, and developer ergonomics are completely different. Those patterns are not transferable like this.

> Maybe including a type is incorrect. I think there is a need though for including information about where you expect a user to be standing, and what they are seeing once they follow a link.
>
> I think the reason you and I might have different opinions is that I’ve moved from seeing messages like emails, and started seeing them (thanks to Aljoscha’s corrupting influence) as transformations. In this context looking at an individual transformation rarely makes sense … and we rarely want to do it. We almost always choose to load in additional message around that.
>
> We can chose to make some of these distinctions optional and in the client, but I think it would be a mistake, because we have a change to convey more meaning.

I don't think I'm conveying the objective of this library clearly, sorry if my communication is confusing. This is a custom URL generation and parsing library. It is agnostic of how each developer sees SSB. A developer can see it as a _chain of transformations_ and another as simple _messages like email with additional linked data_, both approaches can use this library.

Some messages are tangles, transformations, or linked data. This is most prevalent in either mutable entities such as gatherings and linked data like threads, but there are plenty of messages in SSB that are indeed email like and don't require any reducing or transforming. A client might load a _post_ and not query anything else, or it might load the full thread, or it might load backlinks and compute likes and tags as well, it is up to each developer.

Regardless of what you want to do, and regardless of what most people will do, this step will happen after you have transformed the custom URL back into something usable such as a sigil link. The key important concept is separation of concerns here. The way the library is structured makes it serve our current needs and is future proof as it makes no assumption. 

Regarding _tangle locations_ the client that is generating the URL is _tangle aware_ and can choose which is the best _hash id_ to place in the URL. If using the root id makes easier to reduce a given tangle, then share it with the root id, if the developer intent is just to share a branch of the tangle, then share the branch hash id instead. Reasoning about tangles should happen before generating the URL, and after parsing it, it should not be responsibility of the URL library to handle that.

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519),

my friend, I'm exhausted and frustrated.

This is being written after I posted %pwH9Gm82863Opf+oHiTWMq0vgoUw97IU4IkZbtuSzcU=.sha256 it might be better to read that before reading this message.

> p.s. tests and checks are one of the main reasons a module like this would exist (for me). I want shit to throw when someone tries something wrong, I want clear error messages

As shown in the `demo.js` in the library source, the transformation works both way, so we know the library functions are working fine as you can go from a hash to a URL and then back to the same hash. 

The library has some quick tests for the prefixes it uses. Trying to encode a sigil link that is not a sigil link will output an error and return false. Trying to parse a URL that is not one originating from a sigil link will throw an error. What the library doesn't do is check if the final hash or invite are valid. This can be done in your client code after you transformed the URL back into a hash or invite. This is an intentional decision because this way it avoids importing something like `ssb-ref` which is not browser compatible. Your code doesn't change much:

~~~~
const link = ssbUri.toSigilLink(`ssb:message/sha256/blablabla`)
if (ssbRef.isValid(link)) {
  // do your thing!
}
~~~~~

There is no reason to make the URL parsing library handle the complexities of verifying if the hash or invite are valid because you already have code in your client to do it. This would be duplication of code and needlessly coupling between this library and other libraries which are all nodejs based. The way it is, this library is compatible with NodeJS, browser, transpiling, deno, maybe even espruino. It is so simple that you can copy and paste the whole library in the browser console and play with it. **Being simple is a feature.**

> Oh, and I also use this for mocking out example data for tests.

You can already use it for this purpose but I don't know what kind of tests you want to run as the only thing this library does is convert things to URLs. The `demo.js` has tests.

> I’m less keen on a proliferation of thingees.

The SSB JS stack is quite big already. We have ~20+ NodeJS libraries with tight coupling, some of which that are completely duplication such as `ssb-marked` and `ssb-markdown`, but we don't have a library that does what this library does. There is `ssb-uri`, but the browser didn't like those URLs, so we can't use it. This library was built from scratch instead of contributing to `ssb-uri` to remove the dependency on nodejs and because I didn't want to send a PR to [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519)
that was like _hey, I deleted everything, here are the new files._ I don't think this library is where we draw the line of _proliferation of thingees_, it makes sense for this to be its own library.

> It feels like we have something that’s basically a shared need / desire.
> Can we get together on a call and bang out an API we agree on in a hackmd? 

I'm going to be honest. I'm extremely frustrated and burned out by this. I've personally spent more than a year trying to get this going. [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) himself probably spent close to a year or more on this as well. Currently Patchfox is the only client that supports custom URLs, there was no _buy in_ regardless of how much we spoke about the benefits of it. 

The main feature of the World Wide Web is hyperlinking, that is what makes the web a web. Custom URLs are the way to make SSB be a part of the WWW and reap the benefits of it. Both DAT and IPFS have custom URLs.

(continues in a reply, it was too large for a single post)

continuation of %ILBf4aRg2N+K3i3HY3ovds6sm5v7OtEP+NCOr1c4suU=.sha256

## Stories about why this is important

### Pub and Peer invites
Currently, to join a pub, a user needs (taking patchwork as an example):

* Copy the invite code: Three mouse clicks on most OS (select, context menu, copy). Error prone as you need to make sure that you copied the whole thing and only the invite code, not extra potential text surrounding it.
* Launch Patchwork: one click.
* Open join pub dialog: one click.
* Paste the code: one click (middle mouse button, or two clicks if contextual menu + paste, or one keyboard shortcut)
* Accept the invite: one click.

So this is a task involving about seven clicks and multiple dialogs and actions. With the custom invite URL, all of this is a single click. The user clicks on the URL, the client opens, recognizes it is an invite code and does the dance to accept it.

### User wants to share some SSB post on the Web (or other dweb app)

Currently there are only two options, you can either paste a plain-text hash and hope the reader knows what to do with it which usually involves:

* Copying the hash: about three clicks.
* Pasting on the search feature of your client: opaque feature which is hard to discover, one click.

or placing a link to an webby SSB viewer which will only work if both the user and the viewer are actually online.

With this library this is just a single click. The SSB client will open, recognize it is a SSB message link and do whatever it needs to do. The library also supports replacing the protocol schema from `ssb:` to whatever you want, so you can have multiple apps with their own schema but using the same library. This for example allows a client like Patchfox to potentially launch Whakapapa Ora. Allowing clients to launch each other with a single library can potentially lead to more nimble apps as we can start making clients cooperate on the same machine. An example of this can be:

~~~~
// potential patchfox code
if (msg.value.content.type === "whakapapa/view") {
  // oops, we don't deal with this, launch Whakapapa Ora.
  ssbUri.setCustomProtocolSchema("whakapapa-ora")
  let url = ssbUri.fromSigilLink(msg.key)
  window.open(url)
}
~~~~

And in Whakapapa Ora, you can declare that you handle both `ssb:` and `whakapapa-ora:` and point both protocols at the same routine. The user, when having multiple apps that handle `ssb:` installed, is presented with dialog to select in which app they want to open `ssb:` links. If specific niche apps such as Whakapa Ora (and maybe chess, git ssb, etc) declare additional protocol schemas (basically aliases), then we can start launching each other. This has a ton of potential, and the way it is it can even work on mobile as the current library is compatible with cordova and reactnative.

# Conclusion

I'm tired. I'm so tired of needing this and trying to get a conversation going that I went ahead and wrote the library I needed. I took care to make it agnostic enough and simple enough so that it can be used by every single client, from Patchfoo to Patchbay and Patchfox. I also made it simple enough so that I know how to send PRs to the clients to add support for it in case this is the only way forward.

This feature is not complex at all. We have way more complex stuff such as tangles, private groups, partial replication, all of which do require conversations and planning. Those are different cases. The custom URL thing was the very first thing I did for SSB. I did it before I even started working on Patchfox. Thats probably two years ago now. In those two years, couple times each year, I tried to raise the issue. Tried getting people to agree on something, and not a single client besides mine ever implemented anything at all, not even a competing spec. This was not because people were waiting about consensus. It is because developers don't care enough about WWW to work on this, and that is OK I totally understand.

In all SSB related IRL gatherings I've been, I raised this issue. I spoke about this at ScuttleCamp One, at MozFest, at Redecentralize, at IPFS Camp with other butts, at P2P Basel during our unconf chats. I came to realize that everyone is just waiting for this to be fixed by someone else. This was a classic case of _somebodyshould_. It is fixed now and I am too tired of hitting this same convos again and again. This thread alone is about a year old and has probably close to 100 messages now.

I'm shipping this. If people want something else, or want to discuss this in a meeting, I'm happy to join in. If people have problems with the current API or code, there is [an issue tracker online](https://todo.sr.ht/~soapdog/ssb-custom-uri). `ssb-custom-uri` is just a way to convert hashes and invite codes to and from custom URLs, I don't want to bikeshed it. If we find a problem, I'll fix it. If there is something that must be done URL-wise that is not done at the moment, I'll do it. This is not a case of _if we do this wrong, we break SSB_, this is peripheral to SSB and whatever is done here doesn't affect the day to day work of any client at all (which is also why we have a year long thread about this, there is no time pressure to fix it).

I know I'm sounding harsh and impatient, I'm sorry, I'm very very sorry. This is not personal or anything. I'm just too tired or circling this problem forever when I have a working solution that pleases the browsers and is easy to use, the response is _let's talk some more!_

Unfortunately, I can't attend the event anyway. This is not because any virus, it is just not a good time for me to travel to Brazil due to personal reasons. Basically I haven't visited the country since I left for the UK so any time I step inside, I'll need to go to multiple states to visit family and friends and that is more expensive and takes longer than I can afford to at the moment. If I went to ScuttleCamp Two, I'd need to visit at least four states and probably stay more than a month. My pre-settlement agreement with the UK just allows me to travel for two months at a time and not more than 180 days summed together in five years (IIRC). So it is not good for me to travel there, which is the reason I haven't spoken about the event at all, as I'm not going.

Because I'm not a stakeholder in the event, and I'm not keen on involving myself in convos about this virus (as I mentioned in another msg, I'm filtering these terms), I'm not going to give any advise here beyond the fact that it is probably easier to get the virus in Europe than Brazil right now.

Also, people travelling should have travel health insurance in case they are going to a place that their citizenship doesn't entitle them to healthcare. In Brazil you'll be allowed in emergencies if it is an emergency regardless of healthcare plan or insurance IIRC, but it is always better to travel with insurance.

Personally, I'm restricting my travels. I was not scheduled to go to BR but I did have a travel to Italy at the end of the month and another one to Amsterdam. I'm not thinking about going to either places.

# Release 2020.3.3

* **MessageDropdown:** fixing layout for the dropdown menu.
* **README:** fixed build instructions.
* **Custom URLs:** Custom URLs are back but they changed format. The new routines are using [ssb-custom-uri](https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/ssb-custom-uri).
  * I've also added `ext+patchfox:` as a custom protocol schema. This way, other apps and extensions can launch Patchfox if they want.
* **VoteCounter:** new component to count votes on a message ✨.
* **Post:** 
  * Added `@mentions` to compose window.
  * Added `<VoteCounter>` component to card.
* **Blog:** Added `@mentions` to compose window.
* **Contacts:**
  * Added hyperlink with custom URL to feed id display.
* **SSB:** 
  * Changing all threads to filter private msgs out. It was cute to see them among the other messages with the orange private border but I'm beginning to think this may lead to problems in the future. I'm filtering them out with a pipeline entry to `threads`.
  * Changed keyword to search SSB from omnibox to `ssb?`.
  * Added an overly complicated and confusing `workQueue` to enable self-contained components to schedule their queries and be notified when they are ready. This queue works alongside an ephemeral cache (just for the queue results). it should work. The autocomplete for users is dependent upon the cache. Each time Patchfox fetches the avatar and name for a user, it caches it in localStorage (not the image, jut the blob id and name). So as you navigate SSB using Patchfox, this fills up. The autocomplete is built from this localStorage. So if you're clearing localStorage with some privacy add-on this will be affected. If you're just starting with Patchfox, the best thing you can do is go to your own profile and switch to the "friends" and then the "following" tabs, as those tabs fill with data, all those users will be cached. They are usually the users you're talking with so it will help a lot.

### Probably a bad idea...

So, there is this spec/API called [native messaging](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Native_messaging). It allows WebExtensions to launch native applications on the users machine, but it is not as risky as you may think. There is a double-linked whitelist required for this to work. The application needs to have data in a known location (On UNIX is a _json_ in a user's _home folder_ 😺 , on Windows is a _Registry Entry_ 😿) whitelisting the add-on, and the add-on needs to have an entry in its _manifest_ whitelisting the application, but if those things are in place, then the add-on can launch the app.

This is what #patchfox used to launch `ssb-server` in its first version. That part of the code was eventually refactored out into [Scuttle Shell](https://github.com/ssbc/scuttle-shell), a project that I plan to give some more love soon. 

Now, bear 🐻 with me...

If Oasis adds this _json_ and _registry entry_, then Patchfox can actually launch Oasis. Which means that Patchfox could detect if Oasis is installed, launch it and actually open a browser window into it. Why? I'm not sure, but I suspect that just like people use different webapps in the browser they might want to use different ssb apps in the browser...

PS: This is being refactored back into Patchfox. I just need a way to do a deployable Scuttle Shell that doesn't require the user to install nodejs.

I just learned about [sled](http://sled.rs/) which is an embedded database for Rust. 

> A modern embedded database. Written in Rust, usable on servers and phones from any C-compatible language.
— _Source: [sled | sled-rs.github.io](http://sled.rs/)_

```
let db = sled::open(path)?; // as in fs::open
db.insert(k, v)?;           // as in BTreeMap::insert
db.get(&k)?;                // as in BTreeMap::get
for kv in db.range(k..) {}  // as in BTreeMap::range
db.remove(&k)?;             // as in BTreeMap::remove
drop(db);                   // fsync and close file
```

I suspect it might be useful for SSB-like protocols like bamboo, p2panda, etc. I don't know what #sunrise-choir is using but this appears to have many nice features. It might just be cool enough to be used for quick prototypes to test ideas out without the need to roll your own.

This could be your next Pub or SSB SaaS.

I just read an article called [How knitters got knotted in a purity spiral - UnHerd](https://unherd.com/2020/01/cast-out-how-knitting-fell-into-a-purity-spiral/) that delves into what the author named _purity spirals_ and how it affects communities making themselves implode and rot from the inside.

I've been a witness to this kind of behaviour in many communities I'm a part of, and I am terrified of it. The article helped me make sense of past events which I saw happening but couldn't really reason about for the lack of jargon and methods. The article is full of examples of _community implosions_ but it focus mostly on how the _online knitting community_ imploded. 

> Lately we’ve been witnessing more and more small worlds fall apart under the weight of their vast moral centre of gravity. In the past year, the middle-class, middle-aged, overwhelmingly female knitters of Instagram have descended into internecine conflict over racism allegations.
> — _Source: [How knitters got knotted in a purity spiral - UnHerd](https://unherd.com/2020/01/cast-out-how-knitting-fell-into-a-purity-spiral/)_

The lessons there are applicable to other communities as well. I see this happening with frequency in FOSS communities where it acquires enough gravitas to attract (or give rise to) power-hungry people who will use _holier-than-thou_ which hunts to weed out any dissenting group.

> But while a purity spiral often concerns morality, it is not about morality. It’s about purity — a very different concept. Morality doesn’t need to exist with reference to anything other than itself. Purity, on the other hand, is an inherently relative value — the game is always one of purer-than-thou. 
> — _Source: [How knitters got knotted in a purity spiral - UnHerd](https://unherd.com/2020/01/cast-out-how-knitting-fell-into-a-purity-spiral/)_

Check if the following excerpt from the article doesn't remind you, dear reader, from some past experience:

> It is a social dynamic that plays out across that community — a process of moral outbidding, unchecked, which corrodes the group from within, rewarding those who put themselves at the extremes, and punishing nuance and divergence relentlessly.
> 
> A purity spiral propagates itself through the tipping points of preference falsification: through self-censorship, and through loyalty tests that weed out its detractors long before they can band together. In that sense, once one takes hold, its momentum can be very difficult to halt.
> — _Source: [How knitters got knotted in a purity spiral - UnHerd](https://unherd.com/2020/01/cast-out-how-knitting-fell-into-a-purity-spiral/)_

The author delves deep on this case study to illustrate the article but this content is just a part of a larger [documentary they made for the BBC 4](https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/m000d70h), one of which I'm keen to hear on BBC Sounds. In closing, the author leaves us with a very wise remark:

> The simplest solution is to notice earlier, to notice better, and to call it out as something that has nothing to do with morality, and everything to do with purity — and to say why that’s different.
> 
> If you call its name, it flinches. After all, the best defence against witch-finders is a population that doesn’t believe in witches.
> — _Source: [How knitters got knotted in a purity spiral - UnHerd](https://unherd.com/2020/01/cast-out-how-knitting-fell-into-a-purity-spiral/)_

content.title: Private client-side-only PWAs are hard, but now Apple made them impossible.
content.summary: There is a huge opportunity for the creation of private client-side-only PWAs in the world but developers wanting to build such apps are in for an uphill battle against the status quo and now against Apple as well. I've just read a post by Aral Balkan entitled "Apple just killed Offline Web Apps while purporting to protect your privacy: why that’s A Bad Thing and why you should care" that made me realize that the PWAs I was building here might just be dead for iOS users.

content.text: Forgot to say, I posted this originally in [my blog](https://andregarzia.com/2020/03/private-client-side-only-pwas-are-hard-but-now-apple-made-them-impossible.html).

[@zelf](@3ZeNUiYQZisGC6PLf3R+u2s5avtxLsXC66xuK41e6Zk=.ed25519),

on Apple's original post, they say:

> This blog post covers several enhancements to Intelligent Tracking Prevention (ITP) in iOS and iPadOS 13.4 and Safari 13.1 on macOS to address our latest discoveries in the industry around tracking.
> — _Source: [Full Third-Party Cookie Blocking and More | WebKit](https://webkit.org/blog/10218/full-third-party-cookie-blocking-and-more/)_

So it affects all web applications being used from iOS or Safari on macOS.

[@Johan](@4XHLGF4UDOGiS5oqiDUjN97cKVBExloikIIGMiNjHq0=.ed25519) there is a message type called `blog`, I [wrote about it in the Patchfox help](http://patchfox.org/#/message_types/blog) which is outdated since Patchfox can actually write blog posts and is what I used to do it. I don't know which other clients support writing blog posts, I suspect that Patchbay does but I'm not sure. 

In Patchfox, there is a new blog post menu in the compose menu:

![image.png](&6nw01UoCIFnbDQfjO9b2CumQdyfUp1+4jRNQycYMsZo=.sha256)

The compose window for a blog post has more options than the one used for normal posts. It has the possibilities of thumbnails and summary. They are also not limited to 10k chars like normal posts so they suit long form text well. I want blog to be more popular.

[@emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) the problem is the "death by a thousand paper cuts". Apple does lots of little tricks like this with the web platform, and they get away with it because they prevent everyone from shipping alternate browsers in iOS and iPadOS¹ and everyone loves their Apple device too much. They always have a plausible excuse for what they are doing but if you look closely, it is always pushing developers and users towards their app store and places where they are the gate keepers.

---
1: which should be a case for anti-trust probes and stuff but since it is Apple nothing is happening. Microsoft was hit by Antitrust for just bundling a browser, imagine if they actually prevented others...

😺 Yeah! Thats meeeee!!!! 😺 

It lasted from yesterday early evening up to today at 8:30 AM on top. About 46k unique visitors so far. Phew, thanks Racket I'm using a static generator or the site couldn't cope.

[@Maleficient](@KpPLISvjzw8CkoWOJ3zKXBgPtNDuzUgfyGbJEfbJ4H8=.ed25519) the main issue with this is that the whole _add to home screen_ part is optional, you don't need to have an app to the home screen for it to be a PWA. I use many PWAs on my browser without adding them to the home screen because I like that screen to be clean. I keep them as bookmarks and pinned tabs in my browser. A user doing the same with an Apple browser will have a bad surprise in about one week without use.

Oh, and they added that paragraph you quoted later. When I posted it was not there. They've been editing their original post as can be seen in the [similar post by Aral Balkan](https://ar.al/2020/03/25/apple-just-killed-offline-web-apps-while-purporting-to-protect-your-privacy-why-thats-a-bad-thing-and-why-you-should-care/), which inspired my own post and is linked from there as well.

This suspension will run through June 30, 2020, or the end of the US national emergency, whichever is later.

# URLs might be more complicated than we think

>  I stumbled across the WHATWG URL specification, an evolution over RFC 3986. I found it hard to believe they dropped the formal grammar from the RFC, so I checked the issue queue and found a closed ticket from 2015.
> 
> They replaced the BNF with a series of steps which is several pages long and overly concerned with implementation-specific details.
> 
> It really got to me that such an important and basic part of the web stack is so informally specified. So I wrote an appeal to them to restore a formal grammar in this ticket. I think the reasons are worth being spread more widely, so I'm reproducing it here on my blog.
> — _Source: [An appeal to the WHATWG | More magic](https://www.more-magic.net/posts/an-appeal-to-whatwg-uri-spec.html)_

The spec mentioned is at: https://url.spec.whatwg.org/

[@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519) I love everything about this photo and story <3 <3 <3 Thanks a lot for sharing it, it brought a ton of happiness to my morning here! 

I got *Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell* many years ago, probably 12 or more, when I was still living with my parents. It is quite strange for me because I purchased the book, was quite happy with the purchase, buuuuut I never read it. I think I was reading some other books and wanted to finish them before picking that one and it just fell through the cracks of my TBR list. Recently I tried watching the series on Amazon Prime Video but they don't have subtitles and I have difficulty following the dialog (too fast, too quirky, not very clear in terms of sound). Maybe I'll pick the book again. Are you enjoying it?

The fact that you have your timings pegged down to specific seconds is awesome. I'm tempted to try the same timings here and see the result. I think I'm the only person who doesn't pre-warm the cups or the filter, I don't know, I think I'm ok with the coffee going colder faster.

I'm a fan of Paul Stamets too but I never read any of his books, I just watched his TED talks. I'm happy for something really stupid. More than a week ago, I went with my wife to an Italian deli here to buy groceries. People were prejudiced against buying there because they are Italians and some Londoners are stupid. The guy is awesome and so are his products. So, while we were there he had some large containers of funghi secchi (how do we translate that? Dry mushroom?) and I recognized each one of them! I can at least recognize food fungii rsrsrsrs. It is a small victory for me as they were dry and diced, so they didn't had their usual shape. I wondered when I guessed them correctly if that little joy is how people foraging feel when they find something nice.

Been silent for some days. I'm OK, I'm just tired. Pandemics occupy a huge mental space, it saps a lot of my energy. I'm dealing extremely well with quarantine. My routine has been WFH for 16 years, the only difference at the moment is that I'm the barista and that the coffee is worse now. I don't have those itches of needing to get out of the house, or depression for being locked inside. With books and the internet, I could be OK even if completely alone. But I'm not alone,  I have my wife and my cats here, I have all I love under the same roof. I'm enjoying this more than most people and surely more than her.

Still, I understand that for other people the experience is a lot different. I wish I had tips for WFH and stuff but even though I've been doing that since forever, I'm not very good at it. By "not good", I mean that I work slowly, and will often discount hours of work because I've produced little. It is not uncommon for me to register 3 hours of work for a 5 or sometimes even 6 hours stretch because I was mentally blocked in the middle or simply unfocused. The thing is that the **cult of productivity** is not for me, I like working slowly, I like slow mornings, I type quite slowly as well. You know those hacker types from the movies, who are in VIM and typing so fast that the text is a blur? Well, I'm on the opposite spectrum, I used to have SSH fucking disconnect on me while I was pondering.

So the only tip I can give, is that the secret for WFH and self-isolation is to be good and enjoy your own company. You're all awesome, and being able to sit down by ourselves and enjoy the experience is an acquired skill. It helps to invest into that.

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) Patchfox doesn't do filtering like that except on the _popular view_ which I stole from you ;-)

content.title: The hard part of blogging is not writing, it is sharing your post
content.summary: It is increasingly hard for small content producers to share their own blog posts online as news aggregators and social networks move towards different algorithms that penalize them. In this brief article, I’ll summarize the problem, make an argument that the current solutions are bad, and finally question if this path is actually leading to the web we really want.

content.text:
![blogimport.gif](&JsyvvENaAtdY52H6ykwNDD/jaDTlc4goCuiooKGvGGA=.sha256)

# Import RSS/Atom into SSB

The [blog package](https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/patchfox/tree/master/src/packages/blog) has been converted into a mini app. So not only it provides the card to be used by all the message collection views and the blog compose window but it will now sport some new features that will be accessible from the _launcher_ menu.

Importing a feed is the first feature implemented and is shipping on the next version. It is not a bulk import, I'm not interested in doing that as it would spam SSB. What it does is fetch an RSS/Atom and list all the entries in it for you. From that list you can choose a specific post and click the _compose new blog post using this content_ button and you'll be moved into the _blog compose view_ with the content from the chosen post converted from HTML into Markdown and placed in the appropriated fields.

There are some caveats though:

* You still need to clean up the posts. For example, my blog feed lists the whole post content and not just a snippet, so I must clean the value placed in the _summary_ field myself as we don't want the whole post to be placed there.
* If your post contains images, those are not automatically imported into blobs, you'll need to go image by image yourself replacing the URLs with blogs. It is tedious but it beats the alternative which was writing the whole post again and doing that blob upload anyway.
* I don't have a way to alter the date at the moment, so your new blog post on SSB will be posted with the current date and not the `pubDate` from the feed. I'll fix that in a future release.

Anyway, I'm excited by this as it is the first easy way to syndicate content from our own blogs here. The objective with this feature is not for people to start getting random blog posts from everywhere, but to help people here with their own blogs to also post here. That's why it saves the last imported URL, it hopes you'll be always importing from the same URL.

As someone who has been moving back to blogging, this is a feature I really wanted to ship. I outlined this feature as an issue on Patchfox repo in August 2019. It is finally done.

[@punkmonk](@EaYYQo5nAQRabB9nxAn5i2uiIZ665b90Qk2U/WHNVE8=.ed25519),

Sorry for the delay, I've been a bit away.

I've seen RSS being used for _non-blogging_ stuff, for example [Github has RSS feeds for a lot of the activities that happen in a repo](https://www.ronaldsvilcins.com/2020/03/26/rss-feeds-for-your-github-releases-tags-and-activity/). For example, in the shot below, you can see the data from the Patchfox releases (cue [new RSS importer](%AD18JKTigPcmM4wAKT1BPPRxMJ6Vnr6blgJMM0n1jT8=.sha256)):

![image.png](&Z1hyqqlF2HOzdG6ogRMXNGGWYISyO9Gd/JQsejW22UM=.sha256)

So I think RSS could be used to broadcast updates to a map as well.
[@Gaffen](@zdpL3pz44do6ZK5V9wzuzrponmGlgcVyY7TEYVvkVeE=.ed25519) it takes a while to fetch the blob. Sorry. I'll make a loading spinner on patchfox.

[@Danie](@0Tv5f/opjv/m1ONAKl6S79HWbHdLaCtt/emdXl2MCO0=.ed25519),

The image importer is a bit harder to do as you need to find all images on the post, attempt to attach them, replace the urls with the blob ids. I'm not ready do to that code right now but I will probably next month. The best part of this is the automatic conversion to markdown, that saves a lot of time.

# Release 2020.3.6

* **Background:**
  * Contextual menu changed to support multiline quotes. Cherry picked a nice fix by [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) 
* **Core:**
  * MessageDropdown component: fixed the _Open In New Tab_ item.
* **Docs:**
  * Bug fix in the blog documentation by [@Johan](@4XHLGF4UDOGiS5oqiDUjN97cKVBExloikIIGMiNjHq0=.ed25519) 
* **Profile:**
  * Added a button to create a new post mentioning that user.
* **Blog:**
  * Converted the blog package into a miniapp so that I can add featured that help bloggers our without cluttering the rest of the UI. The first feature added is a _RSS/Atom importer_. You can use this to list the blog posts from a blog and then select a specific post content to be used by the _blog compose view_ to post a new blog post to SSB. You still need to clean up the post and replace any image link with a blob image from SSB, that is not automatic yet. [More info about this feature](%AD18JKTigPcmM4wAKT1BPPRxMJ6Vnr6blgJMM0n1jT8=.sha256).


Your Patchfox should be autoupdating right now.

[Piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519),

oooowwwwwnnnn!!! thanks a ton my friend. You inspire me a lot :-) . I'm a by-product of you all, we're all in a positive feedback loop here <3 <3 <3 <3

[@Kira](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519) IIRC the idea behind getting the mugs and press hot is not only to help it keep warm longer but to avoid the temperature shock of adding almost boiling water to mugs and plungers which might be way colder than the water. 

I think it is more about the temperature range between all those things, so losing a bit of heat is not a problem as everything is warmer than if you didn't do it in the first place.

I had another sony one before this one, it was silver like your pioneer but I barely remember it. I suspect it broke out or was stolen, something must have happened for me to get the blue one. I remember using it to go to my first university, which means I had it 2001 (the year it was launched). I stopped using it probably in 2007 or so. It set dormant in one of those drawers we all have. One day in 2015 or so, I decided to check it out. I picked a double A battery, popped in, and pressed play. It resumed playing from where it was paused eight years later. We don't build technology like that anymore. I kept using it, enjoying the tactile feedback of controls, listening without interruption, and just using it while I was walking around the city.

My unit has been developing some strange mechanical noises. I suspect that the motor in the drive will break soon, probably in the next 20 years, I might buy some more players and stock up.

You can get some marvelous players and even decks there in Japan, have you considered getting back into it?

So, if you guys are into HyperCard, there is a modern version which is GPL (and commercial) and can run (and compile to) windows, mac and linux. I've been working with it for 20 years, I used to even work for the company that makes it up to the begining of this year.

You can fetch the GPL version from https://livecode.org

I've posted an example comparing them at [LiveCode is a modern day HyperCard](http://andregarzia.com/2019/07/livecode-is-a-modern-day-hypercard.html). Up to version 4.x of LiveCode we could actually import HyperCard stacks. I don't think the current version can as the file systems changed too much (macOS used to have something called resource forks and used it a lot, it doesn't have it anymore).

This is what LiveCode looks like:

![image.png](&sybYq/Zf5Z1KP32zFF+1xG5+uc9QsOCJm8P4bwg5d4o=.sha256)

So, I know you're pumped for HyperCard but LiveCode language is the same, and LC works directly on your machine and provides modern features. Check out that post, it contains the recreation of a HyperCard sample step by step, and a link to the original blog post that used HyperCard.
Also, AMA, I've been programming with XTalk languages since forever.

> For over two decades, Mozilla has worked to build the internet into a global public resource that is open and accessible to all. As the internet has grown, it has brought wonder and utility to our lives, connecting people in times of joy and crisis like the one being faced today.
> 
> But that growth hasn’t come without challenges. In order for the internet and Mozilla to well serve people into the future, we need to keep innovating and making improvements that put the interests of people back at the center of online life.
> 
> To help achieve this, Mozilla is launching the Fix-the-Internet Spring MVP Lab and inviting coders, creators and technologists from around the world to join us in developing the distributed Web 3.0.
> 
> “The health of the internet and online life is why we exist, and this is a first step toward ensuring that Mozilla and the web are here to benefit society for generations to come,” said Mozilla Co-Founder and Interim CEO Mitchell Baker.
> 
> Mozilla’s Fix-the-Internet Spring MVP Lab is a day one, start from scratch program to build and test new products quickly. By energizing a community of creators who bring a hacker’s approach to vibrant experimentation, Mozilla aims to help find sustainable solutions and startup ideas around several key themes designed to fix the internet:
> 
>* Collaboration & Society: particularly in view of the current global crisis: (i) Foster better collaboration online, (ii) Grassroots collaboration around issues & emergencies, (iii) Local & neighborhood support networks, (iv) Supporting small businesses, (v) Social money-pooling for issues, people & businesses.
>* Decentralized Web: build a new, decentralized architecture for the internet from infrastructure, communications, media & money, using the blockchain and peer-to-peer technologies.
>* Messaging & Social Networking: can we build a new way to communicate online that favors privacy, people, and users’ interests? What needs to evolve?
>* Misinformation & Content: ideas for services that help us get beyond polarization, filter bubbles and fake news.
>* Surveillance Capitalism: whether it’s big tech or governments, everyone’s collecting your data. How do we put the user back in control of their data?
>* Artificial Intelligence that works to benefit communities and citizens.
> 
> Participants in the Fix-the-Internet Spring MVP Lab will:
> 
>* Work in teams of two-to-four people
>* Have access to mentorship through virtual weekly collaboration with product and engineering professionals
>* Receive a $2500 stipend per participant. If you are applying as a team, each team member will receive $2500.
>* Be eligible for cash prizes: $25k (1st), $10K (2nd) and $5K (3rd)
>* Benefit from Mozilla’s promotion of finished projects to gain users and awareness
>* Retain ownership of their projects and intellectual property
> 
> Visit http://www.mozilla.org/builders for additional details and information on how to apply by the April 6, 2020 deadline.
>
> — _Source: [We’re Fixing the Internet. Join Us. - The Mozilla Blog](https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2020/03/30/were-fixing-the-internet-join-us/)_

# Temperature Check

How are your applications going? What are your thoughts about the whole process? 

## 🦄🦄🦄🦄🦄 THE DEADLINE IS TODAY AT 11:59PM ET 🙀🙀🙀🙀🙀

Recently I've posted about Mozilla's [let's fix-the-internet lab](%O0Q3j6TujpbMVMK+OwEJcPdswJhfS8VV2K546nu/w04=.sha256) and invited you all to apply. I've kept silent about my application — not have I commented on any mention about teaming — this is because I had to put my mind in order about what I wanted to do.

What I want to do at the moment with SSB is Patchfox. I still have other projects going which I'm happy to work with but if I'm being honest, my 💖 is in Patchfox at the moment and that is what I'd like to have funding for. There many cool stuff happening with that client and almost no funding going on.

Still, I haven't invited anyone to my team. The thing is, I enjoy working alone. I love exchanging code, ideas, collaborating on other projects, but for me to be myself, I need to have solo projects. That is one of the main reasons I don't ask for contributors for the Patchfox code, being alone in that project allows me to pivot it in crazy directions without pressure. 

Patchfox is my artist medium, there is art that is collaborative, and there is art that is made by a single person, both remain artful. Every couple months, I throw everything away and restart. I implement crazy features, and months later I remove them, then I add them back again later with a better implementation. Patchfox is an ongoing experiment and laboratory.

That doesn't mean that I don't see value in working together or collaboration. I'm more than happy with it and love doing it. But the way the world is at the moment occupies a lot of space in my mind, and the space that is free doesn't want to be part of a team.

And that is why I'm not applying to that program. I read their FAQ more closely today and noticed that even though they accept solo participants, they require that those participants form a team to continue in the program, and  I simply don't want to be on a team right now.

**I'm still cheering for you all and your projects though. 💖💜💛💚💙** It would be great if they'd accept multiple SSB projects on that program. TBH I feel that SSB is the best technology and community to pull out those requirements and wishes expressed by the fix-the-internet organizing team.

---

Because of that, this will be another funding opportunity that I can't participate in. I live in a very expensive city and funding is important to enable me to keep doing what I actually enjoy doing, which is a kick-ass crazy webextension that surprises you all with neat features and crazy stuff every couple releases. So, **if you're in a good situation regarding your finances and value Patchfox, I'd humbly ask you to consider 💰 backing 💰 the [Patchfox Open Collective](https://opencollective.com/patchfox), that is the best way to help empower my development at the moment.**
