emojis have no real semantic value. People perceive them differently. If I react to a text with 🍇 what do I mean? The best thing is just to show the emoji I think, still I'd rather keep this ecosystem without ways to react negatively about something.

In Patchfox, likes are hearts, there is no way to use something else. In most clients, likes are something good. Manyverse has an emoji pickup, which reminds me of reactions in popular chat apps and github. I really like that but I think the selection should be restricted to positive things, offer 10 different emoji, thats ok. If someone really want to be negative about something I said, they'd better write a message explaining anyway. Reacting with 💩 is just 💩

There is no modulation. Most apps just mean "like", they refer to it by other names but it always boils down to "positive feedback". The value from `value` in the vote is just so that you're able to fetch the last one and figure out if the user is removing a vote.

> @SoapDog (SPX) why do you say that?
> If I am understanding the principle of SSB protocol, anyone can define his own data structure…
> You just have to make a client for write/read understanding feed…

I'm saying that because the value is a boolean. The emoji has no significance and the boolean can only be set to true. There is no dislike or spectrum of how much you like something, so there is no way to modulate.

> It is obvious that most behaviours are implemented just as we are used to (like value interpretation).
>
>But using any other well known normalized data like emoji short code is still possible, and will enhance the signification of our “vote”.

You should never enhance the semantic value of something with emojis, emojis are not even a proper standard and they vary from platform to platform. I have access to some emojis on Windows that are unique to windows like for example 🐱‍👤 which for me render as a single emoji (a ninjacat, but for you might render as two emojis a ninja and a cat).

> For example, we have used “vote” to send #g1 #libremoney on “likes” we make between us.

Votes are not meant to be used like that.

> Most people in SSB community enjoyed our enhancement, as it is a MoneyFIX protocol as SSB is for Social, few dislike it…

I'm on a different bubble, I don't see that happening, so far I've seen only one message and it was from [@elavoie](@IgYpd+tCtXnlE2tYX/8rR2AGt+P8svC98WH3MdYAa8Y=.ed25519) asking that maybe you change how you're doing that. I find those messages spammy and don't like blockchain incentives here to be honest. This is only my personal opinion as I dislike blockchains and cryptocurrencies. I think that if you want to do that through SSB, you should do new messages and not overload the ones we're already using. Or at least use it from a profile that is not your own personal profile so that people can block and still hear from you (the person, not the bot)

> We start thinking best will be to enhance “vote” behaviour with “sending money_with_wings” 💸 as expression… Then it won’t bother patchwork or other clients, they just don’t treat them…

I'd advise against trying to enhance vote. Vote works well the way it is. Please instead of overloading a message with new meanings, a message that is already implemented everywhere, do something new. There is a reason blog posts were done as `blog` and not `post`.

[@Johan](@4XHLGF4UDOGiS5oqiDUjN97cKVBExloikIIGMiNjHq0=.ed25519),

I haven't done the hack. There are some features I consider interesting there but I enjoy this device too much, it has been with me since it's release date. I might buy another one to play with it.

What I do is to record my MDs is:

* Create playlists on spotify.
* Play albums I like on Bandcamp.
* I follow some channels and subreddits about Japanese Jazz, those are usually full albums as Youtube videos.

In any case, I press play and record using analog audio. The MD is the only music device I brought with me when I moved to the UK. All the others I had through the years — iPods, Disc Players, Hi Fi sets — all those I've kept in Brazil.

[@fred@ONELOVE](@9BbJwPDjcyIqrOUPNn0nJZBduWdIrpMk3Cjz5MP361s=.ed25519),

> But ScuttleButt is a blockchain!

There is no mining, or financial incentive, or proof of work in SSB. Blockchain in that message is supposed to mean more than just the data structure. And you've missed my point, I don't like cryptocurrencies.

I understand and appreciate what you and the others are doing with mutuals and libremoney, but, as I mentioned before, I don't like cryptocurrencies and that is not only releated to the technology, which I consider wasteful, or the kind of groups that tend to gravitate around them, which I find boring. 

I find it really good that you and your team are looking for low cost solutions and better methods and ecosystem. 

> But money giving is like voting…
> It is unfair when you are not able to produce it in the same amount of the others… And makes donations look like alms
>
>But when you are becoming a Smith and forge same part of money everyday as all other humans accepting it, your relation only based on rewards. Then salary exists and magic can happen 🧙‍♀

No, money giving is not at all like voting. Voting is _a low effort smile in SSB_, you read something smile and click. Your smile might be because it is fun, or because it is important, or because you're empathizing. It is in the end about cultivating relationships.

Money, whatever the kind, is about something else. Also _salary exists and magic can happen_, rsrsrs, we're in completely different bubbles, where I come from, we're want to get away from salaries. 

Magic happens in post-scarcity where things like money and salary don't make any sense. Any form of token incentive, reputation market, ledgers, all this is against the system I want to see built. Yes, I need money because we live in a society where I can't pay rent with a hug, a coffee and a good story, but if I will pour my efforts into something, it surely will not be cryptocurrencies. 

What I like most about this place is the lack of financial incentives around it. I'll keep this as a garden as it is my personal choice not to be a part of cryptocurrency communities. 

As there is some bubble here which I can't see who is really into this stuff. I'd ask you please to consider doing specific profiles and messages for it, so that people who are not interested can filter and block away.

> We are legion.

I know you mean this as a joke and cute remark, but stop to think about this phrase and the contexts of it. This phrase has never been said by entities with good intentions. # Cross-platform app development
## Developing a blogging client

Recently I’ve read this [post about the sad state of cross platform GUI frameworks](https://blog.royalsloth.eu/posts/sad-state-of-cross-platform-gui-frameworks/) and was quite impressed by how much I agree with it and how much I think we should focus more on desktop apps instead of SaaS and mobile stuff. This post is not an attempt to contradict the post mentioned above but another datapoint for those wanting to learn more about cross-platform development tools. In it I’ll talk about a real world application I’ve built for my own personal use to help me blog more.

This post contains lots of margin notes and images. Since it is built with [scribble](https://docs.racket-lang.org/scribble/index.html) it generates HTML that is hard for my own RSS importer to work with. So, I'm just going to post a link to it if you want to know more.

https://andregarzia.com/2020/04/cross-platform-development-with-livecode.html

One thing that we used to use (and abuse) a lot in LiveCode back in the day was stuff such as:

```

```

Which would fetch the stack from remote and load it. So lots of our apps were thin clients that loaded stuff on demand from servers. Much like a webbrowser loading web pages, but better.

I'm launching **Project Moon Hermit** which is something that I [mentioned a couple](%ghYxzIe1atwTudROwjibfMnlDLWQuUI+KyAfNXbl/AQ=.sha256) [times in the past](%nbCypNv4VBvSyFCFjLCSez2H0xHf3YLuT1/CWhhX2b4=.sha256) but never really tried out. Well, yesterday, I decided to test the idea out instead of doing actual work and much to my surprise, it started working._

# What is project moon hermit?

It is a new SSB client of sorts. It is not exactly a client but a version of Lua 5.3 that contains an embedded SSB client inside it. It was built by picking #sbotc by [@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519) and grafting #lua into it.

![Annotation 2020-04-17 150704.png](&pcrl7tmOThNn5ba7PDdwYlcQ8nsSUS4xMz+/+mLLN2c=.sha256)
_Sample script running._

The script that generated the output above is:

```lua
print("hello from " .. _VERSION)

local whoami, err = ssb:whoami()

if (not err) then
    print(string.format("you are %s", whoami.id))
else
    print(string.format("some error happened?! %s", err))
end

local result, err = ssb:latestSequence(whoami.id)

if (not err) then
    print(string.format("latest sequence is %d", result))
else
    print(string.format("some error happened?! %s", err))
end
```

At the moment, **I consider this project a proof-of-concept**. It is not ready for general use as I've implemented only `muxrpc_read_async` calls. There are other paths inside `sbotc.c` that I need to change besides hooking the error handling back into Lua.

Be aware that this is not a library, it is a full interpreter. It executed your lua script after connecting to the SSB Server.

# Next steps

* Refactor `muxrpc_read_source`, `muxrpc_write_blob_add`, `muxrpc_write_sink`, and `muxrpc_duplex` to work with Lua.
* Refactor the error handling to feed back into Lua stack.
* Refactor the args in the command line into something that makes more sense for this project.

# Source code
I've pushed what I'm working on to [github](https://github.com/soapdog/project-moon-hermit).

# How it works?

I basically changed `main()` in `sbotc.c` a lot to extract the parts that called into `muxrpc` into a separate function that I expose to the Lua environment via the [Lua C API](https://www.lua.org/manual/5.3/manual.html#4).

Lua is mostly a toolkit instead of a language. You're supposed to customize it and tailor it to your needs. This project wants to create a scripting language for SSB.

## Exposing muxrpc to Lua

```
// initialize SSB library
lua_pushcfunction(L, luamux);
lua_setglobal(L, "muxrpc");
```

Yep, that is it. There is a `luamux()` function in the C source code, we add it to Lua and expose it as a global called `muxrpc` with just two lines.

## Making it friendlier

The `moonhermit` interpreter makes use of some Lua files (which will eventually be bundled inside the C source code) to create a friendlier API on top of the exposed `muxrpc()` function. It loads a file called `prelude.lua` before running your script. That file makes use of `json.lua` so it can convert to and from Lua tables into JSON.  Lua has [metatables and metamethods](https://www.lua.org/manual/5.3/manual.html#2.4). You can think of them as JS prototypes and function overloading.

The `prelude.lua` assembles an empty table (think JS object) called `ssb`. It attaches a metatable to it (think JS prototype). This metatable has an `__index` key which is set to a function. This means that accessing a non existant property on this table will cause `__index` to be called. This returns a new function, much like JS closures being used as function factories. This new function is a wrapped call to `muxrpc`. Those two lines in the sample:

```
local whoami, err = ssb:whoami()
...
local result, err = ssb:latestSequence(whoami.id)
```

Are actually using Lua syntatic sugar — `table:method("a")` becomes `method(table, "a")` — that when called, returns a new function that is immediately invoked.

The actual `__index` entry in the metatable is:

```lua
__index = function(self, k)
    return function(s, ...)
        local res, err = false
        
        local ars = table.pack(...)
        
        if (#ars == 0) then
            ars = "[]"
        else
            ars = json.stringify({ars[1]})
        end 

        local status, retval = pcall(muxrpc, k, ars)

        if (status) then
            res = json.parse(retval)
            err = false
        else 
            res = false
            err = retval
        end 

        return res, err
    end 
end
```

In the end it is a clever way to create a proxy object. I never implemented `whoami` or `latestsequence` in Lua or C. Calling it like `ssb:whoami()` is transformed into `pcall(muxrpc, "whoami", "[]")` which is a _lua protected call_ so that even if it errors out in the C code, we're safe.

Also, you might have noticed that Lua has support for returning multiple values. That is used to return a result and an error at the same time, like SSB callbacks do.

Phew, I've written so much. It is because I'm excited about all of this. It is early days but I can see this growing into a very good way of creating simple SSB tools and scripts.

At the moment this has only been tested in Linux. It should work on a Mac too but you might need to tweak the Makefile. It doesn't work on Windows because a lot of the C code relies on GNU stuff.

---

This wouldn't be possible without all the amazing work by [@cel-desktop](@lOUVT+Phkvai9a/cCS/RKo+S9hnPAQdVixms/7ldpPA=.ed25519). 💖

_PS: My C skills are garbage..._

In my opinion, having Rust or Zig implementations of ssb server is very important not only due to safety and performance reasons but due to how cross-platform those languages are. > The content warning spec is unclear about the scope of the warning (thread vs message). If one comment in a thread has a warning should the whole thread also have a warning?

I believe that leads to two problems/challenges: 

* **UI Challenge:** many clients show threads or partial threads in the common timelines such as public, mentions, extended network. If CW would cascade from whatever message has it, will all the messages in the thread be rendered with it leading to a stair or stack of CWs? That would be ugly. Should all the messages in the thread be hidden, and only rendered after CW is clicked? What if the CW is not root?
* **Perf problem:** Cascading CWs might pose a problem for performance during pull stream operations because instead of simply fetching a message, you'll need to go back to its root and traverse from there looking to see if any message in the chain (or future tangle) contains a CW.

Because of those two issues. I'd recommend against it.

lol, I can see the English betting on betting on auctions...

So, while I was into getting old devices (mostly newton, magic cap, that kind of devices) in the past, I also had problems with these races and price creep. I've found an app more than 10 years ago that is fantastic for Ebay auctions, it is called [jbidwatcher](https://www.jbidwatcher.com/), I don't know if it still works, I haven't used it in probably ~10 years.

It is a very powerful app and I only used its basic sniping feature. That allowed me to enter an auction number, the bid I want to make and how many seconds before the closing of the auction should trigger the bid. So you could set it to bid 300 EUR in a MZ-RH1 40 seconds before the end of the auction giving no time for the other bidders to bid again. I won many auctions thanks to that software.

Another cool feature I remember is that you could add many auctions to it and then configure it to not bid on an auction if you won another auction previously. So you could add a bunch of auctions for a given item and the first one you won would cancel the others from triggering.

Oh, that software was scriptable, you could really go crazy as in creating snipping configurations for separate items and then adding a bid for and auction that was a bundle of the items and canceling the others if you got the bundle. Or to monitor ebay looking for an item and then bid on it. That kind of stuff.

Getting wordpress to survive this kind of traffic is a bit hard isn't it? You might want to check out caching plugins or placing a cdn, ddos protection such as cloudflare in front of it. Personaly, I don't like surrendering my front to those services but it might be a viable cheap way to make your setup more robust.

You might want to experiment with SSGs or even GravCMS (if you must have a cool UI). My website is a moderately priced vps on Linode. It has never crashed due to HN, Slashdot or similar firehose being pointed at it because it is a static site. I'm using good old Apache to serve normal files, and it works. During the last popular post, I had about 70k visitors in a day (which is pretty big for me) and the server was fine.

## implemented `source` muxrpc calls, new debug option, new samples

I like slow mornings. They are what keeps me sane and allow me to wander through the internet, books and stupid personal project without gilt. This morning I decided to work a bit on project moon hermit.

### new debug option

I've added a new command line option for outputting debug info — it is `-d` — running the `test1.lua` sample without it:

```
soapdog@Cleo ~/p/pmh> ./moonhermit -s 172.19.96.1 test1.lua
hello from Lua 5.3
you are @0xkjAty6RSr5uhbAvi0rbVR2g9Bz+89qiKth48ECQBE=.ed25519
latest sequence is 1623
soapdog@Cleo ~/p/pmh>
```

With the `-d` option set:


It displays a debug section for each muxrpc call detailing the method, the processed arguments and the type. This is useful for me while implementing the project itself.

### muxrpc `source` calls.

I've half-patched the pathway that handles `source` calls, as in, the happy path works but the error handling is not yet hooked into `lua_error` calls. The return value of a source call is a Lua table with the values.

```lua
local msgs, err = ssb:createHistoryStream({
    id = "@0xkjAty6RSr5uhbAvi0rbVR2g9Bz+89qiKth48ECQBE=.ed25519",
    limit = 50000
})
``` 

The `msgs` table will contain the first 50.000 messages for the `@0xkjAty6RSr5uhbAvi0rbVR2g9Bz+89qiKth48ECQBE=.ed25519` feed.

### New samples

I'm adding more sample files named `test*.lua` to play with the stuff I'm implementing. The `test3.lua` picks the first 50.000 messages from this feed, filters for `contact` messages, displays and count them.

![test3.lua running](&c3LMCS2gh4bK95/C55bkEEp7rWODHU+RPgFdtIIXUWs=.sha256)
_`test3.lua` running on WSL2 connecting to patchwork on windows._

It took about a second to run through all those messages. It is speedy enough for my usage at the moment. Just be aware that the json encoding and decoding is being done by `prelude.lua` in pure Lua code and that is quite slow. Once this project matures I plan to switch to something like `lua-cjson` which a native C module.

Source for `test3.lua`:

```lua
local pprint = require("pprint")

function lookup(t, ...)
    for _, k in ipairs{...} do
        t = t[k]
        if not t then
            return nil
        end
    end
    return t
end

function justContacts(m)
    return lookup(m, "value", "content", "type") == "contact"
end

function displayContactMsg(m)
    local user = m.value.author
    local target = m.value.content.contact 
    local action = m.value.content.following and "followed" or "unfollowed"
    print(string.format("%s %s %s", user, action, target))
end

local msgs, err = ssb:createHistoryStream({
    id = "@0xkjAty6RSr5uhbAvi0rbVR2g9Bz+89qiKth48ECQBE=.ed25519",
    limit = 50000
})

if (not err) then
    stream(msgs).filter(justContacts).foreach(displayContactMsg)
    local contactMsgs = stream(msgs).filter(justContacts).toarray()
    print(string.format("%d contact msgs", #contactMsgs ))
else
    print(err)
end
```

It is all quite raw. There are no convenience methods to help with higher-level code buuuut it is working.

### How it works

Lua C API is stack based. When your exported function is called by Lua code, Lua will pass a stack to the C function with the arguments of the call in it. The C code will manipulate this stack and return an integer. The value of this integer is how many elements Lua should pop from the stack and return as results from your C function.

The way it works is that in `luamux` — which is the function that is exported from C to Lua as `muxrpc` — there is a switch on the `type` of rpc call being made. 

If it is an `async` call, which generates a single result, there is a `bs_read_into_lua()` function that uses `lua_pushstring()` to push the value from the box stream into the Lua stack. 

If it is a `source` call, then we don't know in advance how many elements we'll read, so we push an empty Lua table into the stack before executing the muxrpc call. Lua tables are both object and vectors/arrays, it just depends on the indexes used. Instead of using `bs_read_into_lua()`, this uses `bs_accumulate_into_lua()` which check if the last element in the stack is a table (it should be) and it it is, then it pushes a value into the stack, and then set that value as the next element in the table (which causes the value to pop and the table to be the last element again). When this is called in a loop, the effect is similar to `table.insert(msg)`.

```
static int bs_accumulate_into_lua(lua_State *L, struct boxs *bs, size_t len) {
	char buf[len];
	int rc;
	rc = bs_read(bs, buf, len);
	luaL_checktype(L, -1, LUA_TTABLE); // top of the stack is a table?
	size_t tlen = lua_rawlen(L, -1); // how many elements in table.
	lua_pushstring(L, buf);
	lua_rawseti(L, -2, tlen+1);
	return 0;
}
```

I hope to be able to reuse that function for the other types of muxrpc call.

# What are your thoughts about double encryption?

I have some ideas for some very private messages. If I do them the normal way, I'd just publish them as private messages and be happy but if the users key ever leak then all those messages become readable.

Because of that I've been toying (and in mentally toying) with the idea of allowing the user to double encrypt the content using some password. So the message would be first encrypted with this password which is never shared, and then published as a private message. If the user key leaks, there is still the need of breaking that password.

That and its beefier cousin, which is double encryption but using another pk crypto gizmo, might just be _security through added friction_ but if we're about to share some quite private stuff, it might be good to think about this stuff.

---

If you need more context: I'm thinking about how to transport address book data into SSB. This is very sensitive information (even though every user of whatapp/fb/instagram/telegram already shared this info with our corporate overlords).

I've been working on #ssb-backup-tool since yesterday. Implementing the _restore identity happy path_. You couldn't guess how many times I've broken this the indexes on this feed already. The custom indexes in Patchwork are always rebuilt when I move back to it.

One thing that is adding a lot of unnecessary friction is that _requiring_ some SSB modules will add a new `~/.ssb/secret` if there is not one in place. This means that I need to replace files before requiring the module, which means I can't place my requires on top of the file and since the `ssb-config` was used before replacing files to figure out where the files should go, it becomes a bit of a race condition. You might say: _"just overwrite the secret if you're restoring."_, well you can't because the file is in use by the module so trying to overwrite it causes an `EPERM` error.

> Submission Deadline: May 30, 2020 
> 
> What do cat videos, facial recognition and porn all have in common? You can find them at the first annual Small File Media Festival! 
> 
> The coronavirus pandemic is showing us how dependent people are on streaming media. Streaming media currently is responsible for over 1% of our global carbon footprint and rising fast.

> Use your artistic voice to contribute to climate change action and cool down the planet. We’re going to make HD, 4K, and 5G look unnecessary, unsexy, and so last decade. ## Not a client, but a libary

Wrap #sbotc into a reusable library. Creating bindings for a ton of languages. Let people be happy and develop on their own languages.

## The SSB equivalent of CEF.

By that I don't mean bring your own web engine, we already have electron, I mean a packed folder structure that provides the necessary bits for running a SSB node. Think of it as a portable go-ssb and patchql. Binaries are provided, you can just bundle that folder with your client and start the server. All your client needs to do is GraphQL. This bundle doesn't need to contain any UI. The client using it should be responsible for starting and stopping the processes.

I think that this approach must be done regardless of what I'm interested in doing. Whoever knows enough about those projects to just assemble a release of them combined should receive a grant/funds to do so.

Still, once a trauma happens, in Brazil you're screwed, here in the UK a magical robot ambulance arrives in less than 15 minutes and they do their best to save you (aka the prevention vs reaction dilema). I'm happy to have the NHS available to me. I don't think I'd live in a country without something like the NHS or SUS (If I could choose).

---

I have strong opinions about this.

[@Léo [desktop]](@V9CfLhJl1/3Dw6bx5Y9Cgz2hbsYG9UmHCfpQlAhpPcM=.ed25519) it was not serial blocking, I went to the profile to look, I didn't liked what I saw. I find that kind of discourse on the linked thread dangerous and I don't want to spread it further and that is why I blocked.

[@Léo [desktop]](@V9CfLhJl1/3Dw6bx5Y9Cgz2hbsYG9UmHCfpQlAhpPcM=.ed25519) I normally do the ignore. There is a bunch of people I've ignored that no one knows and like you said, that is the best approach. Still, I have very strong opinions about that subject and decided to publicly block in that case because I'm taking a stance. 

In the past, I've been critical of such approaches as well, but talking to [@KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519) I came to realize that we don't have many moderation tools here. I can filter the shit out of SSB with patchfox but that doesn't affect replication. Ignoring doesn't signal anything by design. Sometimes, we want to signal, that is something wise that I learned from that convo.

The good of SSB is that I can't prevent anyone from being here, I can only select what I do and how I react. I'm usually quite OK with discussing and doing back and forths on subjects that I have opinions that are different than other people, we both had heated conversations before (which I'm still ashamed about, I'm sooo sorry), but I didn't block, or ignore because even though we disagreed, I could see where you were coming from and empathize. I like seeing your posts.

This anti-vaxx thing is a different situation. That mindset is dangerous. It kills people where I come from.

[@sam_uk](@s5nSo+j0D+tTklVi1kZqDsgEV0mLtums7UgyGAClD/0=.ed25519) something deeply disturbing is how Brazilians are adopting the worst stupid things that come out of the U.S. things like creationism, anti-vaxx, and worse are all being adopted _en masse_ there. It is a fucking nightmare. Brazil is even more polarized than the U.S. so any attempt of denouncing that shit is shot down with cries of _communism!_ it is a very challenging place.

[@Léo [desktop]](@V9CfLhJl1/3Dw6bx5Y9Cgz2hbsYG9UmHCfpQlAhpPcM=.ed25519),

Much like what [@Daan](@MRiJ+CvDnD9ZjqunY1oy6tsk0IdbMDC4Q3tTC8riS3s=.ed25519) said, I don't have the energy or the will to engage with anti-vaxxers, nor am I required to do so. Sharing a link to an anti-vaxxer petition full of conspiracy theory bullshit without any comment is for me endorsing it. When I'm against something and I share it, I comment on it saying I'm against it and that I'm sharing it for XYZ reason. If I share something without comment, one can only infer that I'm supportive of that.

Be aware that if Fred had shared that and commented against it, I wouldn't have blocked. I'm blocking because it feels like an endorsement and endorsing such bullshit is offensive to me. The reason why anti-vaxxers are wrecking Brazil and the U.S. is because those against it are not vocal enough. There are times, people need to make a stand. I'll make a stand against anti-vaxxers.

> Especially here, Fred may not even be anti-vaxx or not realize this petition was anti-vaxx but rather simply against The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

The amount of bullshit in that petition goes beyond being simply against that foundation. Also sharing things silently is not a way for making people know what your perceptions are.

>  They tend to genuinely give a shit about the health of the citizens as far as I can tell.

Unfortunately, that phrase needs to be in the past tense now as the current fascist-in-presidency is working really hard to undo all the good that all the previous governments had done (both the left and the right previous governments). Who knows if we'll still have all those good track records a year from now.

Let me just say that during the previous left governments, it was the first ever time that Brazil manage to get its shit together long enough to be able to be removed from the U.N. hunger map. That means that for the first time in its history, people were not dyeing from starvation. That is a huge achievement for a country with the economic gap and lack of infrastructure that Brazil has. Now, with the fascist president, we're back in the hunger map.

Telling you this because the evangelical coallition that he represents (aka BBB faction -- cows, bible, bullets -- rich landowners) has a huge intersection with anti-vaxx movement and pro-dicatorship movement. Brazil is travelling back in time towards its dark ages.

> See what kind of effect that has?

People have the right to block people who they think are spreading bullshit. If it is dangerous bullshit, then they have the right to do it publicly and signal it. 

Of course what is bullshit and what is dangerous varies from people to people. Other people might not agree with me and the other five people. They are free to keep listening, while I'm free to do the opposite.

[@Léo [desktop]](@V9CfLhJl1/3Dw6bx5Y9Cgz2hbsYG9UmHCfpQlAhpPcM=.ed25519) then it is up to them to clarify isn't it?

They will see this happening. Maybe they are pro-vaccine, who knows. For now, I feel safer blocking. 

Be aware that I blocked for reasons beyond simply being anti-vaxxer. I mentioned in a post that I will keep talking to anti-vaxx people who I'm already friends with. This is not blocking for pride or anything. This is blocking because I find conspiracy theories harmful to mankind and I will block people who I've got no relationship that are spreading such stuff. It is my hard drive, it is my choice to decide who I carry with me.

[@Léo [desktop]](@V9CfLhJl1/3Dw6bx5Y9Cgz2hbsYG9UmHCfpQlAhpPcM=.ed25519),

He shared a petition that is accusing UNICEF and WHO of sterilizing Kenyan Children. Yes, before blocking I went to read the petition, and the youtube video. And yes, I deal with anti-vaxx people daily, and they share the same content.

You don't share a petition claiming that the fucking U.N. is sterilizing people without any comment if you're against it or just want to spur conversation.

I personally knew people who worked on UNICEF in the past. I've been a grantee of a large philanthropic foundation working with kids and teenagers for two years, it was my main job at the time. Anti-vaxx people were fucking dangerous to those communities. Having to go there and explain that it is bullshit, that it is fearmongering. I've been there and in some sense, I still am.

Look at what've been shared. A petition accusing WHO, UNICEF, Melinda & Gates foundation, of sterilizing children and other unmentioned acts. I don't need to listen to people who propagate this rhetoric and this FUD. 

Entering this scuttleverse and the first two posts are FUD and a batshit crazy petition, both without any other comment. For all I know this is a bot spreading misinformation, I don't care. That petition is shit.

[@Léo [desktop]](@V9CfLhJl1/3Dw6bx5Y9Cgz2hbsYG9UmHCfpQlAhpPcM=.ed25519),

Thats probably where we disagree. I think you're free to act upon seeing content that is offensive to you. That content is very offensive to me and that is why I blocked. There is no reason at all for me to expect anything reasonable from someone who shares a bullshit petition like that without any comment. That profile has never commented on anything as far I can tell. That is the only content they've posted, those two entries. Sorry, I don't want that.

It may be the case that that person enters online soon, see all this mess, and tells us that the profile is some experimental bot that made mistakes sharing stuff automatically and that it was all miscommunication. Who knows, I'm going to wait and see. Depending on what I see, I might unblock.

[@the Queen of England](@YND2Cb9uk3ZdFyzXpaXDH5HZ9udu+qjg4MhNcynK2RE=.ed25519),

> jesus, cows, bibles and bullets, what a mix.

Every time I wake up in the UK, I feel blessed by having an ocean between me and those crazy fucktards.

[@Léo [desktop]](@V9CfLhJl1/3Dw6bx5Y9Cgz2hbsYG9UmHCfpQlAhpPcM=.ed25519) but I contain multitudes inside me. As in I have other profiles, at least four others. I will see it, but not from this machine.

I block in increasing steps. As you said, I don't do it often and prefer to do silent blocks. It is very hard for me to publicly block someone. I had fights here and didn't block people. I often block first on my main machine, but not on the others unless it is something so horrible that requires me to block everywhere at once. Depending on how it goes, I might unblock or if I decide I don't want it, go and block on the other profiles as well.

[@cel-desktop](@lOUVT+Phkvai9a/cCS/RKo+S9hnPAQdVixms/7ldpPA=.ed25519) wxWidgets has an awesome editor component/system called scintilla. It is used by many native FOSS editors. That source you found is the lexer to colorize and stylize markdown text being edited inside a scintilla editor.

I've found people using some other cpp-markdown library to convert it to HTML and then displaying it in wxHtmlWindow. I don't want to use that because it appears to take over the whole window. I'm looking for something lighter. I'm sure there is a way, even if it needs to be built from scratch.

The hardest part for at the moment is that to be effective, I need to rework that forked sbotc into a cross-platform source that can be compiled on Windows. Unfortunately, I know next to nothing about windows C programming, but I think it is worth a try. I'll also investigate if something like mingw might just work.

If I manage to work this out, I'll let you know, maybe the changes are simple and can be upstreamed so that it compiles in UNIX and Windows.

Attempting to compile multiple versions of [wxWidgets](https://www.wxwidgets.org/) for windows again. I posted about it [in the past](http://andregarzia.com/2019/12/wxwidgets-works-under-windows-on-arm.html), and it is not that hard.

My objective today is to build:

* Static and shared libs for win32 X86
* Static and shared libs for win32 ARM64

That combination should enable me to run it in all Windows machines. UNIX-like machines have no problem building this stuff.

[@Daan](@MRiJ+CvDnD9ZjqunY1oy6tsk0IdbMDC4Q3tTC8riS3s=.ed25519) that is how I've been building the #project-moon-hermit stuff but I don't want to do it this way because I want to do a GUI client and WSL is not for GUI apps. Yes, you can run your own X Server on Windows, then launch WSL and export `DISPLAY` by hand, and launch graphical apps, but that is a hack and impractical to distribute apps.

In theory, I think I could simply compile using mingw, but that would lock me to x86 and amd64 only and I really want arm64, which means I need to use MSVC.

![image.png](&mfGZrWJheOm0LiAI/heWags0AXNhfEq2rlmdRTR4ngY=.sha256)

compiling, compiling, compiling....

I noticed that the static build of wxLua on Windows uses some magical assembly stuff:

> * MS Windows 32-bit only libraries that allow a staticly built lua.exe to look and act like the lua.dll shared library.
> * The source code uses the __asm instruction and cannot currently be compiled for a 64-bit architecture since Visual Studio does not support it and gcc does not support __declspec(dllexport,naked).
>
> — _Source: [wxLua 2.8.12.3 - Installation Guide](http://wxlua.sourceforge.net/docs/install.html#C3.2)_

I'm sure that won't work if I compile for ARM64. I'm going to ditch the static builds and go with the shared ones. It is a pity because the static wxWidgets build for x86 worked flawlessly, and I'm having trouble compiling the shared one.
the stuff we do to avoid Qt... 😿

[@Daan](@MRiJ+CvDnD9ZjqunY1oy6tsk0IdbMDC4Q3tTC8riS3s=.ed25519) it is not hard at all. I have a friend who is deep into that ecosystem and has shown me very good stuff. The problem for me is twofold:

* There is no Qt for Windows on ARM.
* They are having a huge licensing mayhem right now.

So, for now I'm avoiding it. Also there is no Qt5 bindings for Lua AFAIK so I'd need to switch languages and I don't want to at the moment.

But, Qt works. (Is it QT, Qt, qt?)

So many errors...

I miss Pascal and Turbo Pascal / Borland Pascal. At least the errors were clearer.

The best one I've got so far was something along the lines of `Internal compiler error. Simplify the code near <whatever file:line number>`. Really?! An internal compiler error?! I went to that line, it was a simple line:

```
bValid = m_bSwapped || pHeader->magic == MSGCATALOG_MAGIC;
```

I went ahead and addes some parens.

```
bValid = m_bSwapped || (pHeader->magic == MSGCATALOG_MAGIC);
```

The compiler is happy now.

I'm facing linker problems trying to cross-compile shared libraries on a host x86 into a target amd64. The MS linker really wants to run the 64bits linker to memory map something instead of the 32bits linker. The problem is that the machine can't run the 64bits linker so the build fails.

This doesn't happen with the static build but I'm sure the static build will explode later. 

That's how much time I had today to play with this. Back to work.

[@Nｅｔｓｃａｐｅ Navigator™](@z2M8msI2EUubNHnrEJncglDIy2/SUd+36jCyJnfeiHk=.ed25519) are you using sylpheed as your email client? How's it going?

I was using Thunderbird on my Surface Go but HD is a premium on a 128gb device so I had to delete it, my email filled almost 10 gigs. I wish I could delete stuff from thunderbird without deleting from the server, and without it simply fetching it again. IMAP sounds cool but TBH I remember pop3 fondly.

[@Daan p20 📟](@tUMwMvb+roaOJAyohpGUxgqYo4E7HfBlY0NkUzALqjY=.ed25519),

wow, these look beautiful! I love the vignetting.

![axix city - dimenonal mirror view - tower, fuckbushes and a dreamliner.](&GAcAYuKBhZEJ+2Cl+u4loDZjSvcSAIoZM3PwD6vuMhQ=.sha256)

Axis city has been described by oneiric architects as pocket dimension in the nexus of all the dreams of the universes. A description that is as useful as describing an egg as _something that comes out of a chicken_. Even thought it is the correct of description, it doesn't describe why it may lead to delicious things or why things can get messy if you ever break its shell.

Existing out of time and space, Axis City makes the life of historians really really hard. To the point that most people that arrive in the city afflicted with that profession end up becoming bartenders or storytellers in the numerous taverns that are available all over the place. Much better to make a living by telling honest fiction, or deal with the daily paradoxes  by serving alcohol to themselves and others.

Arriving in the city is not easy. Oneiric science establishes that the more common a dream template and archetype is, the more solid it becomes in the ether that connects all the universes. They first factor is commonality. That would lead one to conclude that Axis is populated by kids who dream of pissing their pants in class. Surely, that is not the case. Commonality gets the dreamer in the correct path towards axis, walking that path requires either luck, a map, or three blood oranges. Don't ask me why, it just works.

> “I was just making a cocktail to prepared myself for reviewing some stupid papers. I was really tired and fell asleep while holding the damn oranges. I wish I knew better„ — Eric John Ernest Hobsbawm, Historian/Bartender at the confused vegan werewolf inn.

Most people arriving in Axis City are there to do commerce. Dreamliners bring caravan runners from all universes to trade, gossip, plot, and steal. Those people don't stay long. The inhabitants, most of them arrived by mistake and don't know how to leave. Fearing getting lost in the dream path, never able to reach their home back, most start new life in the city. Most of the guilds are always hiring, and by hiring I don't mean that they pay you. You get food and lodging, which for most people is more than enough.

The guild that is the easiest to join — because they accept anyone without any standard or test — is the gardeners guild. They are responsible for keeping Axis City garden out of Axis City. Garden is an euphemism, it is actually a fucking forest. A real fucking forest. I mean, it is actually fucking itself.

To understand the fucking forest surrounding Axis City dimension, we must turn back to oneiric science. As mentioned, the most common dreams lead to Axis. That means that Axis City is surrounded by porn. A gigantic fucking forest that threatens to overwhelm the city if not pushed back into towards itself. The current best way of pushing the forest back is going to its edge and shout words from _The Venerable and Mostly Complete Book of Safe Words Choices As Statistically Calculated For Insecure Curious Men By Benefrits, Sex Dreams Statistician, Second Class_. Little insecure fuckbushes with pop into nothing when hearing their corresponding safe word.

> “When you're dreaming, do not turn left on the orgy! And if you do, do not accept the orange martini from the starberry unicorn at the pond! Don't drink that shit!„ Maria Almeida, just arrived at Axis, looking for a job.

Axis City population is mostly formed by the lost, the dreamers, the shamans, those who put too much effort into fanfiction and cosplay, con artists and magicians. It is a dangerous city, messy, but once you call it home, it is as if you were born there.

If you're not in the category above, pay attention when you're dreaming.

content.text:
[@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) your loving work with the weekly helped us all see the scuttleverse beyond a technical adventure. Seeing those posts made our garden more human, helped us connect to one another with topics, subjects and ideas we wouldn't know about if not for your tireless surfacing of awesomeness.

Thanks a lot for all the hard work. I looked forward for those summaries every week, it was among my favourite things happening here. I'm happy to have arrived in SSB while you were doing it. In the future, we'll not only talk about how it was, but thanks to SSB we can show people what you've made and help inspire them.

😻 thanks! 😻
Hey [@lxoliva](@hhknMruxen2tXWeQYkpKlFsm09ye5R9TrYQyKsM47kU=.ed25519) have you played with Guix yet?

[@martin ➬](@pJsYrTaEjm5XW5Qe0W9JW2c+RpYNqJHPMZ0qGFFYXfI=.ed25519), it kind depends on the kind of community you want to build. I'll outline my ideas below based on seven years of Mozilla volunteering.

* Wiki - absolutely needed. It helps preserve knowledge of what happened, codify how things should happen, plan ahead for things that will happen.
* HackMD/Etherpad - A collaborative editor is good for brainstorming during meetings. At MoFo we relied on Etherpad a lot and you'd be surprised about how much we planned using it. A large part of what made MozFest what it was happened in Etherpads before the event. That is gone now, MoFo is no longer using Etherpads due to security reasons and people switched to Google Docs as they couldn't find a substitute in time. It is not the same. I don't know what they are using these days because I've moved into different stuff.
* A forum - Asynchronous communication organized by threads will help a community that is spread in different timezones work together. A mailing list might serve the same purpose.

I'll create some fictional stories below, but I'll sprinkle them with real info too:

### Fictional Community Story 1 - creating SOPs

Standard Operating Procedures — SOP —  is a generic term for recipes on how to do anything community related. An example of SOPs can be seen in the [Mozilla Reps SOPs page](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Reps/SOPs). Each SOP outlines a recipe on how to deal with a specific task, such as how to fill a budget request, how to approve a budget request, etc.

Those SOPs can be decided in a collaborative way and that's where the tools come into play. 

* Topics for a working group to manage SOP creation is started on the **forum**. Community members add their input and decide who wants to joing the WG.
* Working Group meet online as many times needed. Using multiple **HackMD/Etherpad** they come up with a draft.
* Working Group post draft to **forum** and asks input for the larger community. Depending on the feedback, the go back to meetings and re-drafting. This process repeats until the draft is approved by whatever consensus mechanism is in play.
* Working Group add entries to the **Wiki** on the SOPs. Community members can now get familiar with the final form of the SOPs and new community members have an easier time figuring out how things work.

### Fictional Community Story 2 - An event
FOSDEM 2027 is fastly approaching and your community wants to participate. Some members check the *Wiki* and figure out how to handle event participation, they begin by:

* Following the initial SOP instructions outlined in the *Wiki*. _In our case at Mozilla, this includes for example double checking that the event includes a CoC_.
* A **forum** post goes out with a call for participation. People iterate over it finding out who wants and can join.
* An online meeting happens and **HackMD/Etherpad** is used to brainstorm activities and logistics. If necessary, the participants break into different working groups to tackle specific aspects of event planning. The **HackMD/Etherpad** is at the same time whiteboard for brainstorming and notes for the meeting so that people who were not present can follow the notes afterwards.
* Once the planning is done, a **Wiki* page is added with information about the event, the community participation, it's plan, and afterwards a post-morten and maybe cool photos.

### Summary 

You can see how the tools outlined in the message always work on the same pattern:

Asynchronous messaging to attract participants ← Collaborative editor to brainstorm live &lar; Wiki to codify and preserve output.

With that in place, you can make a small group of people have a large impact as a community. I hope this helps.
[@the Queen of England](@YND2Cb9uk3ZdFyzXpaXDH5HZ9udu+qjg4MhNcynK2RE=.ed25519) yes we do. Oasis should run.

[@Lex Tenebris](@1xmN5aBHmPhMePeyhb13DHfOqK9j1VKl2qOudlQWUoM=.ed25519),

I checked your website and I see that you are apparently a white caucasian American. I'm highlighting this because what I'm about to talk is probably diametrically opposed to your life experience so far. Most Americans haven't been exposed to the kind of violence, danger, and hatred, that we South Americans have. There are a lot of violence, danger, and hatred, in America don't get me wrong, but it is not usually directed at caucasian people.

I'm white-ish caucasian cis male as well, but I come from a very different place. I was born in a dictatorship. Let that sink in for some seconds before continuing reading for Americans never ever lived in something like that, you don't know how it works. I was young, just a kid. I saw the transition to democracy when I was a teen. That transition is not like a fairy tale, we still have many problems that can be easily traced back to the dictatorship.

My grandparents and parents lived in a country that flirted with fascism. I was born when that was no longer fashionable and everyone pretend it never happened. But I went to a good school, and had good history teachers, and they remembered that it happened.

When I was a young adult, there used to be TV Ads from the government to call us to vote during the elections. That is mandatory where I come from. You lose some civil rights if you don't vote (temporarily, until you do the necessary paperwork and fines). That is not because government was cruel, that is because society was still traumatized and scarred when they created those laws, and a democracy is not a democracy if you do not exercise your rights. During those ads, there was a campaign that forever stayed in my mind. It was just black and white photographs. Portraits, like ID portraits. All photos were people killed by the government during the dictatorship. The ad just said: "They died so you could vote." I remember how happy I was to vote.

Brazil is a dangerous country. I've seen my fair share of people being shot, killed, beaten. I've been threatened with all kinds of weapons, from small knives to AK-47s (a favourite of Rio criminals). I've been beaten too. All the times I've been beaten, it was a police officer hitting me.

You come from a different place. Your experience is different. Because of that you don't realize that the "freedom of speech" you claim should be paramount, should never be a trump card to clobber other peoples rights to safety. Unchecked freedom of speech, leads to people being able to hate speech. Having their hate speech protected causes it to spread, hate is very easy to spread. Once you start realizing what is happening, there is already an army of hatred outside, and once that gets going it is very hard to stop.

Brazil has an army of hatred now. Lucky for us, guns are illegal — though easy to obtain, you can even rent a gun in exchange for a share of the profits of your robberies, there is a lot of crime in Rio, it is organized — if that was not the case, we'd be in civil war already.

The army of hatred in Brazil is very similar to the current protesters in the U.S. who in a guise of traditionalism, conservatism and evangelical beliefs, look towards excluding and dehumanizing both humanities and sciences. Those people are the same groups that sites like Gab protects and hosts.

By allowing hatred to root and sprout, by being tolerant with hate speech, by being considerate of others who are fascists, all you do is give them time and safety to grow. And then, one day they come for you. That is what happened in Brazil, a country that has a fascist as president. That what happened to people I know, who've been executed in broad daylight.

It begins with using freedom of speech to protect fascists, it ends with people being gunned in the street. Fascists should never be protected. Fascists can't be reasoned with. The only thing you can do is work towards stopping them, again and again.

So because of that, I think it is completely ok and healthy to block the universe out of places that protect fascism such as gab.
[@KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519) <3 <3 <3 thanks friend! You too!

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519),

Let me just give some anecdote about IPFS community.  I was at [IPFS Camp 2019](https://andregarzia.com/2019/06/ipfs-camp-2019.html), they gave me a sponsorship to go there without asking anything back, much like [@Rabble](@THUzexG1y6kWofwiN8Lix/jNH/P6roYdlCDgpAn2HSc=.ed25519) and Planetary did at ScuttleCamp One.

That event still is the best organised event I've been in a long long long long time. It was fully packed of content and opportunities to connect. I wish all events were like that.

There were lots of different groups represented at the event. There were your usual blockchain people, but there were lot of hackers interested in building better tools for the future as well. It felt great. I interacted a lot with people who work for protocol labs there, and each one of them was a joy to be with. I left the event really happy with their community, specially the people from Portugal.

I think that the community is more spread all over the normal web though. In pockets in Telegram, Twitter, Mastodon and web sites. Or around specific projects. Since IPFS is not like SSB in the sense that it is not shipping community making apps with social network features as the main products, people end up mingling elsewhere. So it is a bit harder to point where they are.

I've been twice to Tableflip here in London to meet with people who work with PL. Those are among my favorite days in London, specially when thinking about the times I went somewhere to meet tech people. I was always well received and felt at home.

I haven't used their forum, but I am sure that a ton of people in that community and inside that company, share common values with us.

[@mudflap-Dell](@w3i0o1aAJimCoOWsvMVCPUl9dKNXIBlgtE/FUh5OQ2k=.ed25519)

> we need more listening- especially to views we disagree with

There is a difference between "views we disagree with" and "that person is a fascist". It is a spectrum and after some fuzzy threshold, it just goes bad and believe me, any kind of support they get will hurt you later, it always does. It did in Germany, it did in Italy, it did in every single country in Latin America. If you're an American, you've never seen the rise of far right and dictatorship, even though your government caused them elsewhere, your people have always been somewhat shielded from such horrors. You can't say "my experience is different" because you have no experience. Your country is has not experienced the kind of fascism I speak about. Reading about it is not experiencing it, watching a video on youtube about some dude who had some success is not experiencing it, and is also not representative of what people experience in real life. It is an isolated case. You can point to a good nice cop in America, there are probably thousands of them, but african americans still die in disproportionate amounts being gunned down by policeman without presenting any threat. You don't go to one of those families and show them a nice video of one policeman helping someone assemble a christmas tree and tell them that "we need more of this". That is wearing blinds.

You are saying "in my experience it is not like this", when I can tell of about at least five or six countries, as in whole countries, that became fucked up because of fascism. 

You're saying we should engage and talk with the same people who:

* Thinks some groups of humans are not worthy for whatever crazy reasons. They are not white enough, not heterosexual enough, not religious enough, you choose. There is always an us and them.

Is this the group you think I should be engaging with? Because if you think so, if you defend these bastards, then please, don't engage with me. I have nothing to do with those who protect fascists. Those who are silent when observing oppression are also guilty.

#### Not really funding but fellowship.

# Mozilla Fellows for Tech + Society
## This year we are introducing a new focus area of the Mozilla Fellowship Program for tech + society strategists in the Global South.

Critical civil society organizations fight inequality, protect the public, and partner with the public sector to serve its citizens. In the era of ubiquitous technology, it’s paramount that civil society also work to address societal issues, as they converge with the digital world. Building capacity at the intersection of technology and society will help ensure the relevance and sustainability of these institutions.

The Ford Foundation and Mozilla are partnering to strengthen organizations in the Global South by layering technology strategies into their work. This will help create a ‘third space’ where key civil society organizations and tech-focused individuals address issues at the intersection of technology and society. This will also seek to address the political element of technology -- that technology as a neutral tool is affected by its creators and their biases. Benefits, harms and side effects come from how systems are designed, what data is selected to train them and what business rules they are given.

We envision that, in 10 years, this collaborative ‘third space’ will flourish in the Global South in which civil society organizations demonstrate strong capacity to address major issues at the nexus of social justice and technology. These organizations will leverage technology to promote these issues while preventing or mitigating their risks.

At the program level, Ford and Mozilla will place senior technology strategists as Fellows within select organizations and coalitions that are foundational to the strength and capacity of regional civil society.

Fellows will help increase the impact of the organization’s work by supporting them to recognize, design, and implement a strategy that accounts for the impact of technology on the organization’s mission.

More info: https://foundation.mozilla.org/en/fellowships/tech-society-fellows/

## Key dates:
* Registration Deadline- Thursday, May 28, 2020 12pm PT
* Full Application Deadline- Tuesday, June 2, 2020 12pm PT
* Notification of Results- By July 31 2020

I originally patched the whitelist used by [`protocol_handlers`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/manifest.json/protocol_handlers) in Firefox but Mozilla is apparently using yet another list for [`registerProtocolHandler()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/registerProtocolHandler) in a bug linked by [@dietrich](@vB/yLGZ7vBGgPMTG5NEczZc6ufr0YqhxRScOk6jPi60=.ed25519).

[@Tim Makarios](@JrVM9RgoJwHcKPzCDZgCrrnZhbPODgm8JP8fDixW/mo=.ed25519) and [@Alex](@ujT9G7p4h1zeFiq7qX79eAQDyL2pTo0rLgIA7iA4VIY=.ed25519),

I understand what you're both talking about. Let me be quite honest that my desire to _block  those people into oblivion_ just causes them to be active elsewhere, it doesn't solve the problem of extremism or diminishes their danger. It just hides them from me, which depending on my current mood is very desirable.

As for de-radicalizing people, or trying to re-educate them, I think that is a losing battle. As long as algorithmic feeds rule and they are steered deeper and deeper into cesspools of hate and conspiracy theories online, there is really no hope of changing them. We're living in a post-truth world where facts don't matter. It is impossible to reason with peopel that can dismiss things like gravity with _That is not what I believe_. 

What can be done is pay enough humanities people to study how we ended up in this mess and what structures led to the sprouting of such groups, and then have governments organize a response so that the next generation doesn't grow like that. In essence it is an educational problem IMHO. The educational system failed the parents, who failed the children, etc. By educational I mean something that goes beyond education in schools, I mean the whole process of educating and learning, which also happens at home and inside the community. Without educating towards reason and empathy, we end up with fucked up people.

While an individual can do the painstaking job of actively working with a group of radicals towards making them better humans, there are even worse radicals being permitted to broadcast their hate on radio shows, the internet, and print media. Radicalization happens at a larger hate than de-radicalization. Just having social workers try to dismantle this mess is not a viable solution. It is noble though.

The main problem in my point of view, which might be different than yours, is that this is not a simple group of _people who think different_, or _people who are angry and have prejudices_. Those are the same people who plan school/mosque/minority shootings, and are usually given light sentences when compared to what happens with minorities. These people are being enabled by many governments around the world, including my own in Brazil. 

Germany has their past problems with nazism and there are still pockets with those filthy bastards around. But due to that past and learning about that past, current day Germans are better equipped to deal with them, including de-radicalization. Or at least that is how it seems to me as an outsider.  

In Brazil on the other hand:

* The Culture Secretary was on TV this week saying that torture was not a big deal and that people die, that is just a fact of life. 
* The president praises dictatorship and military coups. The Brazilian fascists feel empowered and start wrecking and attacking minorities including native land because the president is on their side. We're not talking here about young people spilling hate on the internet, we're talking about  some landowner feeling empowered and then telling his paramilitary security to go into the native land he wants to use for pasture and kill the community leader. 
* Fascists attacking, as in physically attacking and mobbing, journalists trying to cover recent demonstrations.
* Evangelical-oriented fascists are assaulting transgender people on the streets, while the education minister says on TV that there are only two genders and everything else is heresy.
* The president son — who has a strong connection with Rio's paramilitary gangs (illegal dirty cops, basically drug lords in uniform) — telling one of the most popular Youtubers in Brazil that would be a shame if something happened to his mother.

I'll never forget something my wife told me while she was investigating human rights violations for the globe & mail in the past. There was a hit and run, a right landowner son killed a Brazilian indigenous man who was walking on the sidewalk with his pickup truck. In the trial, his lawyer said to the judge: _"but your honor, it was just an indian". as if he had hit an animal.

That is the kind of violence that that Brazilian fascists do. They are not your usual neonazi internet race-hate kind. They are usually aligned with evangelicals, landowners, industry owners. What they hate is poor people, black people, indigenous people. You can think of them as those who miss the times when Brazil was an empire and slavery still existed. When they were aristocracy and servants obeyed. It is actually very similar to shit that is going on the U.S.

What other countries experience in terms of violence due to far-right rise is different from country to country. All of the things I've mentioned regarding Brazil are first-hand accounts that happened to either direct friends of mine, or people who my wife (a journalist) was interviewing in the past. That is violence that is _close_, not something you hear about in the distance that might have been exaggerated or spin up for political reasons.

In the end, I think that fascism is punishable and even though you should try to de-radicalize people, I think that fascism needs to be stopped. I think it is ok to cut whatever agency they have. If I could, I'd spray every single fascist with immobilizing foam spray until only their heads are clear, then I'd put them all into a marathon of watching _Annie with an E_ until they learn what empathy should feel like.

[@Alex](@ujT9G7p4h1zeFiq7qX79eAQDyL2pTo0rLgIA7iA4VIY=.ed25519) said:

> In this way, a network can become gentler over time if growth is small, or will have its hateful numbers small but controlled.

I wish I shared this hope. Because what I see is a group of opinion-formers and media owners who spill hate so wide and so fast that any attempt to curb it with gentle, democratic means is too slow. For me it feels like a sinking ships and we're working with a tiny bucket. The ship is sinking faster than we can remove water, even though we try really hard and actually remove a lot of water. In the end, we're exhausted, our effort didn't make enough change to alter the overall destiny of the ship. I'm quite disillusioned on these matters, sorry, I'm not usually quite pessimist but regarding this far-right grow, I don't see anything normal/gentle working.

# Sourcehut added support for plan9
https://sourcehut.org/blog/2020-05-11-sourcehut-plus-plan-9/

The [build service at sourcehut](https://man.sr.ht/builds.sr.ht/) added support for plan9 builds. They are using [9front](http://9front.org/) as the Plan9 version for the builds.

A manifest like:

```yaml
image: 9front
tasks:
- build: |
    cd /
    . /sys/lib/rootstubs
    cd /sys/src
    mk nuke
    mk all
```

Which basically rebuilds the OS and userspace takes about 115 seconds.

[@juul](@22YV3HX/BGClXH49ZebkcepqRpj7a9f5s0ddwhDSfxk=.ed25519),

> Why do you want to run static apps? Isn’t that just setting yourself up for future pain? I don’t see the appeal.

A case that happened to me recently was related to SQLite. I wanted to use some extensions with it and there is no way to guarantee that the library provided by the package manager was compiled with them. Many apps in that situation will just vendor SQLite, but once you start in that path, you might as well start to vendor a ton of your dependencies, and then you're basically going static. Lots of libraries with compile time options are like this.  

This is less of a problem if you're distributing source files with some clever build system to recompile every dependency with the options you need, but if you want to ship binaries that users can just run, then you're in trouble.

All these problems are solvable but they add a ton of friction to something that should be simple: shipping software to end users that they can just double-click and run.

[@cblgh](@C6fAmdXgqTDbmZGAohUaYuyKdz3m6GBoLLtml3fUn+o=.ed25519) just plugging in that the easiest way to write blog posts in SSB is probably with Patchfox these days, you can just to _compose → blog_ and be happy. 

It would be great if open collective offered RSS/Atom feeds for these updates, then patchfox could simply import them into SSB but they don't.

[@cblgh](@C6fAmdXgqTDbmZGAohUaYuyKdz3m6GBoLLtml3fUn+o=.ed25519) patchfox doesn't run it's own ssb-server, you're supposed to run it at the same time as patchwork (or another client that provides a server), it will just piggy back on that. There is no chance of forking because it is talking to the same server running on your other client.

You need to use the same secret or patchwork will refuse the connection.

For example, all this time I've been running patchwork and patchfox just fine. :D

I had previously tried to compile go-ssb with the 32bits version of Go for Windows. It compiles but when running the server there is a memory map error that is caused by it not being 64bits.

Today I used WSL2 to cross-compile golang to `windows/arm` and used this native arm version to compile go-sbot. It compiled fine but it errored just the same. At least it was more native than the previous version.

Unfortunately `windows/arm64` is not a valid runtime combo for go yet. I can't wait for it to be available so that I can compile a native SSB for Windows on Arm64.

[@angel'in heavy syrup](@L2BBIzFuVfCnN6L6K5OqYoAT1fglcuyhFSZS3gh067U=.ed25519)

> All the so-called “Linux” distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux 

This is not really true. There are many linux distros that don't contain GNU userland or even glibc. Linuxes targeting musl + busybox such as [alpine linux](https://alpinelinux.org) and [kiss](https://k1ss.org/). 

Also in many linuxes there a ton of userland stuff that is not made by GNU. Why we're not including them on the name as well? Every single Linux distro contains SQLite, are we calling it SQLITE/GNU/Linux? 

They all include Python and Perl, and many use those tools for their build systems, CI, package management. Are we calling them Python/Perl/GNU/SQLite/Linux?

Distros who are managed by people from the Free Software Foundation can call themselves GNU/Linux. Trisquel is a GNU/Linux, so is Guix, but forcing that moniker into other systems while complete ignoring that in most distros there is the Linux kernel, probably GNU userland, and a ton of other projects that don't go demanding people rename Linux to suit them.

In this post from 2011:

> Pedro Côrte-Real has posted the results of an investigation into the provenance of the code making up a Linux distribution. "Figure 1 shows the total LOC in Ubuntu natty split by the major projects that produce it. **By this metric GNU software is about 8%. I didn't include GNOME in the GNU category because it seems to now be effectively run outside GNU but including that the total for GNU would be around 13%.** I found two things to be really surprising in this chart. The first is that the kernel is actually comparable in size to all the GNU software. The second is that small projects actually dominate the total amount. It seems that at least for what Ubuntu packages, the origin of the software is highly dispersed."
>
> — _Source: [How much GNU is there in GNU/Linux? [LWN.net]](https://lwn.net/Articles/445454/)_

So sorry but a Linux distro contains way more than GNU in it, both in terms of LOC, but in terms of packages, and in terms of projects involved. Linux is a patchwork, a combination of many many sources, ideas and projects. 

If there is no GNU, then Linux could use BSD userland, that is the route that minix3 went, it has its own kernel and lower level microkernel stuff but on top of that it is basically NetBSD these days. 

GNU and FSF do matter a lot and do a ton of good. I believe they are awesome and am happy to donate money and effort when I can but we should simply stop with this crusade to call things "GNU/Linux". We don't go around calling Android, Ubuntu, OpenSUSE, Linux/Android, Linux/Ubuntu, Linux/OpenSUSE. There BSD distros these days based on FreeBSD, the FreeBSD foundation doesn't go after them to call them FreeBSD/whatever. 

So before coming in and telling people that they are doing something wrong and should change their ways to suit your world view, stop and think, is the project you're talking about:

* Managed and made directly by FSF volunteers?
* Is the project in constant contact and using GNU infrastructure?
* Does the project feels that it belongs into the GNU umbrella and family?

It is up to each project to name itself and up to people to use the name they feel more comfortable with. As far as I am aware, the GPL doesn't require you to call your software GNU anything either. 

If FSF people want a true GNU system, then, they can make it (for me Guix is already the best GNU could ever be) and call it GNU or GNU/Linux but if it is not made by them, then, please stop demanding stuff from other people.

[@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519), I'll do it a bit later today. I need to finish some work first. Doing those tests were my "breakfast" (coffee + toast + try to compile something and watch)

[@John Colagioia](@RoHPOaN65z8ZVYwPr19Ni4KgYCE05k+FAKMdDPyHbvs=.ed25519),

>  majority of what people think of as “Linux” is what was written as the GNU operating system running on top of a Linux kernel.

I don't know if _the GNU operating system_ is still what is actually running or guiding Linux these days. GNU is more than simply software. It is a way of doing things. It coves the software, the license, the ethos, and the community behind it. While in the early days of Debian and other similar distros what we had was in fact the GNU operating system running, these days lots of the parts are listed in the very link you posted might not be actually what is actually running on a given distro.

The basic parts of GNU listed on that link are:

* GNU compiler collection, GDB, Binutils: that is widely used but there are more and more projects switching to clang. I couldn't find a current kernel distro built with clang though.
* glibc: there are many distros focused on musl and other libcs.
* GNU Bash: many distros switched to other shells, specially zsh.
* Coreutils: Lots of distros are using busybox.

Besides that I said that GNU is more than just the software, it is the

* **The licenses:** you can't escape it, there is no way to release a Linux without touching any GPL stuff.
* **The ethos:** for me that is the most important part of GNU and FSF and to be honest it is the part that I value the most. Things should be done a certain way. This ethos is no longer the main driving force behind many distros. Yes, they'll keep the four freedoms, but they are focused on something else and doing something else.
* **The community:** FOSS is so big these days that there are whole groups of thousands upon thousands of developers who are not actually in contact and interacting with FSF in any way community-wise. There are even communities who are making a conscious effort (for whatever reasons) to distance themselves from FSF and GNU.

All that is to say that things are complicated. In the Linux world there are many moving pieces and forces at play. A good point of view is how pervasive (and invasive) _systemd_ is. This init system is not GNU and doesn't adhere to UNIX philosophy. It is backwards compatible with LSB but that is mostly because without that Red Hat would have a hard time pushing it forward.

I know this has been a lot of text, but what I want to say is that:

* I find it annoying that FSF activists keep hunting for people who say Linux and demand that they say GNU/Linux instead. That is a waste of communication and effort in my opinion and serves only to add friction.
* GNU is more than just slapping coreutils on a distro, it should mean more. 
* There are other projects and foundations who are just as crucial as GNU for Linux to work these days. Those other projects don't waste their time trying to add their name to Linux. I think that is a good practice.
[@cryPhone📱](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519) I didn't knew that rsrsrs. I want to get a windows/arm version going so that I can try to build a go-based scuttle-shell.

[@cryPhone📱](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519) [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519),
