[@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519),

>  re systray: it might make sense for various reasons to turn this into a muxrpc plugin that shims around a go package, that way we keep the functionality around.

I was thinking along a different path for this feature. I want to keep it but I was thinking about totally decoupling it from SSB altogether. Create a little go app which is sort of a task runner, it lives in the systray and knows how to start, stop, and monitor _go-sbot_ and _patchql_ binaries. 

Once we have the binaries for both things available, we can create different wrappers to run it. Scuttle Shell would be one that lives on systray (and similar solutions on other operating systems), but other solutions such as a wrapper to start it with systemd or launchd services might be possible too. In my opinion, the more we decouple things, the more flexible they get. Scuttle Shell objective is to start and stop SSB services, I don't think those services need to be aware of it, or at least I couldn't think why they should.

This approach is probably simpler, and it might allow us to make Scuttle Shell flexible enough to manage other kind of services. If the shell is made as a simple task runner, we could use it for other stuff like bamboo, p2panda, etc. Anything providing binaries becomes fair game.

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519),

I'm forking %nEP4se5RF/2qQ3oKQxKaNyFjHcYP8LKfdM9LkPwEfSA=.sha256 to give you an idea. Using `ssb-webify` you can ship web page and it's resources to SSB. You can craft a page using [A-Frame](https://aframe.io) and related technologies. There is a treasure trove of information about mixed reality on the web at https://mixedreality.mozilla.org/

All these would be compatible with SSB as far as I know.

Today, at least for now, I won't show you my coffee because my coffee sucked big time. Me and my wife decided to take a walk to the park and lounge for a while (it is now permitted under the misguided new policies but probably safe if we stay far away from everyone). Knowing that the sun would go down soon, I decided to make coffee for us to take to the park. We both have [fantastic and excellent travel tumblers from Kinto](https://kinto-europe.com/collections/travel-tumbler), they have kept our coffee good for six hours in the past, I love them.

So, I went to prepared the coffee on a Hario v60. Sometimes the Brazilian in me is just too strong, and I go into jerry-rigging mode! I was like, I'm going to save on coffee by adding a bit more water, then I'll be able to fill both tumblrs. That was a poor decision. Basically I made coffee-flavoured tea (aka _chafé_), or coffee-scented hot water. Don't get me wrong, it did helped us stay warm when the wind got chilly and the sun was no longer shining directly on us, but it didn't tasted good.

And that is why I didn't take any picture and why you're not seeing it. Still, I need to write two chapters today, or at about 30 pages if my guess is right. I will not be able to churn through this task without proper coffee. You might see some photo later today.

content.title: Firefox Tricks - Using alternate stylesheets
content.summary: There are many underutilized features in browsers these days but there is one that had been present in Firefox for a long time and is apparently completely unknown to most web developers, they are called **page styles** and they expose [alternative style sheets](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Alternative_style_sheets) to the user.

content.text: Source: [my own blog](https://andregarzia.com/2020/05/firefox-tricks-using-alternate-stylesheets.html)

Don't know if this link about [zettelkasten](https://writingcooperative.com/zettelkasten-how-one-german-scholar-was-so-freakishly-productive-997e4e0ca125) appeared here before but I thought you people would like it.

I just got to learn about #gemini from this post from [@cel-desktop](@lOUVT+Phkvai9a/cCS/RKo+S9hnPAQdVixms/7ldpPA=.ed25519), and got quite intrigued about it. It looks like a fun protocol to implement and experiment with.

Is anyone here  hosting a gemini server? You folks playing with it?
If I stand up on a hammock like this, either it rips and falls down with me, or, I fall down alone after wobbling in panic after 30 seconds.

I've been a GSoC student implementing the first network preflet for Haiku. It was basic my first C++ project (it had more C in it than C++ tbh). The preflet has been replaced with something much better but that initial project made me appreciate Haiku a lot. I don't like C++ but I'd rather deal with a BeAPI in C++ than in Rust, just because I don't like the borrowing semantics. I understand it is safer, I just find rust code a bit ugly. Don't know, maybe I should spend more time with it.

I think that the main problem with more devs in haiku is that there is no good bindings and comprehensive toolkit for developing "best practice" apps in it with languages other than C++.

# Playing with #racket and #gemini

![image.png](&exH6gHEqPMuod9+7sHq18d0PFFuhj5Z69HawSdK6Jp0=.sha256)

I successfully made a request and displayed the response but it is not yet a usable library.

Been wondering if I should stick to a functional library or build a class. 

Classes are not that common in Racket but I like them. I think I'll try a class, it might make it easier to play with ` racket/gui`  later.
I think this is a grant that I want to apply. The other opportunities were a bad time for me but this sounds like a good one.

![image.png](&sW0NBwk01+AEAC4xIPYMWRlCWQFvNx+hzbhg7zXJpYg=.sha256)

Look how cute this is!

I decided to write quasi-functional code instead of classes. I've just implemented a gemini client that is able to parse the response into _s-expressions_. It tags all the lines according to the [gemini spec](https://proxy.vulpes.one/gemini/gemini.circumlunar.space/docs/spec-spec.txt). 

It doesn't support the client cert stuff and doesn't follow redirects automatically. But I think that is enough for me to build a simple GUI tool like the one [@cel-desktop](@lOUVT+Phkvai9a/cCS/RKo+S9hnPAQdVixms/7ldpPA=.ed25519) linked built with _tcl/tk_.

This little "library" is GUI agnostic, it just fetches a `gemini://` resource and if it has a body it parses according to the spec — just noticed that I'm not checking the MIME types, I'm assuming it is gemini, need to fix this — any client tool can easily parse the _s-expression_ generated and render a pretty UI.

The current code is 326 lines only. It needs tests, error checking, etc, but for a toy built during the weekend, it feels great.

[@zelf](@3ZeNUiYQZisGC6PLf3R+u2s5avtxLsXC66xuK41e6Zk=.ed25519) THANKS A ZON ZELF! I'll definitely need help.

I'll read all about the grant and join the meeting.

![image.png](&zS5ZE+yunOnTsoySuHETaFtDVyLivGPhcGDmiC8SH1Y=.sha256)

Got a toy GUI working. It needs tests, error checking, etc, but it is getting better. I think this is enough for today. I'm tired now.

I will polish this a lot before publishing to racket packages directory. At the moment is more like an exploration.

I made a smol blog post [about it](https://andregarzia.com/2020/05/toying-with-gemini.html) — if you read this thread you know most of it already — and also added the sources to an [online repo](https://git.sr.ht/~soapdog/racket-gemini). The source is quite messy but it can grow into something useful.

I wanted to convert that to Racket but I couldn't find a nacl library for it :-( 

anyway, I love these little samples you've been posting [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519). In my mind they are little morsels, or nuggets, or your favourite tiny snack of awesome scuttlebuttiness.

I bet it can be converted almost line by line into Lua though. The signature might be tricky as I have no idea about serialization order in the various json libraries for Lua.
Anyone has an idea what is the oldest version, or minimal version, of libsodium that has the features needed to implement SSB?

[@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) my initial plan — which is mostly a learning experiment — is to try to implement something like _sbotc_, maybe talking to _go-sbot_. This would help me understand how muxrpc and the handshake work without the need to actually handling feed storage and gossiping.
I don't think I can use unix sockets on windows :-(  I've [read it works](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/commandline/af_unix-comes-to-windows/) but it looks strange.

![image.png](&HOF/aUrQ3dbyacUWPYsJDdOHKvFuYkn3LQDbboNr1Bc=.sha256)

I'm working on my own blog reader...

I wanted to be on the meeting but for some reason the gathering had the 31st as the date for me so I didn't log in. Sorry. I'm quite happy with how things turned out. The project outlined in your message sounds very exciting.

This is looking quite neat [@cel-desktop](@lOUVT+Phkvai9a/cCS/RKo+S9hnPAQdVixms/7ldpPA=.ed25519). I really like how you use and extend dillo. 

I'm fond of using symbols like  `§` as significant chars in stuff. In my own little toy language for building slide decks, I use it to add paragraphs to the screen. Having the right symbols and sigils make the experience better for me (without necessarily turning things into APL).

I saw on the git repo you're storing the notes as plain text, is there also an index to aid search? Anyway, I'm just curious. Congrats on building your own zettelkasten. I've been thinking about doing an analog one with pen and paper. I'm still on the fence.

[@cryPhone📱](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519),

I hope you're feeling better today. 

> Additionally I’m only seeing more and more individualism here and unicorn projects with very sparse group cohesion… i don’t know. I really don’t want to go away but it also doesn’t feel healthy right now.

I think I understand this. I'm somewhat starting lots of experimentation here most to have fun. Normally they'd all just remain in my computer never to be shared (because they are experiments only) but this feels a safe place to share stuff.

I see many forces going on here and feel that we should all cooperate more.  There are brittle pieces in the SSB ecosystem that we really need to solve as a group or at least make a group decision about not fixing them. 

Today, I'll set aside some hours to go over some SSBC projects and do more cooperation, maybe it helps.

> As for the grant, if we go into it as a group, I feel much better about it.

it feels like the best option to have a good outcome out of it.

# New 8GB RAM Raspberry Pi 4 available

Sauce: https://www.raspberrypi.org/blog/8gb-raspberry-pi-4-on-sale-now-at-75/

Price: $75

[@miku](@UwQGeCHLPEYEnwpOOQ68OM25HUTlLi92G8v7HMevVFg=.ed25519) check previous work from [@cft](@AiBJDta+4boyh2USNGwIagH/wKjeruTcDX2Aj1r/haM=.ed25519) which has done an SSB-like protocol with micropython IIRC.

[@nanomonkey](@+D0ku/LReK6kqd3PSrcVCfbLYbDtTmS4Bd21rqhpYNA=.ed25519) I don't think that is applicable. I'm not talking about UI but how reconciling information from multiple messages is costly to do over `ssb-ws`. Reducing and traversing complex _pull-stream_ pipelines with multiple _muxrpc_ calls inside it to find out the info you need basically brings stalls Patchfox. In NodeJS with TCP or no-auth stuff you can do all that pretty damn fast, but over WebSockets it is a chore.

It is not about the UI or having a reactive UI, it is about how much computation do I need to do before I actually have the info I want, and how can I minimize that. I believe that sometimes we opt to go with elegant algorithms that look beautiful in their mathematical sense but are worse for my day to day usage than more practical and blunt solutions. Tangles and complex graphs have their place, specially once private groups are a thing and mutable messages become more prevalent, but that is not a silver bullet that should be applied to everything. The _More Info_ message is not the kind of message you'll send often. You might annotate all your close friends, and then update some of them every year or so, but that is it. A couple hundred messages. I think that is OK for a practical solution that makes my life easier.

There is a lot of people implementing different clients here, usually these people are the same people developing new messages and it is only human nature that they will do it in the way that make sense for their work. Someone working on a client that is to be used for collaborative editing of resources will gravitate towards graphs, tangles, crdts. Someone doing simple CRUD might opt for a simpler solution. There are more people working on browsers now, so the limitations I've found will either become more apparent as there will be more people circling this space, or will be solved by better developers than me, I am happy both ways (I'd prefer it to be solved though). 

In this friendly tug of war about how we structure our messages, I'm happy to play the whole of favouring blunt pragmatic solutions that require a minimal reducing work to be useful. Someone needs to do this if only to help people reason about this stuff and then decide in favour of graphs but with a much more clear vision why they are needed.

[@nanomonkey](@+D0ku/LReK6kqd3PSrcVCfbLYbDtTmS4Bd21rqhpYNA=.ed25519) it is not feature complete at all at the moment. It can launch ssb-servers you have installed if you configure it correctly and that is a huge win. It is also built in a way that we can ship binaries for all platforms without electron, which is the initial objective of this project. But it needs polishing, testing, documenting. 

I want to eventually promote it to master mostly because there is no one working on the current master branch. We'll be doing all the future work in Go and leaving the JS master branch stale doesn't necessarily serves the purpose of a master branch. Still, there might be some people using it. This thread is trying to reach out for these people.

[@Zach!](@ZqH7Mctu/7DNInxuwl12ECjfrAKUX2tBLq1rOldNhg0=.ed25519),

Thanks a lot for the new theme, I'm running it here and it is wonderful. 

I'm very fond of Dracula themes. I like them beyond just the aesthetics of the colors, I like them because I'm friends with the creator of the original Dracula theme.  Let me tell a quick story about him. 

I think it was in 2013, I'm not exactly sure but I was quite skilled in old school JS and doing a ton of events with Firefox OS stuff. At a very large event, during a large workshop session, I was coding something and then this very young adult comes and sits by my side and he asks me: _"why did you do XYZ there?"_,  and instantly a bit annoyed and defensive. I'm quite older than him and some weird prejudice played in my mind. Then, I answered him and he answered back: _"why don't you do $WHATEVER instead, it is better."_. He was dead right! It was better. I fixed it. _"Sorry for arriving here commenting but I saw that part and decided to tell you about it, I didn't want to intrude."_ 

Some gears turned in my head and I saw instantly that he knew way more than I did. Prejudices vanished into thin air, and I asked him: "Hey, no worries, can you show me more stuff?" and he went on fixing my code using new stuff I was not very familiar at the time. I think it was a 20 minutes refactor, we were both smiling and I thanked him very much. I learned a ton that day and went on to learn more about the new ES stuff thanks to him.

Our paths crossed a bunch of times in conferences around Brazil. He is one of the best developers I've seen and one of the things he cared the most when we were talking during dinner one day was Dracula  theme and how it grew. Every time I see a new Dracula theme I remember that smile and it brings a smile to my face as well.

[@Rômulo Alves](@xr/Q/zqaEwmmd4wg8xRU1TrMLQhc9qBqNCioCqmv1vQ=.ed25519),

The  _“doing/fixing things as quickly as possible”_ is part of being Brazilian. We all think like that. It is part of our culture, _think out-of-the-box and fast, solve the problem_. This is a great asset in reality, we're primed from our early years to our adulthood to think out of the box, to be creative. The same mindset that makes us world class macgyvers/jerryriggers, makes us great at finding solutions to hard problems.

Learning to write great code is an acquired skill. It is something you can teach yourself. Learning how to think outside the box and be creative is a much harder skill to acquire and teach. You already have the hard skill, you just need to learn more about the other one.

I know a lot of Brazilians working abroad. Lots. What makes them great assets is not that they write great code, even though they all do now. They not necessarily started that way. Your code will be a sum of your teams coding and review process, and you'll learn a lot working on such environments. You can get a head start by studying code that is well written and reading (and practicing) writing in a similar style with similar constraints.

I too have the same mindset as you and I can say with absolute certainty that I don't write great code unless I have other people corralling me into it. I tend to cut corners, write what works, solve the problem fast. It is an everyday struggle but that didn't prevent me from working abroad. There were jobs that I'm ashamed of the code I've written, and others where I absolutely love what I wrote.

The key thing is studying, you can only write great code if you practice. I've read a ton of books about great code, but I didn't practice. Much like I read books on drawing, and can't draw. I can recommend some books if you want, but what I would surely recommend is to start contributing to some project here on SSB and ask for code reviews. There are magicians here, they can help you discover your magic as well.

### RFC
## Implement a `syndication` message

> For those that are unfamiliar with `blog` type message, I've written some [brief documentation about them](https://patchfox.org/#/message_types/blog) as part of #patchfox.

I'm interested in adding messages called `syndication` that is mostly related to marking `blog` posts as being syndicated. The idea is that you could post a new blog post to SSB and then send one or more syndication messages with the hash id of the blog post and URLs to external networks in which the content is being syndicated.

```
{
  "type": "syndication",
  "msg": "%msgid",
  "link": "schema://link/to/same/content/elsewhere"
}
```

## Why?
This could help surface personal blogs, gopher spaces, gemini spaceports (or whatever they are called, in my mind they are spaceports). It also make it easier to share content with people outside SSB. We always have challenges figuring out if someone actually want their content shared on the web or not. Sometimes we read a post here and want to share with friends who are not on SSB. If the original author sends a `syndication` message with a web link referring to that same post, not only you have an easy way to share it, but you can also infer that the author is OK with sharing that specific post.

Some time ago I posted about how [The hard part of blogging is not writing, it is sharing your post](https://andregarzia.com/2020/02/the-hard-part-of-blogging-is-not-writing-it-is-sharing-your-post.html). Being able to spread your original content is quite hard in this age of algorithmic timelines. Adding this message would be a way to tell people (in a machine-readable way) that your content is also present elsewhere. 

## How clients could surface that?
I think this is best served when tied to long form text such as `blog` messages. When a message of that kind is rendered on the screen, the client could also query for messages of type `syndication` by the same author (to avoid spammers hijacking your post) referencing that specific message id. If some messages are found, then it could simply add some unobstructive icons to the UI that represent the kind of URLs it found, such as little globes or favicons for web urls, spaceship for gemini, etc. Clicking one of such icons would invoke the operating systems routine to handle URL launching and the client would care no further.

The UI for authoring this kind of message could be some context specific way of replying to a blog post. What I'd do for Patchfox would be to add a new button labeled _syndicate_ if you're seeing a blog post you authored that exposed a UI for creating such messages.

**Now, tell me what you think! :smile_cat:**

![more-info.gif](&50jIVxfX09a0ILGFTFEI0jsLZlx99lWJO5vOTbQ559w=.sha256)

I've just committed a basic implementation of the _more info_ feature to the _master_ branch of Patchfox in both Github and Sourcehut repositories. Adding and removing fields is supported and the query is fast enough for my own taste. I've changed the shape of the message a bit, it looks like:

```
let data = {
    type: "more-info",
    about: feed,
    fields: currentFields,
    luckyNumbers,
    recps: [ssb.sbot.id]
};
```

The new property `luckyNumbers` is an array of five cryptographically secure integers generated with:

```
let luckyNumbers = new Uint32Array(5);
window.crypto.getRandomValues(luckyNumbers);
```

I'm adding them to the message to add some noise and make brute-forcing the decryption harder. I decided to do this because there is a lot of such data that will be easy to infer, for example people will know that part of such message in my case is my website, adding some random noise there felt like adding a lot more friction to potential bad people. It is not fool proof but it is like salt, there is no reason not to make things delicious and add a bunch of it. **I'm not a security person, I don't know if that was a good idea, it felt a good idea to me but I'd love to have some input.**

[@Rômulo Alves](@xr/Q/zqaEwmmd4wg8xRU1TrMLQhc9qBqNCioCqmv1vQ=.ed25519),

What happened was that when I was writing the feature, I was also recording gifs and taking screenshots to post here. Then, it occurred to me that if someone saw the screenshot, they'd know the exact content of the JS object that I encrypted. Knowing the plain text value and having access to the corresponding cyphertext, usually makes it easier to break the encryption, because of that I thought it was better to add some noise so that even if someone saw a screenshot of my data, they couldn't be sure of the exact content that ended up in the message being encrypted. 

That is how I ended up adding those numbers. Then, I went looking for some safe random number generator and saw the one bundled in the browser and used that.

But maybe just having the asymmetric crypto is enough.

[@Daan](@MRiJ+CvDnD9ZjqunY1oy6tsk0IdbMDC4Q3tTC8riS3s=.ed25519), yes it is all going through the normal standard ssb private stuff provided by sodium. I just added more salt to it because the values inside can be known and easy to infer.
I used to be so afraid of those when I was a kid. The name in Portuguese is prettier, they are called Caravelas (which are the name in Portuguese for the ships known as Portuguese Man o' wars)

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519),

It is not really about solving a problem. Let me see if I can explain with an analogy, but before doing that let me apologize, you may be pre-coffee but I am over caffeinated after pulling an all-night writing 51 pages, I'm a bit of a mess right now.  so, back to our analogy: _You know when you have an artist you like and you go to their page and you can see their content available in multiple channels (as in media/marketing/vendor channels)? Like hey, I want to hear that song and you see it is available on bandcamp, spotify, deezer, soundcloud, DAT, etc... It is a bit like that, allowing authors to publish one and syndicate everywhere._

The IndieWeb people have something to say about what they call [POSSE - IndieWeb](https://indieweb.org/POSSE) — Publish (on your) Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere — it helps spreading your content while retaining control over your own platform. Having a syndication message, allows me to mark blog posts here as coming from my blog, or tell people about my other channels, thus making SSB part of a larger "web" of content in a way that is easy for the clients to reason about. There is no way for a client to figure out if a link posted as part of a text of a message is actually a syndication link to the same content unless it starts doing some quite pro-active scrapping.

Having this message allows the following cool stuff to happen:

* The user profile page can be augmented with links to other channels related to the person beyond simply addding links to descriptions.
* Automated blog import has a way to mark where the content is coming from.
* It allows to build pretty UIs for those links by separating them from the content they reference and placing them in the UI in some useful and aesthetically pleasing  way.
* Clients can completely ignore this message and nothing wrong will happen.

I think I'm just thinking about bridging and reconciling content. This kind of message sounded a good idea to me. I could share blog posts here and when people do something like _copy external link_ it could copy my blog link instead of a SSB-viewer link as it knows it is syndicated content, etc.

## This retro-futuristic luggable uses a Raspberry Pi 4 for dual monitor output.

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519),

Linking back is a bit tricky because non-SSB clients don't have a way to double check the double linking, and we don't yet have working safe custom URLs.

But that is the idea, a message version of `link[rel=syndication]`. By making it its own message, only interested clients will use it, others will ignore, everything keeps working.

# Bintracker
## A Chiptune Audio Workstation for the 21st Century

🎶 https://bintracker.org/

It is made with [Chicken Scheme](https://call-cc.org). From what  I see the UI appears to be made with Tk.

![feedpreview.gif](&+BJJJBQF2b05OctUng7fj7sytD91SBvgTYbCNVcT3Ls=.sha256)

Blogcat finding feeds on pages and previewing them before subscription.

![import.gif](&swsU9d+ot3COVBuRG4eIdy6fDr+NLkA4Vh8EEinA9HM=.sha256)

Got the OPML import working.

[@dinoƧ𝔸Ⓤᖇ](@6ilZq3kN0F+dXFHAPjAwMm87JEb/VdB+LC9eIMW3sa0=.ed25519) I've used for some scripts in my dayjob and really liked it. Very clean and easy to use, I love the URL imports. The script was not a server, it is just a specialized tool to extract data from a generic CMS MySQL database and save it as flatfiles to be used later. It could have been done in any language and probably it would have been easier (as in more straightforward) to do it in a non-async language but it works well, it is easy to understand and I had fun doing it. I'm looking forward to doing more deno in the future.

_PS: You'll probably enjoy that they are looking really close into what it would take to replace the JS based implementation of the typescript compiler with a yet-to-be-written rust-based version. The speed improvement alone would make this really good._

[this is a cool article about hosting a blog on IPFS](https://elais.codes/deploying-this-site-with-ipfs-and-scheme.html). What I find cool about it is that most setups I've seen using either DAT or IPFS usually rely on P2P protocols as an afterthought. The sites are hosted in a standard HTTP webserver while also served and pinned in P2P networks. This article describes a setup that is not like that. The author uses IPFS as the host for the blog and cloudflare DNS to serve it directly from the IPFS network thus eliminating the need to maintain a web server. I think it is pretty neat.

Reading the blog post I mention in [this post about hosting a blog on IPFS](%qBG534PZSkbaAJla0sK9blA/jvTYc2iXy14TBMKoPpk=.sha256) I learned about a scheme-based static site generator that looks really neat. It is called [haunt](https://dthompson.us/projects/haunt.html) and is GPL based on Guile. I think that people using Linux would have a lot of fun using it it specially those using Guix.

Oh, and they have a cute logo:

![image.png](&/WHHXoAgj79VgRcaA2+9jdY6f40M1NjkIaliA2saVrk=.sha256)

content.text:
[@zelf](@3ZeNUiYQZisGC6PLf3R+u2s5avtxLsXC66xuK41e6Zk=.ed25519),

I noticed that I often went to see people's profiles to see when they last posted, which is the same that _last activity_ feature is doing. From how I understand it it is just saving me from scrolling a bit down and looking at the date and time from the last post.

There is no way from anyone in the network to know when you last used a client unless you post something, but if you do, then there is no way of hiding that you were interacting with SSB at that time. Because of that I don't feel it is like surveillance, for me surveillance happens when I am being monitored without agency. In this case, it is just a convenience for some habits that people already had.

A reason for that kind of shortcut is so that you might gauge if the person has seen whatever message you've tagged them on. Maybe you're waiting for an answer and then you notice that the person has not been online for the weekend, and then just cool off.

Don't know, that is just my take, YMMV

Broke my build of Patchwork on windows/aarch64. The spellchecker module and leveldown always give me trouble. I think that native modules are part of what really makes me dislike the NPM/NodeJS ecosystem. 

They are so brittle, so easy to break, and many module developers are building with unix/macs in mind and the scripts fail on windows. For example, I remember a module that actually shipped a windows build script, but the script used a VS solution that was not forward-compatible to the stable 2019 version, so it wouldn't build unless I either downgraded my VS installation, or went into `node_modules` by hand from inside VS and upgraded the file format.

I wish we had a pure JS server, even if it was a bit slower, then it would be easier to run in other platforms. Maybe that is an opportunity for Deno use in SSB.

Creating cross-platform software is not easy. Creating cross-platform C-based modules with bundled build scripts is even harder.

[@andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519) it is just anecdote, but when we arrived in the UK, in our first two months, Lili was walking to the grocery shop and was about to cross the pedestrian xing, one of those that cars are supposed to stop for you. A police car was driving a bit fast and came up to a screeching halt before the crossing. Lili crossed, the policeman drove by her slowly and spoke to her apologizing for not breaking earlier and with less fuss. She called me afterwards, it was a novelty to see a police officer apologizing for stuff, we were finding it very funny.

I know the police in the UK has problems just like elsewhere, but compared to the police from Rio, omg, it is a whole different world.

So, today I posted a bit about how I think that [being violent against the police is a bad decision for you, your friends, and everyone else in the demonstration](%rIwOnLUnhK8T4xOTplhi7KK6VaU0busafDER6hTWBQ4=.sha256). Reflecting about that post, I realized that my own personal experiences with polices are probably really different than what people here experienced in their lives. So, I decided to post a couple stories, all of them are my own. I'm not posting it to raise flames, it is just so that people have a clear grasp of different ways police act elsewhere, and be aware that by Brazilian standards I am a middle-class white cis male, kinda untouchable and safe. If I was a member of any minority, probably all those stories would have gone differently.

* I was camping in a rural city in Minas Gerais state that is known to attract hippies, ufo watchers, new-age cults, etc. There was a police raid in the camp, they were looking for drugs, or so they claimed. I don't actually do illegal drugs, I'm happy wit booze, so I didn't had anything with me but a bottle of rum and one of vodka. The policeman kept screaming at me: _"where are the drugs!!!!???!"_ while he rummaged and throw all my stuff around. By the time he disassembled my flashlight, I asked: _"Will you help me put all this back together?"_, to which he replied: _Do you find yourself funny, carioca?_ (carioca is someone from Rio city, which I am not but I have the accent). I told him: _"Oh, I find myself very very funny."_ and that is when he slapped me in the face and started beating me. I was half drunk, so I was more interested in annoying him by being sarcastic than anything else.
* I was at a peaceful demonstration, the police closed all the streets around us, boxed us, tear gas, rubber bullets aimed at the face of people. Journalists shot with the same bullets too. I remember being gassed and kicked. A friend carried me away.
* My university campus was one of the entrances to a little hill with a vulnerable community in it. I used to work late there as a volunteer in the local TV station. My shift (just Wednesdays) started at midnight and went to about 2 or 3 in the morning. It was common for us to have parties at the university and in one of such parties, before my shift, I went out of the campus towards a bar to buy more beer. A patrol car came running, made a u-turn, both doors opened, two policeman carrying machine guns quickly moved towards me pointing their guns at my body. Be aware that I was wearing flipflops, a shirt, and a bermuda, not threatening at all. The kept shouting: _Where are the drugs?!!?!?_ and pointing the gun at me, one of them slapped me (a common practice among police people in Brazil). I explained I was a university student (that still carry some weight there), that I studied in that building in the corner and was going to buy beer at that other building in the other corner. After some puzzlement, the guy asked: _You're seriously going just to buy beer?_, which I replied yes and asked him to please point the machine gun elsewhere, which they didn't. Then, he said: _Ok, be in the peace of Jesus..._ and they moved away, never exposing their back to me, always pointing their guns at me until they were in their car.
* I told an gym colleague I was robbed. I forgot he was a liutenant or whatever, he asked me: _do you want us to kill them?_.
*  As drunk teenagers, policeman found us, beat us, threw us into their car, drove us to the closest home of one of ours with the intent to extort money from their parent. His father (the sharpest hippie mind in the box), upon seeing the cop and us. Did an impromptu speech on how he loved the police and his father had been a policeman in another state (a lie), and that he had a profound admiration for their jobs (another lie), they were heroes dealing with stupid youth like us (yet another lie). The policeman was ashamed to ask for money, thanked him for the compliments and left. We all had a laugh later.
* Policeman stops me to check my driving license and car documents. Everything is OK, I know it is OK. He tells me I have a broken taillight. It works I tell him. He breaks it and tell me that it doesn't. Asks me if he'll need to find more problems in the car, and go to the station? He leaves with my money.
* I imported an Apple eMate 300 from the UK in the 00s, an eBay purchased. Instead of it arriving at my home, I am summoned to the federal police station in the rio de janeiro international airport. Three old policeman, with that 70s look and feel, with mustaches, etc, are smoking and looking at me. They want to know if I think the police is stupid (I do) because no sane smuggler would try to pass a laptop through customs claiming it costs only 20 GBP. I explain it is a used machine, vintage computing. That is really costs 20 GBP. They talk among themselves, and then come back explaining how the custom import tax is done (which I am well aware of), it is priced 60% on the sum of the product price + shipping cost + insurance. Since it was a mint condition device, I paid for expensive shipping, they told me I had to pay about 100 GBP in taxes, but I could instead, pay about 60 GBP instead, 20 for each of them. I said _OK, I'll pay the 100 GBP tax, I want a receipt_, he laughed and told me I was misunderstanding me, that they'd not let me leave there with a bad business decision. In the end I got the machine, they got the 60 pounds. No one slapped me this time.

I have other more violent stories, but they didn't happened to me of course. I've known people who were killed by the police and saw their brutal actions when I was working on a social program in the vulnerable communities. I've always been insulated from it, but I saw it. Being slapped and punched for money is easy, I got it damn easy.

content.text:
> I feel like I am in a weird position because I am against violence (especially escalation of a violent situation) but also in favour of community self defence. It’s a sort of contradiction that I grapple with.

I'm on the same camp my friend. I think it is important that people know how to defend themselves. It is just that against the police, the fight is not fair and the stakes are too damn high. Still, I totally understand why people will use violence against the police, and why it looks reasonable under a certain optic. If me and my friends been target through the centuries for sistematic killing regardless of my actions, also known as _being shot for being black_, I too would go towards a path of violence. Once the other reasonable paths are exhausted, once people keep dying anyway, that becomes easy to understand and empathize.

[@zelf](@3ZeNUiYQZisGC6PLf3R+u2s5avtxLsXC66xuK41e6Zk=.ed25519), just to be clear, I'm just talking about a very specific case of violence which is _being violent to the police while in a demonstration with more people who are not necessarily being violent to the police, and not in self-defense but in the premeditated violence kind of deal_. I'm all in favor of violence in certain cases.

This doesn't cover:

- you were being peaceful, police/other group became violent and you're defending yourself.
- your doing violent guerilla against a dictatorship.
- roundhouse kicking Trump and his cheeseburger at the same time, one foot hitting his face and the other foot hitting his burger.

There are many cases where violence is pretty ok.

[@John Colagioia](@RoHPOaN65z8ZVYwPr19Ni4KgYCE05k+FAKMdDPyHbvs=.ed25519) unfortunately the violence provoked by those people are not restricted to them and unrelated people die. You live in a place where the police is not as crazy as where I come from, for example, just this year, the police of the state do rio de janeiro alone killed more people than the polices of the whole united states:

* U.S. Police killings for 2019 amounts to 1093 civilians.
* Rio de Janeiro police in 2019 killed 1810 civilians, for the whole of Brazil the number is 5716 official deaths.
_The source for this numbers is an article by The Guardian, a similar number from the Washington Post lists 1004 dead in the U.S._

Whatever is happening in terms of police violence over there, it is worse in Brazil. Police in Rio kills  more and also dies more, the statistics for policeman suicide alone in Brazil is four times the national average. So we're talking about a machine made for traumatizing families, killing people, diying, and killing themselves. It is different and it should serve as a cautionary tale. As protests there become more violent with people doing like that guy in  the photo, there is a chance that your police will become more like mine, and that is pretty bad and dangerous.

People who want to provoke violence are free to do it as long as it doesn't pose dangers to bystanders, anything else is deeply selfish and irresponsible. They can gamble their lives, I don't care, they can't place the lives of other protesters into the bet though.

[@m455](@v5McOmFdOeif/QWH0zYzg7sBU/ytoSImdY35uEKqaiE=.ed25519) and [@Gaffen](@zdpL3pz44do6ZK5V9wzuzrponmGlgcVyY7TEYVvkVeE=.ed25519),

I used to have aeropress-made coffee every now and then when I lived in Brazil, specially just before getting married when I lived with my parents and some friends owned a coffee shop nearby and were really into it. After moving to London I ended up doing more plain old filtered coffee and flat whites and forgot about aeropresses.

My wife prefers her coffee much stronger than I usually do but she dislikes espressos. An aeropress was the only way I could find that I could brew a cup that was stronger than our filtered stuff but not a espresso. I was not prepared for it though, the first cup I made, which was done following the recipe in the box, was soooo much stronger that what we usually take, omg. We found a sweet spot for her taste, we're using once scoop (of the deep scoop included in the kit) of coffee and instead of filling the water up to the 2nd mark in the press, we're adding more water and going to the 3rd mark. This makes the coffee as strong as she likes. We're both happy. I think I'll use it more to make lattes as those milky beverages can benefit from a stronger coffee to make more contrast with the milk.

I really recommend trying it, specially if you can compare it with a french press or v60 cup at the same time, just to notice the difference. I don't notice much difference between my french press and my v60 but that is probably because I am a cheap lazy bastard who doesn't actually take the time to learn to do things properly. With the aeropress it is impossible not to notice the difference.

From the coffee extraction methods I know off, I'm only missing one I enjoy and that is a [clever dripper](https://www.pactcoffee.com/brew-guides/cleverdripper). It combines the filter experience of something like a hario or a kalita with the control you have in a french press. It is a filter shaped much like a v60 but with a valve. You can control for how long the coffee is immersed in water with it. Once you place the dripper on top of a mug, the valve is lifted and the filtering begins.

Since I already have 2x french presses, 1x v60, 1x aeropress, 1x mizudashi, I think I'm more stocked than many coffee shops I've been too and don't need to buy anything more... maybe just a clever.

[@Nｅｔｓｃａｐｅ Navigator™](@z2M8msI2EUubNHnrEJncglDIy2/SUd+36jCyJnfeiHk=.ed25519) I haven't been exposed to Go before checking out go-ssb and deciding to rewrite scuttle-shell in that language. I've found it approachable and the tooling is easy. I reminds me of Pascal, the stuff I like from Pascal.

[@John Colagioia](@RoHPOaN65z8ZVYwPr19Ni4KgYCE05k+FAKMdDPyHbvs=.ed25519) just let me explain that I don't think that vandalism and grafitti are the kind of violence I was talking about. I meant only direct attacks to policemen, as in shooting them, attacking them with impromptu weapons, that kind of stuff. That is what triggers fast escalation in my experience. All the rest, I'm quite OK and in favour. Unless you're doing damage, no one listen, that is true everywhere.

As for the police having a gentle touch, I know all about it. It is the same in Brazil. If I am a middle-class white male I can actually get away with murder (not a joke, and you can do that legal "maneuver" only once), while black people are arrested for carrying alcohol-based hand sanitizer during the protest because that is an incendiary device. It is fucked up.

[@m455](@v5McOmFdOeif/QWH0zYzg7sBU/ytoSImdY35uEKqaiE=.ed25519) the best coffee expert I am aware of is [James Hoffmann](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCMb0O2CdPBNi-QqPk5T3gsQ). That link is to his youtube channel. He is an extremely knowledgeable person, with a scientific approach to explaining and understanding what makes a good coffee cup, and how to make it repeatable. What I like about him is that he is gentle and never arrogant even though he is a champion of barista competitions and used to very high standards. In other circles, you'd see a very arrogant hipster, but there all you see is someone that delivers really good explanation on how to do stuff and why something is the way it is. If you want to know more about coffee, I don't know a better resource.

I'm not yet to create a coffee blog because I don't really have things to say beyond what I already do here, which is posting pictures and trying to tell an interesting tidbit of a story around the photo. :-) but as I learn, maybe that'll happen. <3

[@rchaves](@VUgbo/ihmVWgh7szFJcG0Tg395T5/8JU0jijEVmyByU=.ed25519) I think the chemex is really pretty. A little shop at the street-front at the British Library has it and with the light entering through the windows, and all the reflections of the street passerby's playing at the glass with the coffee shining black-golden in it, it looks damn beautiful. That channel I linked above has some stuff about the chemex that you might want to watch. I never tasted, I just watched it being used in that shop. I suspect it is close to a v60 and similar. What I feel might make a difference there is that the filter is gigantic and being folded multiple times, which should make it much ticker than the filters I use. I'm not sure if the impact of that is measurable with ease, but I suspect it might make a thinner coffee.

The aeropress kit comes with probably a hundred or more filters, the filter is so thin and the pack so packed that I don't really know how to guess how many filters are in it. I think I have more than enough there for the whole year as I don't make aeropresses every day. I also still have half the filters that came with my acrylic v60. Buying filters here is not that expensive, on the online shop where I have my coffee plan, the prices are:\

* 200x v60 01 filters: 12 GBP
* 350x aeropress filters: 13 GBP

They don't sell Chemex there but I found prefolded filters for it in another shop. The price was 8 GBP for 100x filters.

For me the Chemex is probably one of the prettiest filters out there, it is just a too damn nice. I don't know how it tastes though. How was the coffee? Have you compared with a v60?

My own personal list of coffee brewing equipment to get, in order of my current preferences:

* French press, people often don't like it and complain that you can really have control. I don't care, it is easy to use, easy to clean and doesn't require filters.
* Aeropress, it will get you a coffee that is very different than the french press. With those two you have a nice variation.
* v60 or Kalita Wave, this will be very similar to the french press but if you learn to do it propertly (which I haven't) it is heavenly.
* Clever Dripper, the child of a v60 with a french press. I enjoyed it a lot in Brazil. I had a friend who owned a coffee shop, he'd see me coming and would pick the clever and start preparing. 

I think that an important part of coffee for me are the little daily rituals, they might even be more important than the taste. In Brazil, for many years, I'd wake up and have a slow morning. I'd go to a _mate_ shop, order 500ml of ice cold mate with lime, some pão de queijos, and just sit down and watch the city wake up while reading my feeds, news, etc. Many friends knew I'd be there and would also stop by. It felt like a sitcom, in a good way.

After moving to the UK, that routine has been broken. My little coffee rituals at home, and previously going to different shops, are attempts to recapture my slow morning routine, and create enjoyable moments for myself even though most of my friends are far away.

[@emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) [@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) and others interested in #sailing or a bit of storytelling. I just remembered an old thing that happened to me while reading %1r+64wRv2vxQxy3cug+BXTKB3kObL1BNFzEvDKUN5fw=.sha256, it is not really about the waves though but surprises at sea. Be aware that I'll probably get most of the jargon wrong as I know the name and terms for things in Portuguese and not in English, so my attempts to translate will probably be messy.

I used to be a sea scout while growing up. That is like a boy scout but we go to the sea. I started sailing when I was 11 in a wooden sailboat made in 1927 with a gaff-rig sail. I still love that boat. It was a replica of the dinghy's from the old Portuguese Man'o'War ships, the kind they'd lower down to go to the shore. Or so they'd told us. We'd usually have between six or nine crewmembers in it, either rowing or sailing. It was a really nice boat but it had some peculiarities:

* We lost a large number of floor boards, to go from aft to bow would require zigzagging and jumping like a platform game. Stepping on the hull was not OK as we were years overdue for work on the "sealing" (is that the word?)
* The boat had a removable keel, you could lift it so that you could beach it. We lost the keel too.
* Because it was really heavy, and without a keel, we learned to take rolling into account while sailing.
* One of our scouts was an apprentice at a sail factory, our gennaker (is that is? The Portuguese word for it is the equivalent of balloon.) was oversized for our boat. Once it was up, if we were going upwind, we were an unstoppable force of nature, sometimes we could even control where we were going.

There is a very traditional sailing race in Brazil that goes back to the monarchy days. It is a navy school race. We'd compete every year. It was very special for us because in our class we were only competing against navy school cadets as only scouts and the navy had that type of sailboat. We were a bunch of ~13yrs kids with a captain that was like 16 years old, the navy cadets were usually 17 or 18 and had an adult with white cloves as captain. The differences between us were not only age, but the boats too. They were all usually with fiberglass boats that were much lighter than ours.

Still, we were better. That's because we'd sail every single weekend, and they'd do it just a couple weeks every year when the competition was approaching. We knew more about that bay, its winds, and sailing those boats than they'd ever do.

On the specific occasion I'm talking about, we had just won the race. It was the first time I won it. When we were heading back to our club, which was on another city across the bay (think SF and Oakland), we decided that we should throw in the anchor and stop and celebrate for a while. And so we did... we were all lying awkwardly onto the boats floor, looking at the sky, telling jokes and stories...

Thats when we heard the horn....

It was a loud horn...

It was either an oil tanker or a cargo ship. Someone popped their head up and screamed. Our anchor was loose, we'd been rolling through the bay and entered the cargo ship route. There was a cargo ship almost upon us. I don't know what a 6-8 meters wave looks like, but I know what the bow of a cargo ship looks like from below, and it also terrifying for a 13 years old.

We didn't even tried to set the sails, we just picked the oars and started rowing as fast and strong as we could. We had a new scout, this was his first boat trip. He was older and much larger than the rest of us, think college basketball material. He was screaming, crying, and hugging the mast. He lost control over his bowels. In the end we were not rowing to stay away from the ship but to get to shore so the guy could clean himself.

I don't know what 6-8 meters wave looks like, I know what seeing a cargo ship upon you smells like though.

It is a tricky topic [@kas](@RuNxm8SRujPcJx6GjtTQHp6hprAFv5voEkcvoAkB8Pk=.ed25519), I agree.

I used `locale` but I meant language. The abbreviation I used `pt-BR` is part of a very common set used by web browsers and localization tools. They denote basically the language two letter code and the country variant, so that is Brazilian Portuguese which is not necessarily the same as pt-PT, which is Portuguese from Portugal. In theory, when a localization library is looking for a string for a given key and language code, they can look for the specific variant, then fall back to another variant of the same language if they can find it, or to a global default. It is quite flexible. They are also easy to infer from the code itself, I don't speak german but I understand that "de-*" means some kind of german language variant, I think that makes it friendlier than numeric codes on a ISO table.

By simply adding an `extra` lang or `locale` field to messages, we could augment clients incrementally. There is no need to change anything if the developer or user doesn't want to, but it becomes trivial to filter or change priority orders in lists.

I worked with a digital literacy program in the past and coordinated the translation of our content in about 11 languages, most of which I didn't speak. It was impressive how much further into our desired target demographics we could reach once it became easier to them to find content by language.

[@Murilo Polese](@NcgzCoOPLjSkj9Y+GIMFbhxbqIzJCOwYBn/QQDYAOmk=.ed25519) acabei de dar uma pesquisada em algo que eu acho que você vai gostar muito. Talvez você já conheça e isso não seja nenhuma novidade, mas se for acho que vai mudar o seu badge.

Você conhece os _Memory LCD_ da Sharp? Eles são TFTs monocromáticos com uma visibilidade absurda, quase eInk porém fáceis de usar e com um refresh rate decente. O mais importante é que eles consomem basicamente nada, microwatts e se a imagem ficar estática não tem refresh e consome ainda menos. 

Eu tava olhando aqui e pro que eu acho que quero fazer, eu precisaria de duas telas de 4.4'' uma do ladinho da outra. 4.4'' é a maior tela que eles tem. Eu to com uma ideia de UX pruma maquininha baseada em sempre ter duas colunas. O foda que eu só achei a tela de 4.4'' nos EUA na Digikey e tá 72 dólares. Não to com bala na agulha pra pagar 150 dólares + imposto, e ainda comprar os breakout necessários no tindie. Vai ficar prum futuro próximo. Mas acho que uma tela menor serve pro seu badge e vai te dar uma performance/watt maneira.

[Video no Youtube mostrando Arduino + Memory LCD](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DUMHNQGVNnY)
Alias esse outro video aqui [mostra melhor os dois tipos HR-TFT e PLNC](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=32pnqlTL5-Q), sério, olha isso!

Today, for the first time in three months, I've came to enjoy some writing time at Coal Drop Yards. They're doing this safety setup in which the shops are open, mostly with take away and there are tables spread out in a safe distance from each other. A cool thing they did was to spread out some machines that look like a water fountain, the kind you see in offices where you put your mug in, but what actually drop is hand sanitizer, so don't put your cup there. Those machines are using proximity sensors so you don't need to touch anything to use one. I was carrying my mask and a pack of sanitizer wipes. Couple that with those machines and the spread between tables and I felt pretty good.

I also got a takeaway beer, I ordered one for me and one for my wife. The chosen beer was Vedett White, I didn't realize they were serving them in growlers to take away, so each of us got a liter.

I've been somewhat silent and terse here. It feels to me that I've spent months without posting even though I post almost every day. The reason is because my work life became really really busy as deadlines flied by and my main job became a bit uncertain. I decided to focus more on work, but not work as in the capitalist sense of the word, but work in the alchemical sense of the word, a big transformation.

I can't stop doing contract work now, but I can begin my transformation into something different. I love creating small tools and books and that is the direction I want to head to. I want sometime from now be just an author. That passes through making more books, and creating some small tools to aid me in the process.

I've been developing some stuff silently, as good alchemical works are usually done, but I am also Brazilian which means that silently has a different meaning, it means I told very few people. Starting today, I'm going to move these little works into the open and start posting about them and about my plans.

Posting about them will not only help me be more social in an anti-social-isolated world, but also reason and think about things that have been mostly inside my head. I hope the new projects excite some of you too.

Since [Lua 5.4.0](%yczpcvJf0HxYlnSKatXpOyVj4UlExaqSejIdR+i1zgk=.sha256) is out, and that made me really happy, I decided to dedicate a small post to languages that _compile to Lua_.

# [Fennel](https://fennel-lang.org/)

I believe Fennel is the most popular _compile to Lua_ language current out there. There are a lot of people being Fennel developers first and Lua developers second. It looks quite neat, it has a Lisp flavour in its syntax and macro system but it is not a _Common Lisp_, its semantics conform to Lua semantics in most places.

> * **Full Lua compatibility:** Easily call any Lua function or library from Fennel and vice-versa.
> * **Zero overhead:** Compiled code should be just as or more efficient than hand-written Lua.
> * **Compile-time macros:** Ship compiled code with no runtime dependency on Fennel.
> * **Embeddable:** Fennel is a one-file library as well as an executable. Embed it in other programs to support runtime extensibility and interactive development.
>
> — _Source: [the Fennel programming language](https://fennel-lang.org/)_ 

It is quite neat and like Lua, it can run on a small ESP32 all the way to beefy server in a datacenter running OpenResty.

#### Examples of Fennel
The sample below is using [Löve](https://love2d.org) which is a game development library for Lua.
~~~
;; Sample: read the state of the keyboard and move the player accordingly
(local dirs {:up [0 -1] :down [0 1] :left [-1 0] :right [1 0]})

(each [key delta (pairs dirs)]
  (when (love.keyboard.isDown key)
    (let [[dx dy] delta
          [px py] player
          x (+ px (* dx player.speed dt))
          y (+ py (* dy player.speed dt))]
      (world:move player x y))))
~~~

Fennel is mostly built in Lua.

# [Urn](https://urn-lang.com/)
Urn is also a Lisp-like language for Lua. While Fennel is Lua in Lisp clothes, Urn is more into the Lisp-family being influenced by Common Lisp and Clojure.

> * A minimal¹ Lisp implementation, with full support for compile time code execution and macros.
> * Support for Lua 5.1, 5.2 and 5.3. Should also work with LuaJIT.
> * Lisp-1 scoping rules (functions and data share the same namespace).
> * Influenced by a whole range of Lisp implementations, including Common Lisp and Clojure.
> * Produces standalone, optimised Lua files: no dependencies on a standard library.
>
> — _Source: [Urn: A Lisp implementation for Lua | Urn](https://urn-lang.com/)_

#### Example of Urn
Who doesn't like pattern matching? All languages should have it by now...

~~~
> (case '("x" (foo 2 3))
.   [(string?  @ ?x) (.. "Got a string " x)]
.   [("x" (foo . ?x)) (.. "Got some remaining values " (pretty x))])
out = "Got some remaining values (2 3)"
~~~

Urn compiles to Lua but it is written in Common Lisp.

# [Amulet ML](https://amulet.works/)

Amulet ML is a functional language in the ML tradition (I love ML).

> * Generalised Algebraic Data Types (GADTs),
> * Multi-parameter type classes with associated types and functional dependencies, including support for quantified constraints,
> * Type functions supporting dependent kinds, and equality constraints,
> * Rank-N, impredicative types via Quick Look: ∀ quantifiers can appear anywhere in a type, not only the top-level,
> * Principled, extensible records via row polymorphism support inference of principal types. 
>
> — _Source: [Amulet ML](https://amulet.works/)_

#### Example of Amulet ML

~~~
let map f = function
| [] -> []
| Cons (x, xs) -> Cons (f x, map f xs)

let filter p xs = [ x | with x <- xs, p x ] 
~~~
    
* Minimalist syntax: semicolons, in and other noise is entirely optional.
* Pattern matching and guards make writing code more intuitive.
* List comprehensions are a short and sweet way of expressing complex computations on lists. 

Be aware that even though Amulet ML compiles to Lua, it is written basically in Haskell with some bits in SML and OCaml.

---
_Also available on: https://andregarzia.com/2020/06/languages-that-compile-to-lua.html_

# [Moonscript](https://moonscript.org/)

Moonscript has been around for a while (one of the reasons I forgot to add it to this post in my initial publication) and is stable and used in the industry, it is probably the most popular _compile to Lua_ language out there. I believe that a large part of [Itch.io](https://itch.io) is powered by moonscript and NginX. Moonscript feels like CoffeeScript but for Lua. If you pair it with the [Lapis](https://leafo.net/lapis/) web framework by the same author, you have a delightful setup to launch your next web application.

> MoonScript is a dynamic scripting language that compiles into Lua. It gives you the power of one of the fastest scripting languages combined with a rich set of features.
>
> — _Source: [MoonScript, a language that compiles to Lua](https://moonscript.org/)_

#### Example of Moonscript

```
class Thing
  name: "unknown"

class Person extends Thing
  say_name: => print "Hello, I am #{@name}!"

with Person!
  .name = "MoonScript"
  \say_name!
```

Moonscript is built with Lua and Moonscript itself (almost in equal parts).

Of course, it is science:

* `type 1 fun`: it is fun of the normal vanilla kind, boring fun.
* `type 2 fun`: fun when you survive it; also known as fun-after-the-fact. Usually the kind of story you tell at parties or around a campfire and leave your audience with open jaws, broken half-insane smiles, and a wonder if you're telling the truth.
* `type 3 fun`: fun by proxy; or fun when it happens to someone else. The kind of stuff you'll love to tell your friends about and both you and them will be glad it didn't happened to none of you.

There is ongoing research on further levels happening right now. All our data points are indicating a hidden tier 4 which appears to be some deep meta level of fun, some dark fun, hidden from scrutiny and research. It is still early to define it.

Sometimes I think about buying an old PowerPC Mac, installing MacOS 9, and creating a small island of computing peace for me. Often this idealized machine of retrocomfort morphs into a different device, and sometimes I with it was a G4 iMac running MorphOS, or an Amiga running AmigaOS 4.1.

I have realized long ago that it is not about the OS, but what you do with it. When running Windows/macOS/Linux/Haiku, I tend to approach the machine with a _current day; work mentality_ mindset and the machine quickly becomes boring and just a tool to help pay the bills. The current machines are not limited in any way that affects what I am talking about it, the limitation in this case lies in the user himself (_himself is defined as Andre, or SoapDog, or CoffeeFox for a more mathematically verifiable definition of Andre since we can't really prove he is a dog or made of soap, but we can prove his involvement with both foxes and coffee_). When given a machine that can be used to perform work related activities, I will think about working when using it. I will switch from whatever fun thing I am doing to explore work related activities outside my work hours. I need a _dream machine_ that is less powerful, or at least less capable, of doing my work so that I can enjoy it guiltless and without the constant context switch of thinking that I should alt-tab into work.

Mac OS 9 is a very comfortable OS for me. I used it for a long time and used to know the ins and outs of it. Still, many things I enjoy doing these days will eventually touch the Internet and without up to date crypto stuff, I can't really get such machines to work for the kind of tasks I know I will want to use them for, even though I haven't defined them yet.

Using old machines is also a constant exercise in repair and acquiring surplus. I did have a ton of stuff in Brazil but I don't plan to keep growing my collection of stuff in London. It is already too big. Because of that I noticed that I need to define better what exactly I want, so that I can learn what I need to buy or build.

[@hoodownr](@YND2Cb9uk3ZdFyzXpaXDH5HZ9udu+qjg4MhNcynK2RE=.ed25519) I think your friend (the one that is happier now) is further deep on a path that you'll soon follow. In that journey, I hope you find as many lighthearted experiences and friends as you want. That when you look back towards the path you came from, you can recall the good and bad from the past while experiencing more happiness and joy in the present.

### What do I want to do with it?

The meaning of _peaceful computing_ will vary from person to person, I have no clue what you find peaceful, I do know that most of my friends will have the wrong preconceived notion about what I think about it. Many will think that I want a machine I can program in peace. My friends tend to see myself as a software developer, which is also how I am often introduced to people, but I don't see myself as a software developer. Programming is something I do, something I have always done — always just mean more than 25 years in this case — but it is not who I am. I love to tinker and developing stuff is part of tinkering. I love to create, and programming is an act of creation. But, software development is my job and even though I work in a very peaceful environment, I don't regard working as a peaceful activity. Working is stressful by nature for me. Even when given agency over my projects, even with cool co-workers and a good task, working is always stressful.

I am at peace when I am writing. I see myself as a storyteller. A fox who drinks too much coffee, takes a bath, forgets to take all the soap off, puts on a costume of a dog, and goes out into the world telling amusing, and sometimes even truthful, stories. Even though social networks and feed algorithms are constantly driving us into despair and _doomscrolling_, I'm also happy when consuming blogs, feeds (specially from decentralized networks), and reading cool stuff. People in more realtime connection with me will know that I share lots of links and tend to know a lot about where the strange programming devices and languages are. I'm a hoarder of stories with an interest in programming, but I don't want my dream machine for programming. I have other machines for that purpose. I want a machine for reading and writing.

### A cyberdeck maybe?

To be able to consume the content I want, I need a machine that is able to connect to the modern decentralized platforms and the web. This makes old retrocomputing machines less interesting as a ton of time would actually be used into getting them online and browsing the content I want instead of actually enjoying reading and writing. Because of that I have been gravitating towards building a cyberdeck. I could go quite fancy with it with a planck keyboard, and be guaranteed to have a ton of inspiration material available.

As I journeyed deeper into this cyberdeck forest, I realized a very important thing: **the computer doesn't actually matter**.

### It is not about the computer

A cyberdeck running Linux with XFCE is just another computer for me to wonder if I should actually be working. What is important to me is the interface. I want an interface that keeps `$dayjob` away and let me be a storyteller and a listener. This interface can be built on top of `$whatever`, it doesn't really matter, and it can be built using the computers I already own. Once, I'm happy with it, if I feel the need, I can transport it into a cyberdeck for added coolness. 

I think I know what I want to build...

[@cel-desktop](@lOUVT+Phkvai9a/cCS/RKo+S9hnPAQdVixms/7ldpPA=.ed25519),

> How much or how often do you use patchfoo?

I used patchfoo weekly on my Surface Go and Macbook but I haven't been using it on my Surface Pro X because of friction in installing it.

> What do you like about patchfoo?

Everything but what I like the most is that using it feels like a conversation with my friend Cel. The code and the application UX feel Cel-ish. I wouldn't classify it as minimalist because it is definitely not minimal, it is actually very complete, but it doesn't contain superfluous parts and fluff for the sake of fluff. It is dense in the sense of packing a ton of functionality in a tight package. Once you have it installed, it works quite well.

One thing I like that I haven't seen replicated elsewhere is the live view.

> What about patchfoo do you wish was different?

The installing procedure. I'd really appreciate if there was either a zip with all dependencies bundled shared over SSB, or an reliable HTTP GIT endpoint for me to clone. I had lots of problems sorting out the installation of Patchfoo before on my non-standard machines.

> If patchfoo was rewritten, what features or functionality would you want kept? Which would you want removed or do you not care about? What would you want changed or added?

I don't know if this is a rhetorical question to gauge priority for feature work or if you are actually thinking about rewriting it. Anyway, I like it the way it is but I'd like to have some better way to mention people. Maybe a `<datalist>` could work.

> What do you think patchfoo development should focus on next (short term), and in the medium and/or long term?

* Short term: better way to mention people.
* Medium term: easier installation.
* Long term: themes (I know, it is not as important but I like Oasis themes), and those miniapps that you have.

> Would you recommend patchfoo to a friend? Why or why not?

I would recommend it to a tech friend or to a friend who I know is willing to go to their terminal. I'm OK with recommending it to friends using platforms that I know you're shipping binary installers.

> Is there anything else you want to say? 

I really appreciate all the hard work you have put into Patchfoo and the rest of SSB. You're an awesome person and I think this reflects in things beyond coding.

I built my first computer connected coffee machine in 1998 using a 386, Minix, Pascal, and parallel port with badly bent pins. The machine was involved in a weird late 90s _automation_ (neé IoT) catastrophy. There was mechanical arm built by another person which was supposed to take out the coffee cup from my machine and place in a remote controlled skateboard for serving, unfortunately it was positioning the cups wrong and getting everything wet. He started experimenting with other objects that were lying on the table, such as a 9V battery as replacement for the cup, just to try to position the battery in the correct location. Someone in his team changed a `+ 10` to something like `* 10` and the arm actually threw off the 9V battery across the table.

Mind you that my machine had no casing, it was just a bunch of wires connecting an exposed 386 board and power supply to a half disassembled coffee maker. The flying battery hit my machine, causing a short as it displaced some of the wiring, including the 110V supply to the coffee maker...

So yes, that description of me is accurate and matches my late 90s self, thank you very much for it, also I believe BeBoxes are for making multiple cocktails at once, a superb machine, ahead of its time.

One thing I love about Racket is meta languages.

The most useful I have met so far is [at-exp](https://docs.racket-lang.org/scribble/reader-internals.html?q=at-exp#%28mod-path._at-exp%29). When you augment a language declaration with the `at-exp` language you can use _@-forms_ in the source code. So instead of

```
#lang racket
```

At the top of the file, I can use:

```
#lang at-exp racket
```

and then be able to program both using S-expressions, like:

```
(define (hello name) (string-append "hello " name))
```

and using @-expressions:

```
(define (hello name) @string-append{Hello, @|name|.})
```

Which is much better because it can handle multiline strings with interpolation quite well.
