_comments from [Some tentative guidelines for GUI composability](https://hackernoon.com/some-tentative-guidelines-for-gui-composability-2900abead1d9):_

> When I’m trying to solve a problem with a CLI, I write a tiny shell script whose UI is extremely specific to the problem I’m trying to solve, and I do it in a minute or less. I do it incrementally. My command line environment really does operate like a hollywood UI.

I do exactly that with LiveCode. Often when I need a quick script to do a specific task, you know the kind of throwaway script that people will write in perl/python, I launch LiveCode and do it graphically. I have worked with it for more than 10 years — all the way back to MacOS 9 when it was still called Runtime Revolution — and I can craft throwaway stacks in it faster than I can write the equivalent in a cli based scripting language.

> If the average GUI app was like the average shell function (i.e., made in minutes by someone who isn’t an expert, slowly honed over years, and never intended to be able to be used by anyone else), we’d basically have that future. The catch is to make doing that kind of stuff as easy as the unix command line is. We only don’t have it because GUI toolkits are so bad that it takes an expert a long time to write a shitty app — leading to a situation where GUI apps are required to be general-purpose, stable, and unexpressive, in order to make up for the labor that went into them.

For me this is the key point and it is not related to GUI but to _data exchange formats_. The powerful substrate that makes UNIX command line tools so composable is that they are basically all working with plain-text input and output and it becomes easier to pass data around. Even when it is not plan-text data you, as the scripter, are aware of what data is coming out of one app and going into the other. Powershell from Microsoft is an attempt to evolve this by making commands and scripts all work with objects. I can't tell if it is better, I never really got into it, but the idea is sound: instead of plain-text, rich objects and the building blocks to work with them.

Because most GUI toolkits are islands, there is no _easy to use_ and _well defined and understood_ way to exchange data between GUI apps anymore. You can't really launch a simple GUI app and tell, hey drive the output of you to that other app. That was not always the case, in the past AppleScript could do just that and you could pipe output from one GUI app to another, all orchestrated by an easy to use scripting language. I remember crafting scripts to create HTML galleries, they'd actually launch photoshop and remote drive it to process the photos. It all felt natural.

All this was only possible because the operating system vendor cared. They'd ship a technology (AppleScripts and AppleEvents) that allowed GUI apps to communicate with one another. An app could send an AppleEvent to another app, direct exchange of data. AppleScript could orchestrate these events. 

As a developer, you could craft your GUI app normally, and add AppleEvent handlers so that it could exchange data with other apps, then add a _dictionary_ to the app that would match these events with an English-like language thus creating custom commands for AppleScript. Then you can have scripts like:

```applescript
tell application "Adobe Photoshop CS4"
  set OldRuler to ruler units of settings
  set ruler units of settings to percent units
  tell document 1
    resize image width thePercent
  end tell
  set ruler units of settings to OldRuler
end tell
```

**Without a sane way to exchange data, there is no way to build composable GUIs.**

Now, for the rest of this post, I will cease quoting and commenting from [@enkiv2](@Q6jeOaoJOdFq8/3oFaOYC6bKhaVCD3IIdpjG+7Fab2M=.ed25519) article and just type my ideas about how LiveCode applies to what they outlined there.

---

LiveCode ticks many boxes in those guidelines but not all of them. The main problem is that those guidelines assume an object-oriented widget system, something that LiveCode is not. Much like HyperCard was not object oriented in the Java/C++ sense, so is LiveCode. You have graphical widgets but those are not classes and instances. They are just objects.

LiveCode IDE is built with LiveCode and it has hooks for plugins, it is very common for seasoned developers to just extend it with their own plugins (or third-party plugins, there is a market for it). Some will go as far as customizing the IDE itself to the point that it is no longer recognizable. A friend of mine who is very design oriented has a LC IDE that resembles photoshop.

Most of the guidelines in the article will apply if you stay inside LiveCode. If you treat the IDE as a VM and launch different stacks in it, then you can compose stuff by firing data from one stack to another. It can be as easy as:

```
dispatch "resizeImage" to stack "imageTools" with myImageData
```

You can create new widgets but not as a _subclass_ for there are no objects. In the old days, new widgets would actually be groups of other objects. You can design them as you see fit, group them, and share the group around. A lot of LC is groups. These days you also have a widget API and a low-level compiled language called _LiveCode Builder_ that allows you to do FFI and low-level drawing in a language similar to _LiveCode Script_. This is how the current  _WebView widget_ is implemented, it is a _LiveCode Builder_ module that uses _CEF_ to direct draw the webview into the stack at the rect specified. Oh, a stack is just a window. Think of it as a deck of cards, each card is a view.

LiveCode is a live environment, there is no compile-run-debug cycle. I can switch tools from the design tool to the interaction tools and use my stack. When you compile something, you're just bundling the engine with your stack in a self-contained deployable way that doesn't carry the superfluous stuff such as the IDE and non-used libraries.

_This post is getting a bit large, I'll post it now and continue in a new one with examples of my usage._

Just some examples of my day to day use of LiveCode:

### A stupid stack to tell me the coords for a sprite

In the book I've just written, I'm using a spritesheet of hundreds of sprites. In the Phaser API I need to refer to them by their index in the sheet. Of course I can't remember which index is which sprite, so I built a stupid stack that displays the spritesheet and when I click on a sprite it tells me the index.

![image.png](&ZbzIw7MikGBJspD4kADYQrIY1jXBQz6VVW1bg9P5v14=.sha256)
_It is ugly like a throwaway script._

The only source code is a _mouseDown_ handler in the image itself:

```livecode
on mousedown
   put item 1 of the mouseloc into x
   put item 2 of the mouseloc into y
   
   put ((x div 17)+1) + (((y div 17))*32)
end mousedown
```

This helped me get through writing the book. Creating such script with a CLI tool is harder.

### Converting and reconciling files

We have a little virtual tour in our page, more like a gallery actually, and it is made of flat files on disk. For each point of interest in this tour, there is a folder with multiple images and metadata files in it. To reconcile this data out of previous dumps from other legacy systems, I made a throwaway stack.

To build it I used a pattern that I have been using for years. I create a single form. Fields and other controls in this form are used to host the data I'll be manipulating. Buttons will trigger the manipulation functions. This way I can experiment with a single record before doing bulk stuff. Once I am happy, I create a large list with all the records. In this case the list contains the folder names. Clicking a button will drive the stack by clicking the first item on that list and then clicking the buttons it need to click, then proceeding to click the second item of that list, and so on. It is similar to selenium or marionette, I have some code that will work on the data and code that will drive the interaction. Once I click _do all_ I can sit and watch the stack drive itself.

A bonus of doing things like this is that instead of having just a text script that does bulk transformations and rely on other apps to inspect the data, I have a single window that can be used to inspect the data, convert and amend a single record, and do the bulk operation I need.

![image.png](&RwoerxV51x+l/x3lMr8NmLI5xsAiHWF5TyVokWtq7bI=.sha256)
_As can be seen, this was not meant to be seen by anyone else, it is just a throwaway tool._

The code to drive the stack is cute:

```livecode
on mouseup
   get the number of lines in field "points"
   repeat with x = 1 to it
      set the hilitedline of field "points" to x
      dispatch "mouseup" to field "points"
      wait 50 millisecs with messages
   end repeat
end mouseup
```

---

And is how I use LiveCode to create small scripts and GUI tools for my personal use. They are not meant to be shared, and sometimes they are not even mean to be used again once when the job is done. If there is anything clever in those stacks, something I feel I will reuse or I want to share, I can quickly extract it into a more polished library or tool.

1. Discover new programming language.
2. Fall in love with some feature or characteristic of said language.
3. Start building little toys with it.
4. Get observed by the muses up in the godly realm.
5. The muses press the "go into the wrong path" button in my control panel.

# SoapDog's Honest Guide About Advanced Sailing

![photo_2020-08-03_19-43-05.jpg](&S0Prq2AD9XpNpVbTNM0Aqfcc+f9k/sPIw2+ZTWudjos=.sha256)

![photo_2020-08-03_19-43-12.jpg](&aeFoIste2sWpmJOSugdsyCleATV4rwJeX6MzCBuYbm8=.sha256)

![photo_2020-08-03_19-43-07.jpg](&TcQHRgLtfDGMju0+zjwJdEVtRlwcus43AiIQmyDb1qY=.sha256)

This is such an advanced topic that it required three pages to explain. I'm a seasoned sailor who's kept his derrière safe from wind-related math problems for 40 years, AMA.
[@andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519) just answered your previous question.
[@IBob](@vkdMlsuBgzzo5eLS3LZLdqnBpZ26OauJOMIq9gQ2E7E=.ed25519) omg, poor boat! I've been there many times as well.

[@cblgh](@C6fAmdXgqTDbmZGAohUaYuyKdz3m6GBoLLtml3fUn+o=.ed25519) if you imagine a zig-zag, then each vertex is when a tacking maneuver happens. A series of tacking is what gets you upwind. I think in English they call that "beating", I don't know since most of my sail jargon comes from Portuguese and the Portuguese have been sailing for a while. 

### Tacking violents cousin: the jibe.

You can also go downwind in a sort zig-zag motion using Jibes (or Gybe if UK). Both tacking and jibing look similar when drawn, just the boats direction is changed. In one the boat is beating upwind, and in the other the boat is flying fucking fast downwind. What is hard to convey with jibing is that the "violence" of it. Imagine the boat a an angle going downwind, with it's sail full of air. Now, if you change direction (like exposing the other cheek), the sail will need to change to the other side of the boat. That sail was full and now it is angry, it move violently to the other side of the boat, with its boon (the other wooden/aluminum pole that is attached to the mast as a 90 degrees angle) sweeping across the deck while everyone ducks. I learned to be terrified of Jibes as a kid since the "becoming part of the crew" ritual included being thrown overboard when the boon hit your head during a Jibe. I have no idea how we all survived to adulthood. We're all became great swimmers thought (great as in not dying in the water, not as in winning competition).

Here is a video of a jibe:

Take this with a grain of salt as I am not expert and most of what I learned about this was when I was 13 years old and I'm now 40. A lot have happened and I might be mistaken, but if I remember correctly:

The sail can work in different modes, it can be a wall pushed by the wind, or it can be something different that is not actually being pushed by the wind at all. As with most things it is a complex problem. In that case the sail is acting more like an airplane wing with its shape and aerodynamics creating a pressure difference between the side that is exposed to the wind and the other side.  Just like wings in the plane will keep it flying, the sail in the boat will create a lift force and move the boat. That is lifting vs dragging and as far as I remember lifting is faster. 

Physics was never my strong suit, so summary: Boats with keels are dishonest beings, they're wet but they pretend to be airplanes. They learned aikido from an old Japanese sailmaster and thus are able to use the enemy forces against them. They shape their sails like airplane wings, using a delicate equilibrium between lift from the aerodynamics of the sail, drag from the boats mass, resistance from the keel, to end up moving away even faster from their problems.

Sorry, I'm not yet ready to implement themes. The way patchfox works is that it is a collection of small packages. It is not unlike a linux distro. Every thing you see is a "package" and at any time in the screen there might be multiple packages loaded. For example, I'm replying to you using Patchfox, this means that the package `post` is loaded and I'm using it's `compose` view. At the same time that is loaded, there is a navigation menu on top which is courtesy of package "globalMenu", you get the idea.

The CSS kit used is [Spectre.css](https://picturepan2.github.io/spectre/index.html) which does not support dark mode out of the box. I could tweak the SASS to do it in the future. There is an [augmented-ui](https://augmented-ui.com/) CSS addition to make Patchfox looks cool as well. I'm barely using it but I like how it looks.

Many packages carry their own CSS changes inside their views (the views are just [Svelte](https://svelte.dev) components). Usually these `<style>` blocks don't contain colors though. 

So in essence, I never prepared this project for easy themeing and made some decisions that make it a bit harder to do. If you want a client that supports dark themes, I recommend you checkout Oasis and Patchwork.

# Release 2020.8.1

## Major feature: More Info

Learn more about it in [%UbK6ZACB6uFJU0+JDHtnvPW1mV2c2QAq3dXYnKkmcFg=.sha256](ssb:message/sha256/UbK6ZACB6uFJU0%2BJDHtnvPW1mV2c2QAq3dXYnKkmcFg%3D).

## Fixes:

* **Core Components:**
    * LAYOUT: hovering an `AvatarTile` now shows a pointer cursor.
    * MAYBE FEATURE: changed the `VoteCounter` to require a click before fetching votes. The amount of `ssb-ws` calls flying around in a message list was too damn high.  
* **Hub:**
    * LAYOUT: changed the size of message id display on top of thread.
    * LAYOUT: optimized the text on the top of channel display options.
    * FEATURE: the channel view has a new option to show only root messages.

The _half_ part of the release name is because I haven't implemented the _export to vCard_ feature yet. I believe that feature will take a couple days to nail down, I'll do it next week. For now you can add _more info_ data to a contact and view the data, that is already unique and useful.

----

_This was posted with Oasis because working on a browser allows me to run Oasis and Patchfox at the same time._

I'm having a really bad moment regarding all the news about the recent Mozilla layoffs. Most of my friends have been fired. I'm just waiting to learn from two of them but since I already know their teams are gone, I expect them to be a part of the Mozilla Lifeboat now.

For the past seven years Mozilla has been an important part of my life. I have been a Mozilla Rep, an employee, and a Mozilla TechSpeaker. It feels like Mozilla is this beautiful dream that is unfortunately plagued by incompetent managers. And even know they are to blame, so are we. Many in the web development love Mozilla but they don't use Mozilla products, they think their love is enough. It is not. What we are seeing is the consequence of the marketshare of Firefox. Declining marketshare leads to less money, with less money you can't maintain a multinational dream of a better web alive. 

People are angry at Moz, I am angry at them too. But, there is no other vendor out there that cares for you. Apple, Google, Microsoft, none of them have the heart of Mozilla. Being angry and shouting: "I'm going to migrate to Chrome!" is actually just conceding and making the problem worse. Without Mozilla, there is only corporate America shipping web browsers. Is this the world we want?

As I said, Mozilla has a heart that no other browser vendor has, but that heart is broken. Many of teams who were on the leading edge of tech and on the day to day life of all web developers have just been fired. Servo, DevTools, DevRel, all gone. All those people who spent years if not decades trying their best to make a "web for everyone and by everyone" will join ranks with startups, Google, Apple, and Microsoft. They'll be better paid, and probably be safer a job perspective point of view. I have no doubt that such competent people will find new places to work. But, the web, our dear web will suffer.

It is quite like you say. It is really impressive how well Firefox compares to Chrome considering how small the team is. Mozilla has always been much more than a browser vendor. Its work regarding net neutrality and privacy is fantastic. It has been a force for good, but people would keep seeing banners on GMail saying _"Install Chrome!"_; Apple prevented all browser engines from landing on iOS; Microsoft bundled a decent browser... It is hard to compete when all your competitors have infinite money and their browser is not tied to their success. 

People hold Mozilla to impossible standards. They shout, cry, denounce, and create a flamewar about the most simple things, but will happily work for Facebook. I'm not saying people can't work for Facebook, what I am saying is that people apply values and expectation to Mozilla that they themselves don't follow. That makes it even harder for Mozilla to do anything.

Heck the DevTools and MDN teams were awesome. They often would give us workshops and mentor us during TechSpeaker meetups. I don't even know if we still have a TechSpeakers program. Maybe my program has been disbanded as well.

[@Grey 🜨](@JoiN9c9+xO0jgu0gg5yflTf+L1peLTBneFHjrKbmcKo=.ed25519) if this Mozilla has trouble maintaining a browser even with millions in the bank and 500+ employees, what hope a new inexperienced org has of carrying the torch?

Browsers and internet lobbying are games for deep pockets and experienced teams. I know it is not very romantic to say that but the chances of some new crew picking Firefox code and actually being able to improve and maintain it is very low IMHO.

[@Cy](@60jitr5ZbnEFQf0NjcZ6zi2NIAKL40lrFqo2SiiHn1I=.ed25519),

Even though I empathize with you and your frustration, that analysis of the situation doesn't represent the full picture. Believe me, I hate HTTP/2 and CSRF with all my anger. I came to realize some things in the last couple years when I started diving deeper into these browser vendor discussions and processes. The items you list there in your message are features that I have seen outlined as bloat time and time again. I have been in this conversations before and I will outline some arguments for each of the things you mention there. Please don't take this personally, this is not an attack on your opinions or a minimization of your frustrations or the problem, it is just that I was there before and after a ton of discussion came to explanations for most of what you mention.


### Javascript enabled
People need to get over with the hatred against JS. You don't need JS to create simple content sites like your blog and stuff, but you definitely need it for webapplications. Most of what we enjoy about the current web is actually JS stuff. JavaScript engines are fast, not bloated, provide good safety, and the language is approachable.

What you're actually complaining is probably regarding _the amount of JS a given page is sending to your browser_ which is usually a symptom of trackers and profilers. I would bet you have nothing against a lean web application that uses JS but is nimble and frugal.

Without JS you need to do server side rendering and multiple page refreshes, all of which are more wasteful on poor networking conditions. Anyone that wants the democratization of the web and is in fact in favour of getting the next billion people online should not be against JS. The infrastructure of networking and providing a stable, cheap, and good connection to people is much harder and costlier than providing a SoC that can run JS. Things like IndexedDB, Service Workers and PWA work much more in favour of getting more people online and positioning smaller players to succeed than a web without JS.

With JS you can ship a hyper-local PWA to people who need it without gatekeepers and without paying licenses to anyone. It is an agency unlocking technology and should be treated like that.

### WebGL accelerated
WebGL is a hard spec to implement, I totally agree with you. But again I must touch into the topic of agency. WebGL allows rich interactive applications to be deployed on the web without gatekeepers. The potential for it is yet to be realized but the foundation is solid. Gaming is one of the stronger industries in IT and entertainment. WebGL enable game developers to ship quality content on the web. 

This is all part of making the Web a viable multimedia environment. Having access to low-level WebGL allows you to create new forms of streaming and multimedia content which you would not be able to if all the browser had as an opaque rect binding to a native library.

WebGL is part of what made possible for us to remove the dependency in native binary plugins like flash. This made the web more secure and resilient. 

#### HTTP/2 upgrading, 

Be aware that I hate HTTP/2, QUIC, and all that kind of stuff too. What I am writing here is why that was done, in some cases I don't really agree in a deeper level but I understand why browser vendors did it. We need to blame fucking Google.

HTTP 1.x (aka the last true HTTP IMHO) is unidirectional. You can pause requests and stream requests but you can't using a single request send multiple resources. Google in its overly engineered usual ways wanted to make GMail and other Google apps more performant and they decided that replacing HTTP was a good idea, they could craft a new protocol that could do multiplexing and lots of other byte juggling to make those apps speedier. Since they control both ends of this cable, they could implement this on their server and also on their browser in tandem. 

What happened was that Google apps were indeed performing better with the new protocols. Which means it is _death due to a thousand paper cuts_ all over again. Users saw the marketing machine saying Chrome performed better than the competition, they tried it out, and it was true. The other browsers started losing users, they had to scramble to make that protocol a standard because they needed to implement it so that they'd stop losing users.

This is basically FAANG forcing a technology onto vendors because they are strong and you can either comply or die. I hate it too but that is how it happened. If Firefox didn't implemented the new protocol, users would migrate.

### CSRF enforcing, 

Phishing is a real problem. The Web has maintained a strong security model over the years that if you think about how the whole Web actually came to be becomes even more impressive. Browser vendors need to be proactive regarding malware because they are the last line of defense. Without mechanisms like that it becomes too easy to fuck the user.

### Pocket installing, 

Pocket is nothing but a WebExtension. Firefox bundles a bunch of them. It is not bloat, it doesn't add to Firefox codebase in any meaningful way. People don't want Mozilla to die but also don't want Mozilla to try to investigate potential alternatives to make money. Apparently the only way to win this game is not playing...

Pocket begun at a addons hackathon at Mozilla, grew to be a startup, and then returned home to be owned by Mozilla. It provides good features. I for example use it a lot to send articles from the web to my Kobo device. You're not forced to use it and it doesn't alter the browser.

### telemetry transmitting

Without telemetry browser vendors are blind. Everyone want vendors to respond quickly to security emergencies and to have a clear picture of their user base, without telemetry this is impossible.  You need it to discover bugs beyond what your QA team can actually cover. You know that poor combination of Linux libraries in some niche distro that causes multimedia content not to work? Well telemetry is what will flag that even if you don't fill a bug report.

Telemetry is also how you measure adoption and feature usage so that you know what to prioritize when working. If all of your users ignore history management but they all are having a hard time bookmarking pages and navigating those bookmarks, you know where you should put your efforts.

You want strategic decisions from the part of your browser vendor. Small teams can be quite effective if they have data to back and inform their plans. Without telemetry there is no data to verify whatever plan someone thinks is a good idea.

### keypress overriding, click disabling, download preventing, advertisement popping, 

That blame is all in the owners of whatever content you're browsing. The web works well but if whoever crafted the webapp you're accessing decided that those behaviors is what they want, maybe you should let them know that it is not ok.

(continues)

(continued)


### gigantic kitchen sink web browsers.

Many people still approach web browsers as if they were document viewers. From that point of view of course the web is bloated. It is time people understand that what we call web browsers are actually very capable multimedia virtual machines. You use it to fetch and run apps from the ethereal storage that is the Web. They have much more in common to the JVM/Inferno OS/BeIA than they do with Acrobat Reader and other document viewers.

The browser is a virtual machine, HTML5 is the OS. The GUI toolkit sucks. 

## final remarks

As I said I empathize with the frustrations but you and other people need to realize that without the features we often complain about, people would just migrate to browsers that offer such features. If Firefox didn't implement EME it wouldn't run Netflix. Then users would migrate to Chrome to use Netflix and Firefox would crumble even more. Without WebGL all the rich interactivity and fluid graphics wouldn't work, people would move to Chrome to use it. Without CSRF and other security stuff, Firefox would be weaker, people would migrate to Chrome because it was safer. Without telemetry Mozilla would not be able to react quickly to problems, the browser would become weaker, people would migrate... rinse, repeat.

We want independent vendors to compete, they can only do that if users can use the sites they want in the browser. If they can only use the browser for 60% of the sites they need, they will simply use another browser and whatever champion you had in Mozilla would be gone and all that would be left is corporate solutions.

[@interfect](@3wl2IivU+ghWlZj4psiRMQlcOKV9iLbXbNIb1wv+0/M=.ed25519),

> I’ve been tinkering around with a Fenix fork with a longer allowed extension list. Forking and rebranding the browser is a job for about 3-5 enthusiasts to do it properly, I think, with all the infrastructure you need for builds and updates.

If all your fork is doing is changing branding assets, then yes it is damn easy. Just write a new mozConfig that points to new assets and fire your build. Now, if you're changing anything then you're screwed. There is a reason why those Firefox forks that are trying to maintain the old addon APIs and XUL can't merge security updates with ease. It is a damn hard job.

The only Firefox forks who were actually properly maintained were Tor Browser and Cliqz Browser and the common thing is that both had money and didn't change Firefox much.

[@Cy](@60jitr5ZbnEFQf0NjcZ6zi2NIAKL40lrFqo2SiiHn1I=.ed25519),

I like that you're passionate about it and I think there are many projects that share your vision and values. Believe me, I don't feel you're attacking me at all, I'm totally OK (well, I am not OK but for other reasons rsrsrs, with you I am OK).

I'll avoid the ping point of doing points and counterpoints between our arguments, even though I'd gladly have a beer or coffee and go over it with you if we ever meet in an event. Unfortunately text messages are bad medium for carrying emotional value and it becomes harder to infer tone and priority. I am not a native English speaker and sometimes I feel I sound way harsher than I am, but that is just me digressing, sorry.

I disagree with some of the arguments you explained above and completely agree with others. The most important part of what I have said previously, which I hope you understand is that with the changes you are asking for Firefox would end up with almost zero users. You would like it and so would many others who share this vision of a different web but the average web user who wants to do home banking, watch netflix, buy stuff online, check their social network and friends, and play .io games would migrate to another browser.

Without users Mozilla loses political power. It can't influence the web or help steer it towards its values unless it has enough users to back it up. With those changes you have a nice product for those that believe that JS is evil but you don't have something that benefits the web user because they won't use it.

The Web is compromise. It is much like the U.N., there are powerful forces in place and whatever is decided is guaranteed to anger a lot of people. There are a lot of good people trying to steer the web into a direction that we would all recognize as having the best interest of common people in mind but it will always end in a compromise because that is how committees with multiple stakeholders who not necessarily want the same thing work.

What you want is not Firefox, at that point is not even Mozilla. From your arguments, and my comprehension of them and my very shallow knowledge of you, I think you're probably more aligned and happier with FSF/GNU projects and I believe there is a ton to of good actions to do there.

Let Mozilla be Mozilla and keep trying to play the political game. It is way harder than many people realize. Let other projects sprout in other organisations that share the values you're mentioning. For example, you sound like you'd appreciate using #Gemini and tilde communities, I think we have that in common.

Another project that I suspect you might like to contribute is Dillo. It is a fantastic tiny browser that tick many of the boxes you mentioned in this thread. I am sure they'd appreciate more contributors.

The cool thing about the web is that it is retrocompatible and crossplatform. We can work on small browser with the constraints we want and still talk to the larger web.

# Complicated Standards Lead to Implementation Monopolies

An article I found in a Gemini pod at:

🚀gemini://ebc.li/posts/open-standards-are-simple.gmi
🕸 https://portal.mozz.us/gemini/ebc.li/posts/open-standards-are-simple.gmi (webby version via proxy)

> "Since implementing a complex standard is hard, you will eventually end up with the implementation that started the earliest and maintained since, being the only implementation that is actually usable. And that implementation will most likely be the one created by the standard's creators.
>
> In cases where the standard's creators don't maintain an implementation like "the web"⁰, the only choices are either the standard dying out because of it's complexity, or the actively maintained implementations requiring tons of effort, with (most likely) companies backing said implementations." — from the article

I think this is a very good read.

Trying to come up with a build script for #fafi-browser. Racket is at the same time quite easy and quite opaque. It all makes sense once you finally learn it but it can be a forest of strange forms until you do. At the moment I am still a bit lost.

My build script is not working at the moment. It builds the standalone distributable app, all the files appear to be there, but it doesn't work. I can see that it launches the Racket engine because it shows `Racket v7.7` banner if I run in verbose mode `./Fafi.exe -v`. This shouldn't happen as Fafi has it's own verbose mode and banner. I suspect that this distribution assembly is somehow missing my `main` module.

Anyway, even if it doesn't work I think that showing the script here is a worthy act because I want to make you folks curious about Racket. Here it is:

```Lisp
#lang racket/base

(require compiler/cm
         compiler/distribute
         compiler/embed
         launcher/launcher
         racket/class
         racket/draw
         racket/file
         racket/math
         racket/port
         racket/string
         racket/system
         "config.rkt")

(define app-exe-file "Fafi.exe")


(define (compile-app)
  (managed-compile-zo "./main.rkt"))


(define (build-app)
  (parameterize
      ([use-compiled-file-paths (list "compiled")])
    (create-embedding-executable
     app-exe-file
     #:modules '((#f "./main.rkt"))
     #:gracket? #t
    )))

(define (make-distribution)
  (assemble-distribution
   "dist"
   (list app-exe-file)))

(module+ main

  ;; If this file is invoked from the command line, the application will be
  ;; built automatically (including the installer)
  (printf "Compiling .zo files...")(flush-output (current-output-port))
  (compile-app)
  (printf " done.")(newline)(flush-output (current-output-port))
  (printf "Building application executable...")(flush-output (current-output-port))
  (build-app)
  (printf " done.")(newline)(flush-output (current-output-port))
  (printf "Assembling distribution...")(flush-output (current-output-port))
  (make-distribution)
  (printf " done.")(newline)(flush-output (current-output-port)))
```

As you can infer from the script, in Racket we can actually load the compiler as a module and act as if we were DrRacket itself. You have access to a ton of stuff, the hardest part is actually understanding how all this work together and which bits you need.

[@Stardust](@P2lREv/l9EuyFCyNAcTjLV5T25yXKJ3D5GoPtoJQ3Tc=.ed25519),

 > That seems to be interesting. Is preventing browser monopoly a goal?

Yes, it is on our charter under the _Impossible Goals_ section.

Now, honestly, there is no such thing as preventing browser monopoly anymore because no one can actually build a full web engine from unless they are filthy rich and have time machine. That boat has sailed. We can still create tiny browsers for more fun and nimble protocols though, and for subsets of the web.

[@Stardust](@P2lREv/l9EuyFCyNAcTjLV5T25yXKJ3D5GoPtoJQ3Tc=.ed25519),

* There used to be [XULRunner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XULRunner). This is the runtime in which Firefox, Thunderbird and many other projects were built with. Think of Electron but before Electron. It was initially released in 2006 and discontinued in 2015 with the move to the new Firefox stuff (there were good reasons for dumping it). The apps were built with a combination of web technologies and XUL which was another XML-based language to build interfaces.
* There was [positron](https://github.com/mozilla/positron) which was Electron but with Gecko instead of WebKit. It was also cancelled.
* There was [webrt](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Apps/WebRT) which was a runtime that allowed installing open web applications (aka the FirefoxOS apps) in macOS, Windows, Linux, and Android. It predates PWAs, and open web apps would appear in the desktop/android as their own app. It was cancelled and removed in 2016.

Mozilla has shipped many Electron alternatives over the years. Most of them predate Electron and many are (IMHO) better than Electron. It didn't work, they never got traction.

[@mark](@2uAvsruiAF9rFC20OUZWc/Da+6q1HqY0GQjwmyVUZ4w=.ed25519),

There is no wasm without first having a JS engine. Real-world wasm apps depend a lot on JS standard library. JS-in-wasm ends up with two garbage collectors running, you don't want that. Wasm is not yet ready for running dynamic-language interpreters.

If I was you I wouldn't target the web, or even a subset of it. It is really fun to work with other protocols. Check out #gemini and #gopher.

[@mark](@2uAvsruiAF9rFC20OUZWc/Da+6q1HqY0GQjwmyVUZ4w=.ed25519),

I find wasm really cool as well. Originally my thesis for my undergrad degree was a scheme to wasm compiler but I had to drop out and was never able to actually do it. I think that the thing that makes more sense for the job you described is implementing WASI which I assume you're already doing. It will be really cool to see some more wasm stuff in here.

As for Gemini being "in development", all protocols are in development as far as I am aware. I don't think Gemini will see much change in the near future, it is basically already good for what it proposes to do. The spec is damn easy, I could implement a passable browser in a single day, and then spend the whole next week fixing bugs in that code I hastily cobbled together on that fun day. I really recommend doing it. [@RangerMauve](@tdeT1cU3xUQaD2Ne5Ox0Dndly50qS+c5+//Fl7tyPqg=.ed25519) just added support for it in their Agregore browser and all the modules are open source, you might want to take a look as it is closer to the environment you're using than the stuff I am doing.

One cool thing about the Gemini ecosystem is that since it is damn easy to build there are a ton of mini clients, all of them open source and done in many different languages. I think that a Gemini client will become my _hello world_ sample for when I am learning a new language.

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) I like the idea of starting small and working these selected modules at first. ### Fafi has tabs and history now

![video:2020-08-20_12-58-43.mp4](&ZMg+8WTjnonPnWqely+D9LZ59gVEutPO5rjSwPSdKg8=.sha256)

Even though there are tabs in the interface, fafi uses a unified history queue. Most web browsers use a per-tab history but implementing that was more complicated and I didn't felt like doing it. The history dialog is bare-bones, it just displays the `history-backward` list. 

That dialog implementation uses only 34 lines of bad racket programming:

```lisp
#lang racket/gui

(define history-window
  (new frame%
       [label "History"]
       [width 400]
       [height 600]
       [x 100]
       [y 100]))

(define (new-tab) (void))  

(define list-box (new list-box%  
                      [parent history-window]
                      [label "Double click to open the URL in a new tab"]
                      [choices '()]
                      [style (list 'single
                                   'column-headers
                                   'vertical-label)]
                      [columns (list "URL")]
                      [callback (lambda (c e)
                                  (when (eq? (send e get-event-type) 'list-box-dclick)
                                    (define url (send list-box get-string-selection))
                                    (new-tab url)
                                    (send history-window show #f)))]))

(define (show-history-window history callback)
  (set! new-tab callback)
  (send list-box set (remove-duplicates history))
  (send list-box set-column-width 0 360 360 360)
  (send history-window show #t))

(provide show-history-window)
```

The main window calls `(show-history-windows history-backwards new-tab)`.

Another day, another moment Mozilla fucked up.

So, I have been a part of an amazing program for the past 5 years — Mozilla TechSpeakers — we were volunteers who roamed the world speaking about the wonders of the open web. I am one of the original members of the TechSpeakers program, it started with five of us.

Today Mozilla shut us down. We all knew the end was coming when they fired the whole team who managed us. The problem is that they fucked up the shutting down of our program. They basically used [half a sentence in a blog post](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2020/08/an-update-on-mdn-web-docs/). No thank you, not even a description of our program. We were 100+ volunteers being speakers, workshopers, keynote presenters, in conferences large and small, and we learned we were shutting down at the same time the rest of the world by an impersonal blog post. 

The lack of empathy in that post and this process is fucked up and I am a bit of a mess. Because of that:

* I will work a bit less on #patchfox for now. I don't want to deal with Moz stuff at the moment.
* I might start a Racket SSB thing.
* I am really tired.

[@MK's BIG MACHINE](@TJ9ZGr9vVDZ3F2+cm4KpS7HYAjrwq1O+ZOYd5dm7O50=.ed25519), hey I am not saying "the hell with mozilla". Mozilla still the single independent major browser vendor in the world. It is the only company/foundation without shareholders whose only mandate is to try to make the web a better place, a web made by all and for all. I wish they handled the shutting down of our program better and am quite sad, but I'm not burning it all down.

The alternatives are all worse. Chrome, Chromium, Edge, Opera, Vivaldi, Brave, are all Chrome and operated by companies with their own agendas and stakeholders. You are not a stakeholder in any of those browsers. Safari is not even open source and Apple doesn't care about you, only your money. Every other major vendor sucks more than Mozilla.

And it is not only about browsers but about the rest of Mozilla, the foundation, the fight for net neutrality. There is a lot to love there, but right now, they need to learn how to handle community better.
It used to be better there, community used to be fucking great at Mozilla.
